DOC.HEAD: Zoning OK'd for World's Tallest Building
DOC.TEXT: The Chicago City Council on Friday unanimously approved a zoning request to allow construction of a 125-story building, which would be 15 stories higher than the world's tallest. The building, proposed by the Chicago real estate development firm Miglin-Beitler Inc., would rise 1,950 feet, 496 feet taller than the Sears Tower, currently the world's tallest building. The proposed Miglin-Beitler Tower would be in the city's west Loop area downtown, near the 110-story Sears Tower. The council approved the zoning request 44-0, said Alderman William Banks, chairman of the Committee on Zoning. Developer Paul Beitler said the tower's skinny design will cater to the ``new market of the 1990s'' _ consulting firms, small corporations and other small tenants who can't afford entire floors in fatter office buildings.

DOC.HEAD: Fugitive Arrested After Leaving Long Trail of Taunts
DOC.TEXT: Authorities arrested a woman wanted on a drug charge who eluded police for 18 months, taunting them with telephone calls and a note reading ``Nya, Nya, Nya.'' ``She created her own notoriety on this thing,'' said Lt. Gary Rogness, commander of the Los Angeles Police Department's narcotics unit in the San Fernando Valley. Deborah Ulrich, 42, of Encino was arrested Thursday as she was leaving her son's Hollywood apartment, police said Friday. Police learned of her whereabouts from a news story last month saying she was president of her son's rock group fan club, Rogness said. Ulrich's case started June 19, 1987, when officers searched an apartment and found cocaine valued at $85,000. Police issued a cocaine possession warrant for Ulrich, who was in Mexico at the time. She repeatedly taunted officers with letters and telephone calls in which she said she was innocent, Rogness said. One handwritten letter, posted from Colorado, said: ``Nya, Nya, Nya.'' She addressed the police as ``dingbats'' and said: ``I want to continue to make a fool of you. I'll be a folk hero and you'll look like the moron you are.'' The letter continued: ``Even if you should be lucky enough to get me, which is pretty unlikely, considering how stupid you are, you'd then have to face a jury of my peers who are likely to laugh you out of court,'' he said. After her arrest, Ulrich said she would make bail and flee to Mexico or Canada, said Detective Paul True. Police convinced a judge that Ulrich was a ``flight risk'' and had her held on $1 million bail.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Call-up of Reserves to Caucasus Unleashes Anti-Draft Sentiment
With PM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The calls poured into newspapers, radio and television stations: Young men suddenly were being summoned for active service and their wives and mothers demanded to know why. Then they gathered on town squares and demanded that the call-up stop. ``I won't give up my son!'' a woman shouted furiously at a public protest in the southern Russian city of Stavropol, where President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was Communist Party chief for many years. ``We put up with everything, we put up with it, we put up with it, how long are we going to put up with everything?'' she asked in a report that was shown on the nationwide television news program, ``Vremya.'' At a Stavropol assembly hall, another woman shown on ``Vremya'' proclaimed that her factory objected to the call-up. ``We don't want the peoples of these republics to call us occupants. We don't want another Afghanistan,'' she said. Such powerful reaction to Thursday's call-up of reservists in southern Russia to help impose order in ethnic strife in the Caucasus showed just how public sentiment toward military service had changed in the post-Afghanistan era. The protests appeared to get results. Gorbachev acknowledged the population in the southern Russia areas where the call-up went out were unhappy, and state-run media reported Friday that all the reservists would be home by Wednesday, replaced by career soldiers. In an almost apologetic tone, the Soviet forces' chief political officer, A.D. Lizichev, told Tass that the reserve call-up ``was a forced, but unavoidable measure.'' ``After all, we're talking about the fate of peoples. About bringing order in our Soviet home,'' he said. Such arguments seemed to have little effect, however, on the residents of Stavropol. One speaker at the Stavropol protest urged the several hundred people to come back Saturday to approve an official document calling for the call-up to end and all the reservists to be sent home. A woman in a shiny fur hat complained to the cameras: ``The situation is getting worse, and today when my son is called up, I categorically object to my son's blood being spilled. What for? Because the government isn't taking radical measures.'' During the nine years of the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan, there were virtually no antiwar protests except a few small pickets by brave mothers. But since the last Soviet soldiers pulled out in February, the government has said the intervention was a mistake and it has become acceptable to condemn the Soviet involvement in Afghanistan as an ill-conceived foreign adventure. The youth newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda reported Friday it had been swamped with calls from the families of reservists. ```They've taken my husband to war!' groaned a young woman from Kislovodsk into the phone,'' the newspaper said. ``And then followed calls from Pyatigorsk, Yessentukov, Proletarsk in the Rostov region,'' all cities in the Russian area near the Caucasus.

DOC.HEAD: Rice Bran Study Casts Doubt On Cholesterol-Reducing Effects
Ed: RETRANSMITTING to correct category code.
DOC.TEXT: First, the good stuff about oat bran was debunked in a prestigious medical journal. Now rice is taking its lumps. And the rice industry footed the bill. A University of Texas Health Science Center researcher has just finished a $162,000 study paid for by rice industry backers, and the researcher says if rice bran has any cholesterol-lowering benefits, he hasn't found them. Instead, he advised people trying to lower cholesterol levels to reduce fat intake, get to a normal weight and exercise. The rice industry, which has disassociated itself from the study, says the report by nutritionist Jim Hickson and partner Mark Clasen is inconclusive. Rice Council of America spokesman Kris O'Brien said three other studies have shown rice bran ``does have a positive effect on cholesterol.'' Referring to Hickson's study, O'Brien said, ``We don't think it's proper to say that since his test didn't show anything, the other three studies are wiped out.'' Hickson said, ``The companies were not happy _ they were very unhappy. When you come up empty, it's like you failed.'' In the study, about 64 volunteers spent 15 weeks eating foods prepared by the university health center. In the first 10 weeks, the diet included 50 grams of rice bran daily, most of it concealed in bread. Researchers monitored cholesterol levels. ``We knew by week 6 or 7 nothing was happening,'' Hickson said. At week 10, the rice bran intake was increased to 100 grams a day. Hickson said he questioned whether 100 grams of rice bran a day _ about two cups _ was a realistic amount to consume.

DOC.HEAD: Golden Globes to Kick Off Awards Sweepstakes
DOC.TEXT: ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' ``Glory'' and ``When Harry Met Sally'' were favored in tonight's 47th Annual Golden Globes competition. Hosts Cybill Shepherd and Sam Elliott will preside over the ceremonies, carried by Turner Broadcasting Service starting at 7 p.m. PST. A total of 24 awards _ 13 for motion pictures and 11 for television programs _ were selected by 83 voting members of the Hollywood Foreign Press Association. The globes often serve as indicators of the Academy Awards, whose nominations are to be announced Feb. 14. Last year, for example, ``Rain Man'' took two top Golden Globes and went on to dominate the Academy Awards. ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' director Oliver Stone's gripping account of how a patriotic soldier's attitudes about war are exploded in Vietnam, had five nominations. Tom Cruise, who stars in the film as paraplegic Ron Kovic, was nominated as best actor in a dramatic motion picture. Stone was nominated for best director and the film was named in the race for best dramatic motion picture. Unlike the Academy Awards, the Golden Globes divide films into the categories of dramas and musicals or comedies. Also nominated for best dramatic picture were ``Crimes and Misdemeanors,'' ``Dead Poets Society,'' ``Do the Right Thing'' and ``Glory.'' The selections for best musical or comic movie were ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' ``The Little Mermaid,'' ``Shirley Valentine,'' ``The War of the Roses'' and ``When Harry Met Sally ...'' ``Glory,'' the account of a black Union regiment fighting in the Civil War, earned a total of five nominations, as did ``When Harry Met Sally ...'' ``L.A. Law,'' with eight nominations, was the favored television show.

DOC.HEAD: Academy Mails Oscar Ballots
DOC.TEXT: More than 4,700 actors, directors, writers and other movie tradespeople will be receiving ballots in coming days to select nominees for the 62nd Academy Awards, academy officials said. Academy members will be asked to vote for five nominees in specific categories. For example, ballots for the four acting categories will be sent only to members of the acting branch of the academy. Members have until Feb. 2 to complete the ballots, which were being mailed today. The nominees will be announced Feb. 14 from the Academy's Samuel Goldwyn Theater. The awards will be presented on March 26 at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Makes Safe Landing After Blowing Tire During Takeoff
DOC.TEXT: A Delta Airlines MD-80 jet with 89 people on board blew a tire during takeoff Friday from O'Hare International Airport, but was able to return to the airport safely after dumping its fuel over Lake Michigan, officials said. No injuries were reported. Flight 575, bound for Atlanta, took off from O'Hare at 1:37 p.m. and returned to the airport at 2:34 p.m. after the pilot radioed that a tire in the main landing gear had blown during takeoff, said Federal Aviation Administration spokesman Mort Edelstein. Before returning to O'Hare, the pilot followed standard procedure by dumping fuel over Lake Michigan because the aircraft was too heavy to land with a full fuel load, said Lisa Howard, a spokeswoman for the city's Department of Aviation. Ms. Howard said the plane landed without incident and taxied to the terminal, where passengers left the plane and were placed on other flights.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Killed In Train Collision
DOC.TEXT: A sleepy driver drove his passenger train head-on into a freight train in the central Chinese province of Henan, killing seven people, an official daily said today. Thirteen other people were injured in the crash Monday near the provincial capital of Zhengzhou, the China Daily said. It said the sleepy driver failed to see a stop signal and plowed into the freight train heading for Zhengzhou. The passenger train had just left Zhengzhou for the southwest city of Guiyang.

DOC.HEAD: Army Service To Be Shortened, Troops Reduced
DOC.TEXT: The length of military service will be shortened from 24 to 18 months and the number of Czechoslovak troops slashed by 3O,000 by August, a daily said. The troop cut will begin April 1 and be completed by August, the Svobodne Slovo said Friday, quoting government spokesman Ivan Fiala. The new army conscription terms, proposed by the government, will be submitted to Parliament for approval this spring, and officials say they are assured of approval. The length of army service for university graduates will be reduced from 12 to 9 months, Fiala was quoted as saying. Those soldiers who have families with children as well as servicemen with impaired health will be eligible for the new shortened terms retroactively, state TV said. In January 1989, Czechoslovakia announced cuts in its military manpower and hardware amounting to 138 tanks, 51 planes and 18,OOO soldiers. According to officially published figures, there are 197,OOO regular servicemen in the Czechoslovak army.

DOC.HEAD: First Postwar Prime Minister Dies at 102
DOC.TEXT: A member of the imperial family who became Japan's first prime minister after World War II died today at the age of 102, officials at the Imperial Household Agency said. Naruhiko Higashikuni, a great uncle of Emperor Akihito, had been hospitalized since last May, but his condition worsened in November, the officials said. He died from heart failure at the Nisseki Medical Center in Tokyo. Higashikuni was the first imperial family member to head a Cabinet. He formed it two days after Japan surrendered to the allies on August 15, 1945, at the request of the late Emperor Hirohito. His Cabinet, however, lasted less than two months because of general confusion in the country during the immediate postwar period. In October 1947, Higashikuni left the imperial family to become a commoner. Born in 1887 as the ninth child of Prince Kuninomiya, Higashikuni is an uncle of Nagako, the Empress Dowager and widow of Hirohito. He graduated from military school and studied in France from 1920 to 1927. During World War II he fought in the Japanese imperial army as a general. In 1962, Higashikuni filed a suit against the government claiming his right to a large tract of government-owned land in southern Tokyo because it was given to him by the emperor. He withdrew the case abruptly in 1964.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Test is First Since Anti-Missile Referendum
DOC.TEXT: The Navy flew a Tomahawk cruise missile over Maine on Friday in the first such flight since the state's voters rejected missile tests over their soil in a referendum in November. The unarmed missile went on a 700-mile roundabout flight from the destroyer USS Conolly to a recovery site at a Navy survival school outside Rangeley in western Maine. The test was ``extremely successful,'' said Bob Holsapple, spokesman for the Navy cruise missile project. In Portland, organizers of the referendum to halt the tests were outraged and planned demonstrations next week. The test flight, which began at noon and lasted approximately 90 minutes, followed a meandering path across the center of the state, primarily above forest and mountains. The test had been delayed earlier in the week because of bad weather. Temperatures at flight levels were around zero, allowing the Navy to carry out its mission of testing the Tomahawk's performance in cold weather, Holsapple said. Before parachuting to the ground at the recovery site, the missile circled the town of Rangeley at an altitude of about 3,500 feet, the Navy spokesman said. Eric Johnson, spokesman for the Coalition for the Cruise Missile Referendum, said he was incensed that the Navy's defied Maine voters who approved the non-binding referendum against missile tests by 52 percent to 48 percent. The test is particularly inappropriate when the easing of Cold War tensions has reduced the need expensive weapon systems, he said, maintaining that cruise missiles pose the greatest single obstacle to a strategic arms treaty. Earlier this month, Navy Secretary H. Lawrence Garrett III notified the Maine congressional delegation that three test flights were planned this year despite the referendum.

DOC.HEAD: Dole Predicts Moynihan Social Security Proposal Will `Self-Destruct'
DOC.TEXT: Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole predicts a Democratic proposal to roll back Social Security payroll tax hikes will ``self-destruct'' in Congress. Dole told reporters Friday the move by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., to slash the taxes must be reconciled with another Democrat's push for enactment of a national sales tax _ and predicted that couldn't happen. The Kansas Republican linked the Social Security proposal to legislation to be submitted by Sen. Ernest Hollings, D-S.C., seeking a 5 percent value added tax. ``He'll deliver the good news'' of a tax cut, he said of Moynihan, and Hollings ``will deliver the bad news.'' Because of this, Dole said, the Social Security initiative will ``self-destruct.'' Not only that, Dole said, the White House will soon offer a proposal that would force the government to stop using the Social Security surpluses to reduce the budget deficit. Dole commented as Rep. John Porter, R-Ill., introduced his own proposal for preventing use of surplus Social Security taxes to reduce the federal deficit. Porter said that unlike Moynihan's proposal, his would protect retirees without ``playing tax-cut politics with the Social Security system.'' Meantime, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said that Moynihan's proposal dramatizes ``the inequity and regressive nature'' of the tax system, but he wasn't ready to endorse it. Mitchell said he's worried about the impact of Moynihan's proposal on the multibillion-dollar budget deficit and said he would await two staff studies before making up his mind. But he criticized President Bush for immediately resisting Moynihan's proposal, saying, ``I regret the manner in which the president and the White House has treated t.'' Discussing issues facing lawmakers when the second session of the 101st Congress resumes next week, Mitchell used the Social Security payroll tax issue to attack Bush's tax policies, particularly his quest for a cut in capital gains taxes. The Maine Democrat said Moynihan stated ``in very stark terms the administration's tax policy, which is, `Let's cut taxes for the wealthy, but not the working people. ... Let the little people pay, cut taxes for the very wealthy.''' ``I think that is a tax policy that is unfair and wrong from a policy standpoint, and Senator Moynihan has expressed it dramatically,'' he said. Moynihan wants to roll back the Social Security payroll tax increase that began Jan. 1. His proposal would save workers $7 billion in Social Security taxes this year and $55 billion in fiscal 1991. The payroll tax, paid by both employers and employees, rose to 7.65 percent Jan. 1 from 7.51 percent, and it is levied on wages up to $51,300 instead of $48,000. A wage-earner could pay as much as $3,924 in Social Security taxes this year, an increase of about $319 from 1989. Porter's plan, which is being promoted by House Republican Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia, would return the surplus proportionately to workers. The money would not come in tax cuts or refunds, but into a kind of Individual Retirement Account and each worker's claim on future Social Security benefits would drop as the individual account builds.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnam, US Agree To Joint Projects On Missing Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: Vietnamese and U.S. specialists have agreed to conduct joint activities by the end of February to account for Americans reported missing from the Vietnam War, an official news report said. The two sides reached agreement at a three-day meeting that ended Friday in Vietnam's capital, Hanoi, the Vietnam News Agency said. No details were given in the report, seen today in Bangkok. About 2,300 Americans are listed as missing in action from the war, which ended in a 1975 Communist victory over the U.S.-backed South Vietnam government. Joint activities in recent years have included excavation of sites where U.S. warplanes crashed and field expeditions in which villagers have been asked about crashes that they witnessed.

DOC.HEAD: Secretary of State to Visit Prague
DOC.TEXT: In a show of support for an emerging democracy, Secretary of State James A. Baker III will visit Czechoslovakia next month after he holds talks in Moscow on easing East-West tensions. U.S. officials say Baker may add other Eastern and Central European stops to his schedule, as the Bush administration steps up its campaign of trying to encourage Warsaw Pact countries to adopt Western political and economic systems. Czechoslovakia is making that transition with little indication of tension. It flirted with reform in 1968 and then experienced two decades of hard-line rule after the ``Prague Spring'' was extinguished by Soviet troops and tanks. Baker, who is going to Moscow on Feb. 4 for talks with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, also is considering stops in Romania and Bulgaria, the U.S. officials said Friday. The Bush administration is in the midst of working out a program to lower U.S. tariffs so Czechoslovakia can boost its trade with the United States. That would involve a waiver from strictures of the 1974 Jackson-Vanik amendment, which imposed high tariffs on most communist countries. Baker will discuss with Shevardnadze, among other topics, arms control and the 12-year-old civil war in Afghanistan. Baker will try to resolve with Shevardnadze how long-range, air-launched cruise missiles carried by bombers should be counted against a treaty limit of 6,000 strategic nuclear warheads. The goal is to complete a treaty to reduce U.S. and Soviet long-range missiles by 30 to 50 percent in time for it to be signed by President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at their Washington summit meeting in June. Robert Kimmitt, undersecretary of state for political affairs, met with Afghan rebel leaders Thursday in Pakistan to help set the stage for Baker's meeting with Shevardnadze. The Soviets withdrew their troops from Afghanistan last year, but the pro-Moscow government has managed to hold its own against U.S.-armed rebels. Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said Baker discusses peace prospects for Afghanistan every time he sees Shevardnadze. Baker likely will go to Prague on Feb. 8 or 9, depending on other undecided travel plans, said the officials, who demanded anonymity. He will wind up in Ottawa for the Feb. 12-13 conference with NATO and Warsaw Pact foreign ministers on the U.S. ``open skies'' proposal. That proposal would allow unarmed aircraft to fly over other countries' territories in search of suspected military activity. Czechoslovakia, at one time a hard-line Communist state, is led by President Vaclav Havel and Speaker of the Parliament Alexander Dubcek. Havel, a writer, was a target of the old regime for advocating human rights. Dubcek was a leader of the reform movement that took power in 1968 and then was crushed by Soviet troops and tanks. The country is moving toward democratic elections. Havel's brother, Ivan, a member of Civic Forum, a pro-democracy movement, and Martin Palous, the group's foreign policy spokesman, are due to visit Washington next week.

DOC.HEAD: Georgia Town Commemorates Birth of Oliver Hardy
DOC.TEXT: The town where the hefty half of Laurel and Hardy was born unveiled a marker to commemorate that event and hopes to become a mecca for fans of Oliver Hardy and his frail British pal, Stan Laurel. The ceremony Thursday marked what would have been Hardy's 98th birthday. He was born in 1892 in Harlem, an eastern Georgia village of about 1,500 people, and died in Hollywood in 1957. A proclamation from Georgia Gov. Joe Frank Harris called Hardy, who portrayed a blustering, frustrated dunce in the duo's films, ``the most famous of all Georgia entertainers.'' Guests at the ceremony included Bill Cubin, curator of the Stan Laurel Museum in Ulverston, England, Laurel's hometown.

DOC.HEAD: Young Heartthrob Pleads Innocent to Drunken Driving Charges
DOC.TEXT: Actor Christian Slater, who appeared in ``Tucker: A Man and His Dream'' and ``Heathers,'' pleaded innocent to drunken driving charges. The 20-year-old heartthrob from suburban Van Nuys is charged with five misdemeanor counts, including battery on a police officer and resisting arrest during a late night incident. An Aprl 2 preliminary hearing was set for Slater, who is free on $3,000 bail. He entered his plea on Friday. On Dec. 29, Slater led authorities on a chase through West Hollywood after he was clocked 15 mph above the 35 mph speed limit, authorities said. The chase ended when the actor crashed his car into a pole, authorities said. Tests showed the actor's blood contained .16 percent alcohol, above the legal limit of .10.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Kicks Off Election Season With Broadside at Castro, Ortega
DOC.TEXT: President Bush says the end of former Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega's rule should be a lesson for the ``two holdouts preventing a totally democratic hemisphere,'' Cuba's Fidel Castro and Nicaragua's Daniel Ortega. ``So let Daniel Ortega and Fidel take note, like the dinosaur, the day of the dictator is over,'' Bush declared to a standing ovation at a Republican dinner. Bush, who celebrates the first anniversary of his inauguration today in the privacy of the presidential retreat in Camp David, Md., kicked off the off-year election season by appearing Friday night at a $1,500-a-plate dinner for Republican Gov. Bob Martinez's November re-election effort. Speaking in the city where Noriega remains in custody awaiting trial, Bush praised prosecutors for assembling a team ``to make sure justice prevails.'' ``The world in January 1990 is a very different place than it was in January 1989,'' Bush declared. He cited the end of totalitarian rule throughout Eastern Europe and said that ``a dictator resigned in Panama. Now the people rule in Panama.'' Bush said Castro and Ortega are ``swimming against the tide.'' His remarks produced sustained applause from his audience in a city where anti-Castro sentiment remains high. The president earlier Friday toured a section of the Everglades and spoke to a homebuilders' convention in Atlanta. With a group of local sixth graders in tow, the president spent nearly two hours at the Royal Palm visitor center in the Everglades National Park, listening to a lecture from a park ranger and walking along elevated wooden trails to inspect alligators, turtles, fish, birds and other wildlife. ``I guess you all can go away realizing you have to protect this resource,'' Bush told the students. But he added, ``You can't stop everything from growing. You need sound management.'' Bush has set a goal of ``no-net-loss'' of wetlands, but the administration has yet to produce a strategy to achieve that policy. A White House statement on Friday said a presidential task force studying the matter will spend ``the coming months'' holding public meetings around the country to solicit public comment before making recommendations. Earlier Friday, Bush told the National Association of Homebuilders in Atlanta, ``I am not satisfied'' with the prevailing home mortgage rates of around 10 percent and wants to see lower levels throughout the economy. ``We cannot allow the high costs of housing to suffocate the financial life of America's young people. And when it comes to housing, this must not become a society of `haves' and `have nots,''' Bush said. The homebuilders are experiencing a slump, with housing starts _ construction of new homes and apartments _ hitting their lowest level last year since the 1982 recession. The administration over the past few days has been leaning on the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates, amid reports that momentum for easier credit at the central bank may be ebbing.

DOC.TEXT: Comedian George Burns, who turns 94 today, says his health is good. ``From the hips up, I'm OK. Until you get to the top of my head, where I have to wear toupees. But then, I've been wearing toupees since the '20s.'' Burns continues his heavy work schedule, with one-nighters and casino appearances planned for this year and beyond. He has postponed a date in Las Vegas, where musicians are striking _ ``I won't walk through the picket line.'' Burns brags that his last two books, ``Gracie, a Love Story'' and ``All My Best Friends,'' made the best-seller list, and he is mulling over a murder mystery with co-writer David Fisher. Also in the works: another ``Oh God!'' movie. The comic planned to celebrate his birthday at a restaurant with his show biz chums, including Milton Berle, Carol Channing, Danny Thomas, Dinah Shore and Don Rickles.

Johnny Carson was so frightened of a former mental patient who allegedly threatened him that he hired off-duty police to guard his house around the clock, Carson said. Carson testifed Thursday at a preliminary hearing that he received at least five letters and tapes _ the letters signed ``Ken Orville Gause, the Baron KOG'' _ which threatened him and his staff if he refused to hand over millions of dollars. Gause, a Milwaukee resident, had been seen at his house and at NBC's Burbank studios where ``The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson'' is taped, Carson said. He was arrested Dec. 5 in the lobby of the studios. Authorities said Gause carried a sock filled with gravel and had Carson's address in his possession when he was arrested. Burbank Municipal Judge Marion E. Gubler ordered Gause, 36, to stand trial in August on 10 counts of extortion and making terrorist threats. Gause is to be arraigned Feb. 2 and remains in custody on $250,000 bail.

Country singer Reba McEntire has plenty of stage experience, but she found acting harder than anything she'd done before except for farming. McEntire plays a heavily armed survivalist in a supporting part in the movie ``Tremors,'' starring Kevin Bacon. ``It's the hardest work I've ever had in life, except for gathering cattle at age 14,'' she said. ``But once you're on a stage and acting out the words to the songs each night for the fans, the acting didn't come hard for me at all,'' she said Thursday. McEntire, who is expecting her first child, is known for her hits ``Whoever's in New England'' and ``Cathy's Clown.'' She was voted female vocalist of the year by the Country Music Association from 1984 through 1987.

Artists Andrew and Jamie Wyeth took actor Charlton Heston and his son on an illustrated tour of ``Treasure Island.'' Heston and his son, Fraser, on Thursday traveled to Brandywine River Museum for a look at patriarch N.C. Wyeth's drawings for the novel. The museum is exhibiting 18 of Wyeth's illustrations. Fraser Heston recently directed a made-for-TV movie of the famous adventure novel, starring his father as Long John Silver, for the Turner Broadcasting Network. The Hestons then hosted a private viewing of the new movie for the Wyeths. In 1911, N.C. Wyeth's illustrations depicted Robert Louis Stevenson's tale of a strange island, populated by sinister pirates and a young adventurous boy.

Actress Jennifer Grey said she has had enough of relationships with actors, and will have her eye on others. ``In the words of my people, `Never again,''' Grey told US magazine in its Feb. 5 issue. ``I'm an equal opportunity dater. I think everybody should have a shot.'' Grey, best known for her role in ``Dirty Dancing,'' went out with Matthew Broderick for three years and was engaged to Johnny Depp for nine months. She described the two as ``lovely boys.'' The actress said the naive character she played in ``Dirty Dancing'' is not her. ``Sometimes I think I did too good a job because people think that's who I am,'' she said. ``I was never that innocent in my whole life. Ever. Ever!''

Donald Trump's 282-foot ``Trump Princess'' is too cramped for parties, so the billionaire is getting a bigger yacht. The current Trump Princess _ recognized in the Guinness Book of World Records as the world's largest private yacht _ has become too small for the Trumps to entertain guests, Trump spokesman Jeff Walker said. The new 420-foot version, which he expects to unveil in 1992, will be fitted with a Roman bath and amphitheater. Meantime, Trump is looking for a buyer of the old yacht. He paid $30 million for it; his asking price is $115 million.

Actor Todd Bridges of TV's old series ``Diff'rent Strokes'' is headed for a second legal battle with his former accountant. Bridges sued Larry W. Risse, a Sherman Oaks accountant, for allegedly concealing assets when the two settled another lawsuit accusing the accountant of embezzling $400,000. Bridges contends in the lawsuit filed Thursday in Superior Court that he never would have agreed to the 1988 settlement had he known Risse and his wife had more in assets than their home. The lawsuit alleges fraud and negligent misrepresentation. Calls to Risse's office on Friday went unanswered. Bridges, who played Willis Jackson on ``Diff'rent Strokes,'' was acquitted last year of attempted murder in a shooting that critically injured a man.

DOC.HEAD: Continental Jet Landed on Same Runway as Eastern Jet, Small Plane
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with pilot quotes. Pick up 7th grf pvs: `Shortly after...
DOC.TEXT: The pilot of an Eastern Airlines jet that crashed into a smaller plane didn't see it ahead on the runway until the last minute because he had been watching another jetliner that landed in front of them, federal investigators said Friday. A Continental Airlines jet had been cleared to land on the same runway ahead of the twin-engine Beechcraft Air King, which was struck from behind by the Eastern Boeing 727-200, said Robert MacIntosh, an investigator with the National Transportation Safety Board. The accident at Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport late Thursday killed the pilot of the smaller plane and injured the co-pilot. There were no other injuries reported. ``We were on the ground, and we were in stopping mode, and suddenly there they were,'' said the pilot, 23-year Eastern veteran Ralph Orlando. ``But we couldn't fly anymore. We weren't at flying speed anymore, and we had our speed brakes deployed. We couldn't have possibly lifted over it.'' ``My first instinct was to try to avoid contact. So I made a sharp left turn to avoid it. But that wasn't enough. But I also had a plane of people to consider,'' said Orlando. The pilot didn't explain why he hadn't seen the small plane sooner. Just before the Eastern jet overran the Beechcraft plane at about 7:10 p.m., the air traffic controller told the Continental pilot to stop between runways after he had cleared the airport's northernmost runway, MacIntosh said at a news conference. All three planes had been cleared to land on the runway, and all three pilots were tuned into the same radio frequency with the controller, he said. MacIntosh said the controller told Easter pilot Orlando, that he had his plane in sight. Shortly after that transmission, the controller asked the Continental plane to ``hold short'' of the parallel runway, an order MacIntosh said meant the plane should stop between the two runways. He said investigators had yet to determine why that order was given. The Continental pilot, who has yet to be identified, did not immediately acknowledge the instruction and the tower controllers discussed among themselves whether they thought the pilot had heard it, MacIntosh said. Shortly thereafter, the Eastern pilot reported having hit the Beechcraft. ``The captain (of the Eastern flight) stated he had been looking down the runway in some awareness of the Continental. He saw the tail of the (Beechcraft) aircraft a very short time before impact,'' MacIntosh said. MacIntosh said investigators do not know why the Eastern pilot was not aware of the Beechcraft until just before the accident. He said the Eastern pilot did not acknowledge hearing the controller's instructions clearing the Beechcraft for landing. ``I'm certainly not in position to judge error yet,'' he said, adding, ``It would be absolutely glib for me to opinionize on what should have taken place.'' MacIntosh said investigators would spend the weekend examining the cockpit recorder tapes and studying the distances between the planes, the approaches of the plane and the controller's conduct. Earlier Friday, Eastern said its pilot had been cleared to land and didn't see the smaller plane ``until he was right on top of him.'' Another NTSB spokesman, Drucella Andersen, said that under aircraft approach rules, ``the arriving aircraft cannot be cleared to land until the preceding aircraft has left the runway.'' ``We won't speculate as to what this might mean. I can't tell you what the cause is,'' Ms. Andersen said. Federal Aviation Administration spokesman Jack Barker said, ``It's not unusual for the tower to clear more than one airplane to land. The pilots must adjust to whatever conditions arise.'' The normal landing procedure for a line of planes is to keep a distance of three to six miles between each of them in the air, Barker said. The rule is designed to give the first plane time to land, roll out and clear the runway before the next plane crosses the runway boundary. If for some reason the first plane does not clear the runway, the second plane is supposed to go into a ``missed approach procedure'' and go around the first plane, Barker said. But Eastern spokesman Jim Ashlock said the Eastern pilot did not see the first plane in time to take evasive action. ``He was cleared to land and that tells him, `my runway is clear and I can come on in,''' Ashlock said. The Eastern jet, rolling down the runway at 120 mph, sheared off the roof of the twin-propeller plane, which was owned by Epps Air Service and based at a suburban airport, authorities said. There were no injuries to the Eastern plane's 141 passengers and crew of eight. Airport spokesman John Braden said there was a little rain and fog at the airport Thursday evening, but ``it was not bad weather.'' Ashlock said he did not know who was at the controls at the time of the accident, but he said the entire Eastern crew had extensive flying experience. Orlando had been a pilot for Eastern since 1967, he said. The first officer, co-pilot Michael D. Runyan, hired by Eastern last March, had 7,388 hours of flying time and second officer Henry Stanford, hired by Eastern last April, had 5,430 hours flying experience, Ashlock said. Both planes Friday remained on the runway, which was closed.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Soviet Troops Fight Extremists in Streets of Baku, 7 Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 2nd pvs, `State Radio,' to UPDATE with radio confirming troops entered, reporting casualties. Pick up 3rd pvs, `The spokeswoman...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOSB1,3,47, NY11, LON3
DOC.TEXT: Soviet troops broke through blockades set up by ethnic extremists in downtown Baku early Saturday and killed at least seven people in street battles, a spokeswoman for a militant Azerbaijani group said. State Radio Moscow later Saturday announced that the Presidium of the national Supreme Soviet, the government's top executive body, had declared a state of emergency in Baku because of the ``sharp aggravation of the situation'' that it blamed on ``criminal extremist forces'' in the city. The radio confirmed that military units entered Baku, saying they were fired on by ``militants of the Popular Front'' of Azerbaijan and ``were forced to retaliate.'' It said casualties had been reported but did not give a figure. The spokeswoman said two pitched battles were fought inside the Azerbaijani capital, leaving at least seven Azerbaijanis dead. ``It's very dangerous on the street,'' she said. ``Battles are still going on.'' The official news agency Tass carried no reports of troops fighting in Baku, an oil center and port of 1.8 million residents on the Caspian Sea. Western reporters have not been allowed to go to the scene since the ethnic violence flared a week ago. The army intervention, the first such combat reported in Baku involving Soviet soldiers, came after ethnic riots turned into open warfare between Azerbaijani and Armenian militants. Bad blood between the two peoples goes back centuries. If the latest deaths are confirmed, the toll now would be at least 79 people killed and more than 220 wounded. Army and internal security troops poured into the southern republics for days, but had not entered Baku until shortly after midnight Friday. Leila Unusova, a spokeswoman for an organization calling itself the Azerbaijani Social Democrat Group, reported by telephone from Baku that Soviet troops surrounded a square near the Communist Party headquarters building where about 30,000 Azerbaijanis gathered in an antigovernment protest. She said the forces had armored personnel carriers, water cannon and other military equipment but she did not know if soldiers at the square opened fire. ``Our citizens blockaded roads on the south and north with cars and buses,'' she told The Associated Press. ``Young people, 20 to 25 years old, were there,'' manning the barricades. She said that shortly after midnight, Soviet army units entered the city from the north and from a base inside the Baku military academy and fired on the militants' positions. A doctor told her two young men were killed in one street battle and five to seven others died at another site. Wounded were being taken to three city hospitals, the spokeswoman reported, hours after fighting broke out. About 5,000 regular army troops and thousands more Interior Ministry soldiers and police had moved into the troubled areas to try to restore order, but Soviet authorities were reluctant to engage the militants directly. The military's violent breakup of a nationalist demonstration in Tbilisi, Georgia, last April, in which 19 people were killed, touched off a national scandal. And a Defense Ministry callup of reservists to reinforce military units on Thursday was abruptly suspended a day later in the face of widespread public protest. An American journalist in Moscow spoke by telephone before dawn Saturday to a spokesman for the Azerbaijani People's Front in Baku, who said Soviet soldiers were engaged in street fighting and doctors were told to stand by. The sounds of gunfire could be heard in the background over the telephone, said the U.S. journalist, Los Angeles Times correspondent Masha Hamilton. Phone connections to the Caucasus from Moscow have been cut much of this week, making confirmation of reported fighting extremely difficult. Moscow Radio said reinforcements were being sent to Armenia and Azerbaijan. Earlier Friday, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev blamed extremists opposed to his reforms for the ethnic warfare in the Caucasus and said some Azerbaijanis were calling for a separate Islamic state. His comments came as Azerbaijanis reportedly brought arms into the country over the border they have forced open with Iran. Others rallied in Baku, with some calling for the violent overthrow of Soviet power and a union of the predominantly Moslem republic with Iran's Azerbaijan region, Tass said. Many of the troops sent to the southern republics have been unable to reach their destinations because hundreds of Azerbaijanis have blocked airports and roads with trucks and buses, opposing what they view as Kremlin interference. Despite attempts by the troops to maintain order in Armenia and Azerbaijan, Gorbachev said the situation was not improving following six days of battles. ``It's still difficult. People's lives are in danger,'' Gorbachev told British TV. A Moscow Radio broadcast said Friday that ``additional contingents'' of troops were being brought into Armenia and Azerbaijan and ``new sub-units'' of Interior Ministry troops had arrived in Nagorno-Karabakh, an Armenian-dominated enclave in Azerbaijan. Both Armenia and Azerbaijan claim the territory. Gorbachev told a conference on his reforms that the warfare served the interests of ``a group of extremists, irresponsible adventurists and representatives of the shadow economy.'' The shadow economy refers to the billions of rubles of illegal trade transacted outside the state-run economy. ``Perestroika is a bone in their throat, but they can't oppose it directly, so they clutch at tension on an ethnic basis,'' Gorbachev said, according to Tass. Tass said Gorbachev also blamed Azerbaijani extremists who are ``calling for the republic to secede from the U.S.S.R., for an Islamic Azerbaijan.'' But, he added, ``among the people they are not receiving support.'' Tass said demonstrators in Baku called for secession from the Soviet Union and the unification of Soviet Azerbaijan with its Iranian counterpart ``under the flag of a single Islamic state.'' People who didn't agree were threatened with violence, Tass said. The People's Front newspaper, called Freedom, charged Moscow with provoking the ethnic warfare, the government newspaper Izvestia said. Other Soviet media made Baku sound as if it had been virtually taken over by the Azerbaijani People's Front. Members have captured offices of the KGB, the Interior Ministry and the prosecutor, destroying documents and trying to seize weapons, according to Interfax, a news service of Radio Moscow. Extremists blockaded the Communist Party leadership's headquarters and demanded the government resign, the Azerbaijani news agency Azerinform reported. Baku was paralyzed Friday as workers struck to press demands that Soviet troops be withdrawn from the city and to protest plans for a curfew, said Savili Peretz, Azerinform's deputy director. Most Azerbaijanis are Shiite Moslems, and most Armenians are Christians. They have been fighting, striking and demonstrating sporadically for two years in a dispute over Nagorno-Karabakh. The latest round of violence began Jan. 13 with anti-Armenian riots in Baku. The unrest worsened on the Iranian border, where Azerbaijanis destroyed guard posts, fences and security alarms this month in a drive to reunite with their ethnic neighbors. Despite checks by border guards, Azerbaijanis brought weapons across the border from Iran, Izvestia reported Friday. Izvestia said extremists commandeered three trains carrying soldiers and military equipment in Azerbaijan. Tass reported three people were killed and four wounded Friday in an Azerbaijani attack in Yeraskh in the Armenian republic on the border with the Azerbaijani enclave of Nakhichevan. It was the first report of Azerbaijani attackers crossing into Armenia.

DOC.HEAD: Atwater Tells GOP to Tell It Straight on Abortion
DOC.TEXT: Republican National Chairman Lee Atwater says the party welcomes candidates on both sides of the divisive abortion debate and warns they risk all but certain defeat if they try to avoid the issue. ``There is no litmus test,'' Atwater said Friday in his keynote address to the Republican National Committee's winter meeting, which was dominated by discussion of how the GOP can blunt the Democrats' successful use of abortion against Republicans last year. Atwater said he and President Bush would stick to their anti-abortion positions but said ``we both understand that a great national party is built on many individuals'' with different views. ``Our party is big enough to accept different views on many different issues,'' Atwater said, calling the internal debate over abortion one of the ``growing pains'' of trying to become a majority party. This year's state elections are considered especially important because they will determine which party will control congressional redistricting based on the 1990 census. ``In 1990 no candidate can run for public office without squarely facing the abortion issue,'' Atwater said. Democrats running in 1989 for governor and lieutenant governor of Virginia, governor of New Jersey and mayor of New York won by pressing their pro-choice positions against GOP candidates who had anti-abortion records. Apparent attempts by the Republicans to moderate their stances were ridiculed by Democrats, who Atwater said ``pulled a reverse twist on us'' by borrowing a key Atwater election strategy. ``They defined our candidates before they defined themselves and that's almost always fatal,'' Atwater said. ``What no voter likes is vacillating, waffling or double talk.'' At a news conference after his speech, Atwater said he, Bush and the national party would work diligently for pro-choice Republicans despite differences on abortion. Other Republicans should also put party loyalty first, he said. He said that in private sessions with the GOP leaders _ talks dominated by abortion politics _ ``there seems to be a consensus'' to welcome pro-choice GOP candidates without abandoning the party's anti-abortion plank. An attempt by one RNC member to get the meeting to reaffirm that plank failed Thursday. Other participants said it was best to avoid such a move because of the problems it could cause some candidates. Bush, however, shows no signs of keeping his anti-abortion views under wraps. He vetoed two bills last year that would have allowed the use of federal funds for abortions in cases of rape and incest and the White House said Friday that Bush will address a rally of abortion foes via telephone Monday, the 17th anniversary of the Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion.

DOC.HEAD: Followers of Greeks, Romans, Marcel Marceau Take to the Stage
DOC.TEXT: Toby Sedgwick has been lying on a London stage this week pretending to be a slice of bacon, sizzling in a pan. As he twists and turns, the room is filled with the smell of frying bacon _ at least to the noses of many of those watching. Sedgwick is a mime artist, and some of the world's best are performing in the 12th London Mime Festival, the oldest event of its kind. During the two-week festival, the mimes are performing in theaters, concert halls, local community arts centers, universities, even a library, in London and in towns across England. ``We have probably presented every major mime in the world,'' festival director Joseph Seelig claimed in an interview. Mime is entertainment without words, a form of theater practiced by the ancient Greeks and Romans. Seelig called it ``the art of creating illusion in silence, without props or music, just the body.'' The world's best-known mime is probably Frenchman Marcel Marceau, who wears the white makeup of a clown, a striped jersey and a tall hat, and makes you believe he is climbing the stairs when there are none. ``Marceau has one style, but he is so famous he has eclipsed the others,'' Seelig said. ``Charlie Chaplin was a mime, but nobody thinks of that.'' ``Because of Marceau, people think mime in France is bound to be the best and popular, but it isn't so. Mime is wonderful in Eastern Europe, and there are splendid American mimes.'' Dan Kamin, a busy American performer, has his own show at the festival called ``Confessions of an Illusionist.'' His book, ``Charlie Chaplin's One-Man Show,'' is regarded by many in the profession as the definitive study of Chaplin's art. Mime blossomed in Czechoslovakia because under the old Hapsburg Empire, the Austrian rulers made German the official language. Actors circumvented the prohibition on their own languages in theaters with mime theater, which didn't need a license. Seelig called the Czech mime Bolek Polivka, who is taking part in the festival, ``the greatest clown of our time.'' Polivka and his partner, Chantal Poulain, work with every theatrical trick in the book: costumes, masks, puppets and illusion. Michael Stanwood and Jim Jackson of Denver ask in their ``Mimic Sole'' show: ``Is it art, or are you just having a good time?'' To the accompaniment of Stanwood's autoharp, keyboards and car spring, Jackson juggles, dances on a tightrope and traps the unwary in gigantic soap bubbles. Between festivals, Seelig travels to see new acts and listen out for tips on who is new and good. ``Nineteen of 20 are a dead loss, but the one can be something very exciting,'' he said. ``Mime is a small world.'' Helen Lannaghan, the festival co-director, said the budget is small and dependent on box office receipts, with some help from the state-funded Arts Council. Income from all sources is $165,000. This year's festival opened Jan. 15 and runs through Jan. 28.

DOC.HEAD: State Losing Millions In Fake Medi-Cal Diaper Claims
DOC.TEXT: ``Sticker bandits'' who found a loophole in a state health care plan for the poor may be cheating taxpayers out of more than $100 million a year, a published report said. All it takes to become a Medi-Cal ``provider'' is to ask the state for a number and start sending in bills, said Carlo Michelotti, who heads Medi-Cal's anti-fraud efforts. Under Medi-Cal, those who qualify for state-paid care each month get a card with five identification stickers. When they receive medicine or medical supplies, they pay by handing over a sticker, and the pharmacy or store then bills the state. But hundreds of people are stealing or buying the stickers, using them to authenticate phony orders for diapers, rubber sheets and pants and other incontinence supplies and then charging the state, the San Jose Mercury News reported. These supplies are especially difficult for medical specialists to keep track of, Michelotti said. ``A diaper is a buck a pop,'' he said. ``It's a pretty innocuous thing.'' ``The crooks have discovered a weakness in the system, and they're busy driving trucks through it,'' said Steve Adler, chief of the state Justice Department's Medi-Cal fraud bureau. The amount being stolen in diaper scams is enough to pay for two doctor visits for every one of California's 3.3 million Medi-Cal recipients, according to the newspaper. The state reimbursement is about $1 a diaper. Over the past nine months, the Justice Department's Medi-Cal fraud unit has been investigating seven alleged diaper bandit cases, each involving millions of dollars. Last fall, the owner and four employees of an Oakland company were arrested and accused of defrauding the state of $9 million. The case has not yet gone to court. State health officials suspected rip-offs after the yearly payments for diapers and other incontinence supplies quadrupled in two straight years _ from $30 million to $120 million. For the current fiscal year, officials expect the bill to reach at least $150 million _ of which only $35 million is legitimate. Fifty people every week apply to become Medi-Cal providers, compared to about one application a week a few years ago, Michelotti said. Medi-Cal hopes for new rules sometime this year to allow the screening of applicants. Until then, thousands of bills will be paid without question, he said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Ordered to Protect Documents Seized By Troops in Panama
With PM-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys for Manuel Noriega have forced the U.S. government to protect documents confiscated from the homes and offices of the ousted Panamanian leader and provide a list of the papers to the defense. U.S. Magistrate William Turnoff made the ruling Friday after defense attorney Steven Kollin filed an emergency motion requesting the move. Kollin stated in his motion that Assistant U.S. Attorney Myles Malman traveled to Panama City to inspect material belonging to Noriega that was seized by U.S. troops during the invasion last month that removed Noriega from power. Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Sullivan refused to discuss Malman's trip to Panama, but didn't object to the order. It would be nearly impossible to determine which of the documents would have direct bearing on Noriega's drug trafficking case, Sullivan said, calling the defense motion unrealistic. But Turnoff ordered that the documents be protected and an inventory done. But he told Kollin the defense must give more specific information on the addresses of Noriega's homes in Panama City and Rio Hato and disclose which offices he occupied in the Panama defense Forces headquarters and Fort Amador. The magistrate said the inventory of documents from Noriega's houses must be available by Thursday, the day before Noriega's bond hearing. Turnoff said that was because the defense contended some evidence from the homes may bear on the hearing. Earlier Friday, U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler cautioned both sides to avoid intimidation in the case of Noriega co-defendant Luis del Cid. But Hoeveler refused to order government investigators to keep away from defense witnesses in that case. An attorney for del Cid complained that investigators from the Immigration and Naturalization Service visited the defendant's wife and two friends shortly after the three testified at a bond hearing Tuesday, and intimidated them about their residency. Del Cid's wife, Tilsa del Cid, is Panamanian. The other two women, Norma and Eglantina Alvarez, are Nicaraguan refugees. Hoeveler noted that the three women had offered to take custody of del Cid if he is freed on bond. ``It is important for me to get the full picture of what their status is,'' Hoeveler said. But he added: ``No investigator for either side can intimidate witnesses.''

DOC.HEAD: Barry, Advisors to Debate His Political Future in Wake of Drug Charges
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry's top aide is running the city government while political advisers assess the mayor's future in the wake of his arrest on a federal cocaine possession charge. Barry, who said he is innocent of the crime, wept Friday when he told his cabinet he was turning over most of the reins of District of Columbia government to his city administrator. Barry's arrest late Thursday in an FBI ``sting'' operation at a Washington hotel for allegedly smoking crack and his appearance before a federal magistrate Friday threw the city government into turmoil and threatened to end his political career. U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens told reporters a court-ordered blood test administered to Barry after his arrest came back positive. Barry's advisers, many of whom have weathered years of federal investigations targeting Barry, were meeting again today to debate whether he can still consider running for a fourth term. His aides were deeply divided at stormy meetings Friday over whether the mayor should give up at least part of his duties and seek drug treatment, according to a source familiar with the sessions who spoke on condition of anonymity. The source said Barry's cabinet assembled in a contentious session while the mayor met with some his own advisers. Barry eventually joined the full cabinet meeting, rejecting suggestions that he enter a treatment program but telling his staff in a tearful statement that he would give up day-to-day operations to City Administrator Carol B. Thompson. Barry's office said in a statement that the change in government was based on the mayor's ``need for time to handle his legal affairs, his concern for his family, and because it is in the best interests of the citizens of Washington, D.C.'' The mayor canceled a rally scheduled for Sunday at which he was to formally announce his candidacy for re-election. Jesse Jackson, whose April move to Washington sparked rumors he would run for mayor, said in Chicago that he was stunned by Barry's arrest and hoped the case would be tried ``in the courtroom, not the newsrooms.'' ``I think at this point it's inappropriate to talk about the politics of the matter and the legal options until we get all the information about just what has happened,'' he said. A stone-faced Barry and his wife, Effi, walked through a sea of reporters outside the federal courthouse to get to his hearing before U.S. Magistrate Deborah Robinson. He was released on personal bond and told he must submit to a urine test once a week. Outside the courthouse, Barry declined comment on the case or his political future, and his lawyer said he would plead innocent to the misdemeanor charge. If convicted, the mayor could face penalties of up to one year in jail and a $100,000 fine, said Stephens. He faces another court appearance Feb. 5. Barry was lured to the FBI-rented room by an ex-lover who agreed to cooperate with investigators, said a law enforcement who spoke on condition of anonymity. The woman was identified by sources familiar with the case as Rasheeda Moore. One source said Ms. Moore agreed to cooperate after she got into trouble with state authorities in California. According to court papers filed by federal prosecutors, the room was watched through a surveillance camera and Barry was taped as he gave ``a quantity of currency'' to a cooperating witness in return for the crack and smoked the cocaine in a pipe. Federal agents then entered the hotel room and arrested the mayor. The Washington Post, in today's editions, quoted a law enforcement source who said Barry ``was shocked, shocked ... totally taken aback'' when the agents moved in. At City Hall, other elected officials struggled to assure city workers and residents alike that the government will function despite the crisis created by Barry's arrest. ``It is very important that we retain some sense of normalcy,'' said city council member Betty Ann Kane after a closed meeting to discuss the crisis. ``It was very somber in there, (with) people still in a state of shock. Everyone is concerned about being able to reassure people that the city is not going to fall apart.'' Stephens dismissed suggestions the mayor may have been unfairly entrapped in the hotel ``sting'' operation. The ``carefully planned, carefully reviewed and carefully executed'' undercover operation was ``scrupulously fair to the defendant, Mr. Barry,'' Stephens said. ``There was no entrapment there.'' But many observers said the legal questions about the case are outweighed by the political damage the arrest will cause. Jeffrey Gildenhorn, a fundraiser for Barry's reelection effort, likened the mayor's arrest to the mood of the President Nixon's White House as the pressures of Watergate mounted in 1974. ``I feel at this point a similar despair,'' Gildenhorn said.

DOC.HEAD: Groups Ask Court to Just Say No to DEA Ruling
DOC.TEXT: Two groups are asking a federal court to make the government allow marijuana to be used for medical applications. Used as a drug for centuries, marijuana has been known to have therapeutic potential for 150 years, but its been illegal in the United States since 1937. For the past 15 years _ most recently last month _ the Drug Enforcement Administration has rejected bids to make marijuana available for such purposes as controlling nausea in cancer patients and treatment of glaucoma. But groups went to federal court Friday to try to overturn the DEA's latest decision and force the agency to change marijuana's status as a Schedule I drug, which is available only for research, to a Schedule II drug, which would make it available for patient use. Only synthetic tetrahydrocannabinol, THC, is available on Schedule II for use as a cancer chemotherapy anti-nauseant, and Kevin Zeese, counsel for the Drug Policy Foundation, says it doesn't work as well as the real thing. Studies by a half-dozen states comparing marijuana and the synthetic THC for their anti-nausea properties found ``marijuana's much more effective and much safer as well,'' said Zeese. The foundation represented the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws and the Alliance for Cannibis Therapeutics in the appeal with the U.S. Court of Appeals. Zeese said that when patients are given synthetic THC, ``a patient takes the whole pill and is stuck with the whole pill, whether he needs it or not. ``With THC, you're taking the pure drug, a much more mind-altering substance. You see God on that stuff. It's like tripping,'' Zeese said. ``Marijuana is something the patient can control. A cancer patient will take two smokes off a marijuana cigarette and that's all he needs.'' The government provides marijuana for free in some cases when the Food and Drug Administration approves use of the drug for ``compassionate'' medical purposes. However, medical marijuana advocates say the process is time-consuming and discourages physicians from applying for the right to prescribe the drug. The FDA said at least 24 ``compassionate'' applications have been approved since the first in 1976, and some covered more than one patient. Robert Randall of the Alliance for Cannabis Therapeutics, who suffers from glaucoma and was the first to get the FDA's nod, said he and four other patients have the only current government approval to use the drug. Zeese noted the latest appeal is the fifth time the issue has gone to court, but said previous cases have been based more on procedural matters. ``This is the first time (the case) is on the issue of whether marijuana has medical value,'' Zeese said. The appeal targets the Dec. 29 decision by DEA Administrator John C. Lawn that overturned a recommendation by DEA's chief administrative law judge, Francis L. Young. Young, in recommending that marijuana be placed on the less restrictive schedule, called the drug ``one of the safest therapeutically active substances known to man.''

DOC.HEAD: Cavazos Offers Goals for Higher Education
DOC.TEXT: Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos is calling on college and university leaders to help ensure that advanced education is available for any American who wants it, regardless of race or economic status. He told the American Council on Education on Friday, ``By the year 2000, students from all population segments and economic groups who aspire to enter and complete programs of post-secondary education (should) have equal access to a quality education.'' The Bush administration and nation's governors are preparing specific guidelines and timetables to improve learning mainly in elementary and secondary schools, but Cavazos said higher education leaders need to define their mission as well. ``Universities and colleges must assume leadership in restructuring education in America today,'' he told about 1,200 educators in the luncheon speech. Cavazos declined to comment on an Associated Press story that said President Bush will call in his State of the Union address for guaranteed pre-school programs for disadvantaged children and for a cut in dropout rates by about half by the end of the decade. Among the goals for advanced education, Cavazos proposed to: _Reduce by half the gap the degree completion rates between black and Hispanic students, and white and Asian students. Cavazos noted 55 percent of blacks and 51 percent of Hispanics who enter higher education do not earn degrees, compared with 33 percent of other students. _Make sure 50 percent of all bachelor's degree recipients are able to demonstrate proficiency in a foreign language. About 10 percent of students now demonstrate such a proficiency. _Guarantee that all associate and bachelors' degree recipients are proficient in college level math and science, can write coherent, grammatically correct papers, display a basic knowledge of world history, geography and culture, and have high critical thinking and problem-solving skills. _Increase by 25 percent the number of college graduates completing doctoral programs in the basic arts, mathematics, sciences, engineering and technological disciplines, and by 50 percent the number of women, blacks, Indians and Hispanics in the group. Cavazos stressed a special effort must be made in minority teacher preparation. ``You must involve yourself in helping America restructure elementary and secondary education,'' he said. ``I must remind you that the quality of the student that comes to your university or college is totally dependent upon what is occurring in the public elementary and secondary schools of America today.''

DOC.HEAD: Baker Makes Headway But Mideast Negotiations Remain Elusive
DOC.TEXT: A first round of Mideast negotiations is still beyond the reach of Secretary of State James A. Baker III after a busy week of diplomacy. He wound up Friday with Egyptian Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid, who left ``cautiously optimistic'' that Baker would succeed eventually. But the State Department gave no indication of a breakthrough in a brief summary of their 45-minute meeting. And the Egyptian did not claim one. Diplomatic sources said Abdel-Meguid on Tuesday brought Baker Egypt's suggestions for hurdling a dispute over Palestinian participation in negotiations and that Israeli Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin took them back to Jerusalem for consideration. No details were provided by the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Rabin was expected to follow up the proposals with Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir while Israeli Finance Minister Shimon Peres is due to meet in Cairo next week with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak. ``I am cautiously optimistic about the outcome of this whole exercise because there is a keen interest and awareness of the necessity for peace for all of us in our area,'' Abdel-Meguid told reporters after his third and final session with Baker. ``We have been discussing some very important points,'' he said. ``I am not in a position to say more about them.'' Asked if the gap had been narrowed, he replied: ``I think yes.'' Baker's intention is to have Abdel-Meguid and Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Arens hold a three-way meeting with him in Washington in late February. The main hurdle is what role, if any, is to be played by the Palestine Liberation Organization. Israel wants to keep the PLO out of the negotiations; Egypt is working with Yasser Arafat's organization to try to gain a foothold in the talks. Even as Baker pursued his diplomacy, the State Department took another slap at Israel. It criticized the detention of Faisal Husseini, a pro-PLO Palestinian activist, as detrimental to U.S. peace efforts in the Middle East. Although spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said U.S. officials had not sorted out the allegations, she read a statement that said ``we are surprised and disturbed'' by reports that Husseini and other Palestinians had been detained. ``Such actions discourage Palestinian confidence in the peace process and contribute to the prevailing atmosphere of distrust,'' the statement said. While criticizing Shamir on Tuesday the State Department also faulted the Israeli policy of settling Jews on the West Bank and in Gaza. Ms. Tutwiler said the establishment of new settlements or expansion of existing ones did not promote the cause of peace. Asked if the settlements also were illegal _ a position taken by the Carter administration _ the spokeswoman said the Bush administration had not addressed the question.

DOC.HEAD: Disclose Some Rare Threats, Airline-Government Session Says
DOC.TEXT: Threats against airlines _ real threats and hoaxes _ are sparking debate between air carriers and the federal government about whether the flying public should be kept informed. After a lengthy meeting Friday between officials of nine major U.S. passenger airlines and the Federal Aviation Administration, an apparent consensus emerged that on extremely rare occasions, informing the public is ``the prudent thing to do.'' But FAA Administrator James B. Busey said after the session that his agency's official opposition remains unchanged, at least so far. ``Currently, the FAA believes that publicizing threats against airlines would be counterproductive to the security process,'' Busey said. The meeting was prompted by the recent decisions by Northwest and Delta Airlines to publicize threats against some flights. The disclosures were an exception to the industry's usual practice of taking such threats seriously and trying to nullify them _ but not making them public. Busey called the meeting ``a listening session'' and said it gave the airlines ``an opportunity to discuss the need, if any, for changes in the current policy toward threats against airline flights.'' He said he believes ``these kinds of threats are most effectively handled by security professionals who are in a position to implement countermeasures.'' Jim Buckhorn, an FAA spokesman, said that as the session ended, ``the consensus seemed to be that it wasn't a good thing to publicize all threats but that they agreed there are instances where it is the prudent thing to do.'' Buckhorn said most of those present agreed it was not a good idea to make public hoax telephone calls. ``There are 600 or so such calls each year,'' he said. ``Our experience has shown that publicity simply encourages more hoax telephone calls.'' But Busey said keeping the lid on most threats does not mean the safety of travelers is not fully taken into account. ``The flying public should be aware that if a threat is determined to be specific, credible, and cannot be countered, the targeted flight is cancelled,'' he said. Buckhorn said Busey will schedule a meeting later with representatives of the Aviation Consumer Action Project, a consumer advocacy group which wants the FAA and the airlines to fully inform the public when bomb threats are received.

DOC.HEAD: Two Female Soldiers Refused To Enter Combat Zone
DOC.TEXT: U.S. military authorities are examining possible charges against two female soldiers who refused to drive other soldiers into downtown Panama City at the peak of the U.S. invasion, according to Defense Department sources. The sources, who spoke on condition of not being identified, told The Associated Press the women ``feared for their lives'' in the mission, which involved ferrying troops into the sniper-filled city after sunrise on the first day of the invasion. ``Tears were involved,'' said one source. The source cautioned that although charges may be considered for such a thing as disobeying a direct order, that does not mean that any would be brought. ``Charges are just being considered,'' the source said. Army policy bars women from being sent into combat, but some 600 women were among the troops who invaded Panama on Dec. 20 to oust dictator Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. These women were members of units assigned ``support'' functions, not front-line combat roles, even though some of their assignments resulted in females coming under fire. Capt. Linda Bray has gotten wide publicity for leading a military police company engaged in a firefight before capturing a Panamanian Defense Forces barracks and dog kennel. A Defense Department spokesman, Lt. Cmdr. Ken Satterfield, declined to comment on the report that the women broke down in tears and refused to drive into a combat area. He said he was unable to speculate on any possible charges being brought against the two women. ``U.S. Army officials are looking into the incident and will determine what action, if any, is appropriate in the best interests of the Army and the individuals concerned,'' Satterfield said. Asked about the details of the incident, the spokesman said the two female soldiers ``were unable to make a trip to drive combat soldiers'' in the early morning hours of Dec. 20. The two women were drivers assigned to the 193rd Support Battalion, he said. ``The drivers' state of mind at the time was such that they felt they would endanger the lives of the combat soldiers they were to transport if they were to undertake the trip,'' Satterfield said. ``Because of the urgency of the mission, they were replaced by soldiers assigned to the 193rd Infantry Brigade (Light), who carried out the driving assignment,'' he added. The two women were returned to their unit and ``performed other driver duties,'' the spokesman said. The women belonged to a battalion that was supposed to provide support to all Army units normally assigned to Panama, as well as the reinforcements brought in for the operation, Satterfield said.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Die as Jet Crashes in Rain; Cause Sought
With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: A twin-engine corporate jet crashed while attempting to land in a downpour, killing all seven people aboard, authorities said. One official said the pilot apparently gave no indication of trouble. The 21-seat Gulfstream jet was arriving at the Little Rock municipal airport late Friday afternoon when it hit a light tower short of the runway, lost a wing and a wheel, spun to the ground and disintegrated in a fireball, witnesses said. The jet carried employees of an Eastman Kodak Co. subsidiary. ``The weather was atrocious,'' said Jim Keet of Little Rock, a pilot who arrived on a commercial flight just before the jet's crash. ``The problem was visibility. The air was stable, but you couldn't see the ground until just as you landed.'' Airport manager James Rodgers said he did not believe the pilot gave any indication of trouble. ``In normal airport operation, we make pilots aware of local weather and a decision to shoot an approach is up to him,'' Rodgers said. Airport officials do not make recommendations about an approach and, so far as he knew, there had been no thought about closing the airport because of the weather, Rodgers said. ``The airplane broke apart on impact,'' said Coroner Steve Nawojczyk. The victim's bodies were scattered for 200 yards, he said. Charley Rogers, who was driving on a highway which passes the airport, said he saw the plane ``hit some guy wires or something _ I saw sparks. It looked sort of red and blue. When the plane hit the ground, it just exploded. All I saw was the explosion. There were sparks up in the air, so it did hit something in the air.'' The plane had departed Longview, Texas, earlier in the day en route to Batesville, Ark., said Bill Edwards, a spokesman for Tennessee Eastman in Kingsport, Tenn. Eastman's Chemical Division headquarters is in Kingsport. The firm has an Arkansas Eastman plant at Batesville. The plane was unable to land there because of weather conditions and was diverted to Little Rock. Gary McDonald, manager of community relations for Arkansas Eastman, identified the dead as: M.L. ``Bud'' Gernert, retired Arkansas Eastman president, and his wife, Marian, and company employees William Schirmer, Randy Wood, Nathan Casteel, and company pilots Don Mason and Ed O'Neal. Arkansas Eastman, which manufactures chemicals and bulk aspirin for Bayer, is a division of Eastman Kodak's Eastman Chemicals Division. Jack Goodwyn, director of public and government affairs for Texas Eastman in Longview, said the plane flew from Kingsport to Longview and that three people are believed to have gotten off at that point. Texas Eastman Plant Manager Paul Folzenlogan and his wife got off the plane at Longview. ``I feel very lucky and blessed,'' Folzenlogan said.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Justice, Labor Secretary, U.N. Envoy Dies at 81
DOC.TEXT: Arthur J. Goldberg, whose lifetime of public service was capped by his pivotal seat on the Supreme Court, will be buried in Arlington National Cemetery. Goldberg was found dead Friday by his maid when she entered his apartment. He was 81. His physician, Dr. Michael Newman, said Goldberg died overnight of cardiac arrest from coronary artery disease. Henry Fleisher, a longtime friend who said he had lunch with Goldberg on Wednesday, said the former justice was found lying on a sofa, where he apparently had been reading a newspaper. Goldberg lived alone since his wife, the former Dorothy Kurgans, died in February 1988 at age 79. She was an artist and author. The couple had two children, Barbara and Robert. Ralph DeStefano, director of Gawler's Funeral Home, said Goldberg will be buried in Arlington National Cemetery. Appointed to the Supreme Court on Aug. 29, 1962, by President Kennedy after 19 months as secretary of labor, Goldberg left the bench three years later at the urging of President Johnson. Johnson then named Goldberg U.N. ambassador on July 20, 1965, after the death of Adlai E. Stevenson at a time when U.S. involvement in Vietnam was escalating dramatically. Goldberg wrote Johnson: ``I shall not, Mr. President, conceal the pain with which I leave the court. ... It has been the richest and most satisfying period of my career.'' On the court, Goldberg was allied with Chief Justice Earl Warren and other liberals who asserted the court's authority against other government institutions and expanded its role as a protector of individual rights. His appointment to the court provided the critical fifth liberal vote needed for many of those decisions. Justice William J. Brennan, a fellow liberal who served with Goldberg, said Friday that the former justice ``was very human, a man of dignity and courtly bearing, punctilious, courteous, cultivated, a superb host.''
