In perhaps his most controversial Supreme Court opinion, Goldberg spoke for the court in a 5-4 ruling that threw out a confession by a murder suspect who was denied a lawyer during police questioning even though the suspect repeatedly asked to see his lawyer. Goldberg wrote: ``If the exercise of constitutional rights will thwart the effectiveness of a system of law enforcement, then there is something very wrong with that system.'' Goldberg repeatedly defended the right of the poor to legal safeguards and due process. In contrast to his Supreme Court years, Goldberg's tenure at the United Nations was frustrating. He resigned in April 1968, separated from the center of power in the administration and with United States mired in the war in Southeast Asia. Goldberg, after returning to the practice of law in New York, was defeated by Republican Nelson A. Rockefeller in the 1970 race for governor of New York. In 1971, Goldberg returned to Washington to practice law and teach at American University. He remained active in public life. He was appointed by President Carter as U.S. ambassador to a 35-nation conference in Belgrade on human rights and headed a private commission that studied the role of U.S. Jewish groups during the Holocaust. Goldberg was born in Chicago on Aug. 8, 1908, the last of 11 children of Russian immigrant parents. His father, Joseph Goldberg, ran a business carting fruits and vegetables from the city's markets to hotels. After graduating from Northwestern University Law School in 1929 at the top of his class, Goldberg became a specialist in labor law. When his appointment to the high court was announced, Goldberg's wife confided to reporters what was generally believed: the job was the one her husband always wanted.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: James Carpenter got a tax refund check a little early this year _ or 40 years late, depending on your perspective. Carpenter was rummaging through his late mother's papers and found a check from the Internal Revenue Service worth $122.40 that he had asked her to hold for safekeeping. It was dated April 21, 1950. ``I dang near fell over, I was so surprised,'' he said. ``My mom was one who would stick things away like birthday cards. I probably gave it to her for her to hang onto for me. She sure did.'' Each year the IRS receives calls from people who find old checks, said Elcy Maccani, a spokeswoman for its Detroit office. ``I've had people call before with old checks, but this is one of the oldest I've heard of,'' she said. Carpenter, 61, a custodian at Bay Medical Center, can take the check to an IRS office and receive a voucher for the $122.40. After the IRS verifies that the check had not been reported lost and then replaced, it would reissue him a new one, Maccani said. The IRS began a new policy in October that makes all government checks void after one year. The policy also states that old government checks must be cashed by Sept. 30, 1990.

Neither rain nor snow nor dark of night is supposed to stop the mailman from his appointed rounds _ but a free-roaming pit-bull shepherd and Great Dane are another matter. Mail service to a northeast Spokane neighborhood was suspended Jan. 10 when mailman George Finster said he was tired of being charged by Virginia Provost's menacing dogs. For the past week and a half, two dozen neighbors on Provost's block have had to collect their mail from the post office. ``This is probably the worst case we've had,'' said Gail Mackie, executive director of SpokAnimal, the city's animal control agency. ``We're dealing with an owner who couldn't give a rip. They cut off her mail and she got a post office box.'' Starting Friday, an animal-control officer is accompanying Finster on his route. Assistant City Attorney Stan Schwartz said he is researching an ordinance that would prohibit dog ownership for people who are convicted too often of allowing their animals to run free.

DOC.HEAD: Agency Upgrades Probe of Escort, Lynx Restraint Systems
DOC.TEXT: The government says it is stepping up a probe of possible torso belt failures in the Ford Escort and Mercury Lynx that consumers have blamed for five deaths and 76 injuries. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said Friday that it was upgrading its investigation from a paperwork-based preliminary evaluation to an engineering analysis in which engineers will study the possibly defective parts. ``We've received numerous reports which allege malfunction or failure of the passive restraint system,'' said agency spokesman Tim Hurd. The investigation involves the 1987, 1988 and 1989 Escort and the 1987 Lynx, Ford Motor Co. spokeswoman Linda Becker said. An estimated 1,029,312 are on the road. The Lynx was discontinued after 1987. The agency and the automaker have received 316 complaints between them that blame the belts for five deaths and 76 injuries resulting from accidents, Hurd said. Ford is cooperating with the investigation and company engineers are inspecting the Escort and Lynx models in question, Ms. Becker said. ``We have found no evidence that any systematic defect is involved,'' she said. ``It appears the passive belt systems have performed as designed.'' The cars have manual lap belts in addition to the automatic torso belts being investigated, she said.
DOC.HEAD: Bush Says He Won't Sign Clean Air Bill If It Too Costly
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is calling on Congress to approve clean air legislation but says he will veto any bill that costs substantially more than the proposal he sent to Capitol Hill last summer. ``I will only sign legislation that balances environmental and economic progress,'' the president said Friday in a letter to Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., the Senate minority leader. Bush, noting that the Senate is planning next week to begin floor action on a tough air pollution control bill, said the proposal is twice as expensive as the administration proposal and the one under consideration in the House. The cost to industry of toughening the nation's air pollution controls is expected to be a major subject of debate as the legislation moves forward in Congress in the coming months. Senate Democrats have said in recent days that their bill is not substantially higher in cost from the Bush proposal. But the president in his letter to Dole said administration estimates put its price tag at more than $40 billion a year, compared to $19 billion for the administration proposal. At the same time, maintained the president, the Senate bill ``provides little incremental environmental benefit'' over House and administration versions. Environmentalists have maintained the Senate bill is much stronger and should be enacted.
DOC.HEAD: Baker Asks Greater Freedom in Distributing Money
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III, grappling with eliminating foreign aid this year to more than a dozen friendly nations, is seeking congressional support to disregard some legal restrictions on how aid money is distributed. Baker met with Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., on Friday to see whether lawmakers might permit some flexibility in the so-called ``earmarks'' Congress imposed on fiscal 1990 foreign aid money. Dole said Baker complained that the administration has a list of some 30 countries to which it wants to give a total of $1.6 billion, but has only $950 million in unearmarked money to hand out, leaving a $650 million shortfall. State Department officials have come up with a series of scenarios under which some of the earmarked money _ roughly $150 million to $250 million _ could be pared from its mandated recipients and given instead to more needy countries such as Bolivia, Jamaica, Argentina, Peru and countries in the Eastern Caribbean. ``Some of these countries, small countries, important countries, are going to be zeroed out,'' Dole told reporters. ``He asked us if there's any chance leaders in the House and Senate might go along with it.'' State Department officials have been agonizing over the allocations for this year's foreign aid for weeks. The allocations were supposed to have been decided last month, but remain up in the air because of the shortfall.

DOC.HEAD: `Laissez les Bon Temps Rouler?' Not at the TV Programmers' Convention!
DOC.TEXT: Only the television industry could bring a dull convention to the city of Mardi Gras and Bourbon Street. The glitter business, known for choking our tubes with glitz, gore and cheap canned thrills, decided to be sober, industrious and subdued this year. In previous years, the free booze flowed like water and each of the exhibitors from the National Association of Television Programming Executives put on a lavish buffet. ``It got to be kind of a contest among the big guys to see who could outdo the other,'' said one nostalgic executive. ``We'd compare notes and say, `You've got to do Warner Bros., they've got the crab claws. Paramount has the sushi.''' This year, there wasn't even a carrot stick in sight. And the joint was lousy with Perrier and Diet Coke. ``There was food to be had,'' said one disgruntled programmer, ``but you had to sneak into the back room and gobble it like a kid. Embarrassing.'' So much for the New Sobriety. In the good old days, there was a glitz glut. Big-name show biz acts entertained the customers. Hulk Hogan would body slam at the drop of a contract. This year, the World Wrestling Federation's regulation-size ring was usually empty, a mute reproach echoed by large, thick-necked, mournful-looking men in business suits. The non-diaphanous robe of the duty angel at the ``Highway to Heaven'' almost reached to her knees. There wasn't even a dog and pony show. The 1990 rules of conduct grew out of a movement among West Coast members, reportedly pressured by Disney chief Michael Eisenberg and other studio heavyweights, to tone down the excesses. ``The only way they could get it voted through was that if one did it, we all did it,'' said another executive, who like the others didn't want to speak ill of his cohorts for the record. ``Next year, we'll vote on it again.'' ``You see this banana,'' said a program buyer. ``It's the only thing I've had to eat between the hours of 7:30 a.m. and 7 p.m. in three days.'' It sure was fun, though, to watch the law of supply and demand in action, in a year when exhibitors had roughly one-third more programming to sell than there were time slots to air it. ``Are we doing more business?'' asked one executive. ``When you're giving it away a dime on the dollar, you might be doing more deals.'' More than 200 exhibitors shelled out upwards of $6 a square foot to fill the huge New Orleans Convention Center with plush, carpeted enclosures, TV monitors, neon signs, viewing rooms with comfy chairs and soft drink bars. More than 8,000 registered participants _ program directors and station managers from your local TV stations _ percolated up and down the aisles to take in the sights. They got to meet Vanna White of ``Wheel of Fortune'' and Alex Trebeck of ``Jeopardy,'' the top-rated shows in syndication. They shook hands with the eponymous Geraldo, Oprah and Sally Jesse Raphael. Not to mention Joan Rivers, George Jetson, a Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle and Donald Trump. There was the World War II-vintage torpedo plane above the ITC booth where ``Tic Tac Dough'' is making a comeback. There was Paramount's bank of TVs over a ``Star Trek''-style command desk, Buena Vista's cavernous den behind the eerie silhouette of the Disney castle, and Warner Bros.' big logo in blue neon. And, there was the remarkably tanned, fit and blond Toni Adams, who identified herself as a TV personality for the U.S. Wrestling Association. She said she runs a summer camp and a wrestling school in Texas and manages her husband, wrestler Gentleman Chris Adams, ``So you can see I'm more than just a pretty face.''

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Longest Shuttle Mission After Landing Delayed by Fog
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with landing delayed by computer problem; picks up 7th graf, ``The spaceship...''
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto covering
DOC.TEXT: Mission Control ordered a 95-minute delay Saturday in the landing of the space shuttle Columbia because of a problem in the spaceship's computer system that was quickly resolved. The ``wave-off'' call came just 25 minutes before Commander Dan Brandenstein was to fire braking rockets to start the spaceship on an hourlong dive through the atmosphere to end the longest shuttle flight at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. Touchdown, which had been set for 3:01 a.m. EST, was delayed until 4:36 a.m., after Columbia made one more swing around the globe. Mission Control reported a switching problem in a backup computer, but the astronauts were able to quickly resolve the trouble. In normal configuation Columbia has four primary computers working and one backup. The control center directed the astronauts to restructure the system to shift one of the operating units to the backup position. ``Good job,'' Mike Baker, the spacecraft communicator in the control center reported after the task was done. ``I don't want you guys to get the impression we don't want to come home or anything now,'' commander Dan Brandenstein quipped, referring to an earlier one-day postponement of the landing. ``We were beginning to wonder,'' Baker replied. Mission Control said the computer problem was believed to be a transient signal. To be safe, technicians took the computer off line. Columbia is able to operate with just two of its five computers working. The spaceship and its five astronauts had planned to return home Friday morning, but the landing was ``waved off'' first by one orbit and then by a day because of a threat of fog that proved to be real at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. The weather was favorable Saturday morning in the Mojave Desert. Columbia carries enough fuel and other supplies to stay in orbit until at least Monday, NASA officials said. The astronauts had a light day Friday, working on a couple of experiments and snapping some more photographs of Earth before going to bed around noon. They were awakened Friday evening to the strains of ``Anchors Aweigh'' for shuttle commander Dan Brandenstein and pilot Jim Wetherbee, both Navy men, and the fight song for the University of Wisconsin at River Falls, Brandenstein's alma mater. ``Good morning Columbia. We'd like to know what it feels like to be record setters,'' Mission Control said. ``We're at a loss for words,'' Brandenstein said. It was the second time they were awakened. Their sleep was interrupted in the afternoon when an alarm sounded, indicating there was briefly too much nitrogen gas in the nitrogen-oxygen atmosphere inside the shuttle. The alert didn't pose a threat to the mission, and the crew went back to bed after checking a computer system that showed there were no further problems, NASA said. Dense patches of fog were in the area at the planned landing time Friday and even lingered on through the morning, Mission Control reported. Flight rules dictate visibility of seven miles for landing. ``So it looks like it was a good call to wave off today,'' the control center said. ``Tomorrow, Edwards is looking real good. Should be just fine for landing ... we shouldn't have a fog problem tomorrow.'' ``OK, Thanks. And it looks like a great call, not a good call,'' Brandenstein replied. Columbia is bringing home a scientific laboratory, called the Long Duration Exposure Facility, that the astronauts snatched from a weakening orbit using the shuttle's 50-foot robot arm. LDEF had been in space for nearly six years, but it was being slowed by atmospheric drag. The satellite was gradually sinking closer to Earth and would have been destroyed in a fiery plunge through the atmosphere in early March if the astronauts hadn't saved it. There were 57 experiments attached to LDEF's exterior, and scientists were anxious to see how the various materials in them fared during the long stay in space. They can use that knowledge to design long-duration spaceships and the planned manned space station. ``You've made the retrieval and return of LDEF look easy,'' Pete Petersen, director of NASA's Langley Research Center, said in a message sent to the crew Friday. The center at Hampton, Va., built LDEF and manages the project. ``The LDEF scientists look forward to a wealth of data that will have a major impact on future missions,'' Petersen said. Friday's delay not only made the flight the longest shuttle mission yet, but it also set some records for the crew members. At the planned landing time, Brandenstein will have logged 573 hours in orbit _ the most ever for a shuttle astronaut. In addition, mission specialist Bonnie Dunbar has spent more time in space than any other female astronaut, completing 427 hours at landing. Even the other three crew members, who are all first-timers in space, set a record. Pilot Jim Wetherbee and mission specialists Marsha Ivins and David Low have spent more time in space, 258 hours each, than anyone else in their 1984 astronaut class. The astronauts also released a Navy communications satellite and worked on several medical and science experiments during the mission, which is the 33rd shuttle flight and is a steppingstone toward months-long trips aboard the space station starting in the mid-1990s.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Considered Suicide During Manhunt, Says Former Spokesman
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega contemplated suicide during the time he was being stalked by U.S. troops last month, a longtime member of the former Panamanian general's inner circle told The Washington Post. Mario Rognoni, a former cabinet member, said Noriega considered taking his own life because he didn't want to go down in history as the war trophy of some unknown American GI, according to a report published in today's editions. ``He was very conscious of history,'' said Rognoni. Rognoni, who served as a Noriega spokesman, gave an account of Noriega's days in hiding before he decided to seek asylum at the Vatican embassy in Panama City on Dec. 24. Rognoni said some of his account was based on ``secondhand'' information from persons who were with Noriega during the five days the general was in hiding, but The Post reported that a number of details conformed with accounts garnered from other sources. Rognoni said he maintained telephone contact with Noriega through an intermediary during that period. The general felt he had three options, said Rognoni: to try to wage guerrilla war against the Americans, to seek asylum or to commit suicide. On Dec. 23, as it became increasingly difficult to evade searching U.S. troops, Noriega decided to take his life, said Rognoni. But the former spokesman said he believes the general was talked out of suicide and opted to seek diplomatic asylum the next day. Rognoni was arrested by U.S. forces on Christmas and spent four days in detention. Noriega surrendered to U.S. troops on Jan. 3 and was flown to Miami to face drug charges.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Attorney's Background Check Reveals Domestic Violence
DOC.TEXT: Acting U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen denied the reports of domestic violence contained in a 19-month FBI background check, but they were confirmed by his first wife and a former companion. The investigation submitted to the White House two weeks ago also revealed that Lehtinen had problems with former employers. Lehtinen's temper had been mentioned as a possible liability in the prosecution of ousted Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega, and he removed himself from the case last week amid reports the Justice Department didn't want him to try the case, The Miami Herald reported Friday. Lehtinen was appointed as acting U.S. attorney in June 1988 by then-Attorney General Edwin Meese. Justice sent the probe to President Bush, who must submit Lehtinen's name to Congress for confirmation. According to witnesses interviewed and documents obtained by the FBI during its investigation, Lehtinen's smashed furniture and once shoved his former wife out of the house when their marriage was ending between 1982 and 1983. Lehtinen denied the allegations to the newspaper. ``This article and many others will make a lot of allegations,'' said his spokeswoman, Diane Cossin. ``Embroidery and speculation are not worthy of comment.'' Lehtinen's first wife, Donna Stevenson, said Friday that ``Dexter has a temper. I do know he throws things and he yells,'' she said. Ms. Stevenson denied Lehtinen ever hit her, however. During a two-year romantic relationship with his former legislative aide, Dolores Zell, Lehtinen threw things at her, shook her and once sprained her arm when he pushed her to the floor, according to the FBI report. The FBI ``asked about some incidents where specific things happened, like whether I had ever seen anything thrown, or have anything thrown at me or whether I had seen any furniture broken,'' Zell said. She said she told the FBI ``that I had seen these things done, and happen.'' The FBI investigation is made up of raw data obtained from a variety of sources and no judgement is made on the credibility of the reports. The Herald also reported that Lehtinen neglected to list one of his former employers on his official resume, and that he would not confirm whether the omission was made on the employment history he gave to the Justice Department. Lehtinen was taken off the payroll of Shutts and Bowen, a prominent Miami law firm, in 1982 because he rarely showed up for work even though he continued to draw paychecks, the Herald said. On Thursday, he confirmed that he worked for the firm and that the firm's managers were unhappy with the amount of work he did. He said he told the FBI ``everything I know of,'' but added that he ``didn't type those forms.'' Lehtinen said he did not know why his confirmation has been delayed. Justice Department officials have told him a Judiciary Committee rules change caused the delay, he said. Lehtinen graduated first in his class from Stanford Law School in 1974, became a prosecutor with the Los Angeles U.S. Attorney's office and then with the Justice Department Organized Crime Strike Force in Miami. In 1978, he left government service to pursue a political career and worked in private law firms and as an independent attorney in Miami.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Fighting To Preserve Veto of Chinese Student Aid Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Delete extraneous word `Friday' in 2nd graf.
DOC.TEXT: The administration, facing new action by Congress, is stepping up its defense of President Bush's veto of legislation to let some 40,000 Chinese students remain in the United States after their visas expire. The White House said Friday that administrative actions taken by the executive branch of government gave the students relief that was as good _ or better than _ the steps outlined in the vetoed legislation. But congressional Democrats remained dissatisfied, and Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, told reporters an attempt will be made to override Bush's Nov. 30 veto when lawmakers return next week. Mitchell also accused Bush of pursuing a wrongheaded policy toward the Beijing government in the aftermath of the communist regime's crushing of the student rebellion in Tiananmen Square last June. He said two secret missions Bush approved to maintain contact with Chinese leaders represented ``an embarrassing kowtowing to a repressive government.'' Those moves sent ``exactly the wrong signal'' to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, he said. ``If there's one thing we can deduce from the events in the world today, we can deduce that the days of the current Chinese leadership are numbered,'' Mitchell said. ``We are aligning ourselves with old men whose days are numbered. I think it's adverse to our interests.'' Mitchell said he expects to await a test vote in the House before initiating action in the Senate to reverse Bush's veto of the Chinese student relief bill. The White House released a letter from Attorney General Dick Thornburgh saying that in carrying out the president's order, ``the action I have taken affords relief equivalent to, or greater than, the relief that would have been provided'' under the vetoed bill. In vetoing the bill, Bush said it was an infringement on his authority and could jeopardize exchange programs and U.S.-China relations. In his letter, Thornburgh said he complied with Bush's order, which relied on existing law, to provide Chinese students in the United States with irrevocable waivers of foreign residency requirements, which they may exercise until Jan 1, 1994. Among other steps, he said Chinese nationals had received necessary authorization for employment in the United States. Moreover, Thornburgh said, the Immigration and Naturalization Service had established an ``outreach'' program to assist Chinese nationals. ``Initial results of the program indicate that these outreach efforts have been successful and that (Chinese) nationals are aware of the available options and are filing applications,'' Thornburgh said. In most cases, visas for visiting foreign students are issued for two years. The bill Bush vetoed would extend the students' visas for more four years and then give them a chance to apply for permanent residency.

DOC.HEAD: AM-Space Shuttle, 1st Ld-Writethru,
Columbia Astronauts Photograph Earth, Tend to Experiments
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs to explain where signals came from; SUBS 9th graf to show saline solution taken orally; SUBS 15-16 grafs to explain Wetherbee's running on treadmill
DOC.TEXT: Space shuttle Columbia's astronauts photographed North Africa for a film documenting damage to the planet Monday as they whirled around the world on their seventh day in space. Clear skies gave the astronauts the chance to shoot pictures of Lake Chad, the Nile Valley and fires in Kenya for a giant-screen IMAX film called ``Planet Earth'' on the damage man and nature are doing to Earth. The five crew members also worked on several medical and scientific experiments that have been the focus of their 10-day flight since the two main objectives _ releasing a satellite and capturing another _ were completed last week. Columbia is scheduled to land Friday at 2:59 a.m. PST. The astronauts' work day began a little early when their sleep was interrupted Sunday by a buzzing alarm that signaled a brief problem with a navigation system. But the five unexplained signals from a sensor on the system that tripped an alarm posed no threat to the mission, and the astronauts returned to bed. When they woke up as scheduled two hours after the alarm sounded, Mission Control told them scientists had monitored the suspect unit, but detected no further problems. Columbia commander Dan Brandenstein then successfully tested the system and put in back into operation. ``Everything is going well,'' flight director Al Pennington said Monday morning. ``They've had a very good day. In fact, they're having a very busy day today.'' During the day, mission specialist Bonnie Dunbar had difficulty with one experiment in which she must seal the lower half of her body inside a container resembling a collapsible vacuum bag. In the experiment, an astronaut drinks a saline solution and spends time in the container, which has gently pulls the body's fluids toward lower body parts. In space, fluids tend to move toward the upper body. Researchers hope the two techniques will prevent astronauts from having trouble standing when they return to Earth. Dunbar had trouble with the device's waist seal, which apparently doesn't work quite the same in weightlessness as it does on Earth, and needed some assistance from mission specialists Marsha Ivins and David Low. Mission Control awoke the astronauts with the University of Washington fight song. Dunbar is a Washington graduate. ``Good morning for your second wakeup of the morning,'' the control center said, referring to the earlier alarm. Ground controllers also apologized to the crew for having to work on a holiday. ``Sorry you have to work through the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday, but you're doing so well that no one wants to give you a break,'' Mission Control said in morning messages sent to the crew via the shuttle's fax machine. Columbia pilot Jim Wetherbee received a special message: a certificate from Sunday's Houston Tenneco Marathon. Wetherbee ran on a treadmill at about the same time his mother, Althea, participated in the 26.2-mile marathon. Mrs. Wetherbee had asked him to be her pace partner in space. Wetherbee's certificate said he ``ran'' the marathon in 5.4 seconds, meaning that was how quickly he traveled 26.2 miles in space. His 70-year-old mother, the oldest female to participate, finished in four hours, 59 minutes and seven seconds. ``You were awarded an honorary completion certificate for the marathon. Many of us were surprised you weren't disqualified for leaving the course,'' Mission Control's message said.

DOC.HEAD: Winter Storm Leaves Destruction in Texas
DOC.TEXT: Storms with high winds that spawned at least three tornadoes moved out of Texas today, leaving in their wake a trail of battered homes and more than a foot of snow that snarled traffic in the Panhandle. At least two people were injured in one of the twisters, authorities said. Both were listed in stable condition at a hospital in Lufkin, southeast Texas. One tornado flipped over a mobile home and knocked out power lines Friday in nearby Hudson. Heavy snow in northwest Texas that began Thursday night caused at least one traffic death. Benjamin Thorpe, 60, of Big Spring died when his tractor-trailer rig slipped off a bridge near Lubbock. Snow drifts of 3 to 4 feet were common in the Panhandle, and the state highway department ``strongly discouraged'' travel in the area Friday, closing two state highways. One was later reopened as skies cleared. In three Dallas suburbs, high winds tore a roof off a restaurant and damaged buildings and houses. ``Our roof's over in our neighbor's yard here,'' a cashier at a Webb's barbecue restaurant in Duncanville told Dallas radio station KRLD. ``I just saw things flying.'' The cashier was not identified. A Garland police officer reported sighting a funnel cloud, but much of the damage was blamed on storm winds. Damage in Grand Prairie occurred along a path stretching several miles, authorities said. An undetermined number of houses were damaged by the twister that struck Hudson. About 200 area homes went without power for several hours, authorities said. ``It's quieted down. But a lot of power lines are still down,'' said Lupe Laird, a dispatcher for the Angelina County Sheriff's Department, late Friday. The twister downed electrical lines at a subdivision housing 1,800 people near Hudson, and it may be two days before power is restored, she said. The National Weather Service posted flash flood watches and river flood warnings as the system moved eastward.

DOC.HEAD: China Limits Activity by Foreign Journalists
DOC.TEXT: China published new regulations today banning foreign journalists from actions the government deems harmful to society and from filing reports it views as false. The broadly worded regulations give the government wide latitude for controlling foreign journalists following the Jan. 11 lifting of martial law in Beijing. The martial regulations had placed tight restrictions on reporters. ``Foreign journalists and resident foreign news organizations should observe professional news ethics and not distort the facts, create rumors or use improper methods to interview or report,'' said the regulations, which were signed by Premier Li Peng on Friday and took effect immediately. ``Foreign journalists ... cannot carry out activities that are incompatible with their status or that endanger Chinese national security, unity or society's common interests,'' the rules said. The Information Department may give warnings or revoke the accreditation of journalists who violate the regulations, one clause said. China criticized as distorted most foreign reporting on the pro-democracy protests last spring and the June 3-4 army attack that crushed them, killing hundreds and possibly thousands of people. The government maintains the protests were a foreign-instigated plot to overthrow the Communist system. During the protests, Chinese consulates abroad stopped issuing work visas for visiting journalists, and dozens entered with tourist visas. In June, the government expelled two American reporters based in Beijing, an Associated Press reporter and one from the U.S. government-funded Voice of America radio. The new regulations do not explain what are considered improper methods of gathering information. Under martial law, all interviews had to be approved by military authorities. The regulations make no mention of informal or on-the-street interviews, which were permitted before martial law was imposed May 20. Even since martial law was lifted, however, few Chinese have dared to give on-the-street interviews. Even officials often regard interviews as political risks. It was not clear if the new regulations supercede a 1986 set of rules that required foreign journalists to get approval 10 days in advance before leaving Beijing to report elsewhere in China. That rule has been used mainly to keep journalists from visiting Tibet, where Buddhist monks and nuns have repeatedly demonstrated for independence.

DOC.HEAD: Two Quakes Shake Tehran, Injure Two
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with two injuries. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Two earthquakes shook the Iranian city of Tehran and nearby areas early today, injuring two people and damaging homes, Iran's official media said. The quakes at 4:57 a.m. and 5:45 a.m. registered 5.2 and 4.9 on the Richter scale, according to the the official Islamic Republic News Agency. They were centered 85 miles east of Tehran, the capital. The agency said the injuries occurred in Firuzkuh, 70 miles east of Tehran. The homes were damaged in the capital, it said. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A quake of magnitude 5 can cause considerable damage.

DOC.HEAD: Houston Gets First Female Police Chief
DOC.TEXT: Deputy Chief Elizabeth Watson promised to continue the community work of her black predecessor as she becomes the leader of the nation's largest police department ever directed by a woman. Mrs. Watson, 40, succeeds Lee Brown, who takes over as New York City's police commissioner Monday. Brown was Houston's first black police chief when he was tabbed in 1982 by Mayor Kathy Whitmire, who on Friday named Mrs. Watson. Mrs. Watson, a 17-year veteran of the force, said she favored efforts by Brown to get officers more involved at the community level, especially with minorities, an approach the mayor had said was a criterion in her search for a new police chief. Mrs. Watson had commanded several divisions, worked five years as a detective and was assigned to an anti-riot and terrorism squad at one time. ``I am not Lee Brown in pretty obvious ways,'' Mrs. Watson said, laughing. ``But I do share his commitment and his vision to see policing in America become a partnership with the community.'' Mrs. Watson will lead a force of some 4,500 officers whose morale is thought to be low. Houston's slow economy in recent years has prevented officers from receiving pay raises. The department also has been held up for criticism in the wake of two recent fatal shootings of citizens. In one, a woman was shot to death in October after a freeway altercation with three off-duty officers. In November, a security guard was shot after being pulled over for a traffic violation. Brown, in one of his last acts as chief this week, fired the four officers involved in those incidents. The mayor's nomination must be approved by the city council, where initial reaction was positive. ``I think this lady has done a great job,'' Councilman Frank Mancuso said. ``She didn't get to be a deputy chief by accident.'' She also received backing from Mark Clark, president of the Houston Police Officers Association. Gerald Arenberg, executive director of the Washington-based National Association of Chiefs of Police, said of her selection was remarkable, considering 92 percent of police officers are men. ``It's always been a man's world,'' he said. ``To have a woman rise so rapidly and then be named head of one of the largest police forces, that's an extraordinary circumstance,'' he said. The only large city to have female chief previously was Portland, Ore., which had a woman heading the force for 1{ years a few years ago, Arenberg said. A native of Philadelphia, Mrs. Watson moved in 1963 to Houston and attended public schools. She was an honors graduate of Texas Tech University in Lubbock. Mrs. Watson and her husband, Robert, a police sergeant, have two children.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Agent, Bank Robbery Suspect Killed in Shootout
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Fixes typo in lead, recasts
DOC.TEXT: An FBI agent and a man suspected in a bank robbery died and two agents were wounded in a shootout after the agents burst into the man's home, authorities said. The SWAT team knocked on the door at the house of James Price, 45, Friday evening, to serve a warrant. When he didn't answer, they broke down the door with a battering ram, FBI spokesman David Binney said. As they entered the house Price opened fire with a shotgun, Binney said. The FBI agent pronounced dead at a hospital two hours after the shooting was the first slain in the line of duty in St. Louis, authorities said. The injured agents were treated and released for gunshot wounds to the arm and leg, respectively, Binney said. Their names weren't provided. No one else was in the house when the shooting occurred. Authorities were looking for the weapons and money taken in a Jan. 3 robbery, Binney said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Victims of Pakistan Hijacking Can Sue for Punitive Damages
DOC.TEXT: Families of victims of the 1986 hijacking of a Pan American World Airways plane in Pakistan can sue the airline for punitive damages, a federal judge ruled. The decision by U.S. District Judge John E. Sprizzo was at odds with an earlier federal ruling and is the latest interpretation of the Warsaw Convention on international air travel. On Jan. 3, a federal judge in Brooklyn, Thomas Platt, ruled that the treaty barred punitive damages for families of passengers killed in the December 1988 bombing of Pan American Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland. Platt said the Warsaw Convention restricted international aviation lawsuits to compensatory damages and limited those damages to $75,000, unless ``willful misconduct'' was proven. Sprizzo, however, disagreed. In his decision Thursday, he said no language in the treaty ``expressly preempts or precludes'' punitive claims. Sprizzo's ruling stemmed from more than 50 lawsuits filed by the families of victims of the hijacking of a Pan Am flight from Bombay, India, to New York on Sept. 5, 1986. At a scheduled stop in Karachi, Pakistan, four gunmen seized the plane. Twenty passengers were killed and dozens more were injured. A call to Pan Am for comment was not returned. Lee A. Kriendler, an attorney representing plaintiffs in both the Lockerbie and Pakistan lawsuits, said he has asked Platt for a rehearing on his ruling in the Lockerbie case. He also sent Platt a copy of Sprizzo's ruling. In a previous ruling, a federal judge in Washington allowed plaintiffs in the 1983 Korean Airlines disaster to seek punitive damages from the airline. That case involved the Soviet shooting down of a KAL plane carrying 269 people. A jury awarded $50 million to about 130 families. The award is now under appeal.

DOC.HEAD: Acquitted McMartin Defendant Sues for $1 Million
LaserPhotos LA1
DOC.TEXT: Peggy McMartin Buckey, acquitted in a preschool molestation trial that lasted nearly three years, plans a return to court for a $1 million lawsuit that alleges malicious prosecution. ``I feel I have a right to have a home again,'' Mrs. Buckey said Friday. ``My husband and I worked hard for what we had. And to take everything away from someone who's done nothing _ it's a nightmare.'' Buckey said the family has been living off her husband's earnings as an aircraft company electrical technician, her and her mother's Social Security, their daughter's teaching salary, and help from their church. At a packed news conference, Buckey and members of her family told of death threats issued in the aftermath of the verdict, and said they are considering moving out of Southern California. ``My husband was threatened in court yesterday,'' Buckey told reporters. ``They told him, `You're gonna be killed.''' The 63-year-old Mrs. Buckey, and her son, Raymond, 31, won acquittal of 52 felony charges on Thursday because jurors said bizarre allegations of molestation at the McMartin Pre-School appeared to be the result of coaching by parents and therapists. A mistrial was declared on 13 other counts, all involving Raymond Buckey. The district attorney's office will have to decide whether to try those counts again. The nation's longest criminal trial cost over $15 million. The suit filed Friday names as defendants Los Angeles County, the city of Manhattan Beach, former District Attorney Robert Philibosian, Children's Institute International and therapist Kee MacFarlane, as well as Capital Cities-ABC Inc. and its former reporter Wayne Satz. ``I have no idea what her intent might be,'' Philibosian said. ``Similar lawsuits have been filed in the past and they are all routinely dismissed by the courts. It's not unusual for defendants to do this,'' he said. Ms. MacFarlane said the lawsuit was the fifth filed against her by various former McMartin defendants, ``and every court that has been asked to consider them, including the California Supreme Court, has thrown them out,'' she said. ``My opinion, both as a lawyer and a reporter, is that this is an entirely frivolous and groundless kind of lawsuit,'' said Satz, who often broke stories in the case in early 1984. ``We stand by our coverage, but we have not yet seen the legal papers,'' was the response of a Capital Cities-ABC spokeswoman in New York. Assistant Los Angeles County Counsel Robert Ambrose refused immediate comment on the suit, and Manhattan Beach City Attorney Carl Newton was not in his office. The lawsuit contended that all defendants joined in a conspiracy to have the McMartin defendants indicted. They were accused of defamation, malicious prosecution, conspiracy and violation of Mrs. Buckey's civil rights. The suit sought general damages of $1 million and unspecified punitive damages. Mrs. Buckey, who is the only plaintiff in the federal suit, appeared at the news conference with her mother, Virginia McMartin and her daughter, Peggy Ann Buckey, who both were charged in the original child molestation case but had their cases dismissed.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Space Shuttle Lands at Edwards Air Base
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with shuttle landing; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Space shuttle Columbia streaked out of orbit to a delayed landing in the Mojave Desert Saturday at the end of a record 11-day shuttle mission that retrieved a valuable science satellite. Commander Dan Brandenstein guided the winged space plane out of the darkness to a touchdown at 1:36 a.m. PST on a brightly lighted concrete runway after a journey of 4.5 million miles. Columbia was not visible to viewers here until it was making its final approach just above the runway.

DOC.HEAD: Salvadoran Soldiers Charged in Priests' Murders
DOC.TEXT: In a case closely watched by the U.S. Congress and human rights activists, the director of El Salvador's Military College and eight other soldiers were charged with murdering six Jesuit priests. Judge Ricardo Zamora of the 4th Penal Court on Friday ordered Col. Guillermo Benavides, three lieutenants and four enlisted men to stand trial. The murder charges imply ``premeditation and perfidy'' and carry a maximum sentence of 30 years, court secretary Nicolas Hernandez said. A fifth enlisted was charged, but he deserted in December and is a fugitive. The new rector of the Jose Simeon Canas Central American University, where the priests taught and were slain, called the investigation ``insufficient.'' ``We believe the investigation as to who was behind this is lacking a series of elements,'' said the Rev. Francisco Estrada. ``It seems to us strange that a sole colonel would have decided to commit a crime of this magnitude.'' All six priests were educators at the university, one of the region's leading institutions. The priests, their housekeeper and her teenage daughter were dragged out of their beds on the night of Nov. 16 and fatally shot by uniformed men. Benavides, chief of the Military College and a former head of military intelligence, is the highest Salvadoran officer ever charged with a human rights-related crime. No officer has been convicted of such a crime, even though rightist death squads killed thousands of suspected leftists in the early 1980s. All the defendants except Benavides and Lt. Rene Mendoza, who was also at the Military College, are members of the elite U.S.-trained Atlacatl infantry battalion. The unit had been assigned to Benavides to provide security for the rear section of the college. The campus is on the south side of the Military College. ``I don't want any witnesses,'' two accused lieutenants _ Gonzalo Guevara and Jose Espinoza _ quoted Benavides as telling them shortly before midnight Nov. 15, when he allegedly ordered the killings. ``OK, gentlemen. We're playing for keeps. It's either them or us, because they have been the intellectuals directing the guerrillas for a long time,'' Guevara's testimony quoted Benavides as saying. The massacre took place during a major offensive by leftist guerrillas in the country's decade-old civil war. Rightists often accuse clergymen of helping the leftists, and the killings of the Jesuits raised fears of a return to the days of wholesale slaughter by death squads. The killings also prompted calls in Washington for a re-evaluation of the $1.5 million in military and economic aid the United States provides El Salvador daily. Zamora issued his ruling at the end of a 72-hour deadline that began Tuesday when the prisoners, who have been under arrest since early January, were put at the disposition of the court. The court order opens a 120-day period during which the case is prepared for trial, but this phase can be delayed by motions. In the pre-trial depositions made public Friday, several of the soldiers described how five of the priests, including then rector Ignacio Ellacuria and vice-rector Ignacio Martin-Baro, were roused from bed, taken to the yard behind their home, and forced to lie face down in the grass. Two of the men charged, Sgt. Antonio Avalos and Pvt. Oscar Amaya, admitted they fatally shot them. Avalos said he understood Espinoza gave the order to fire, and that if he disobeyed he ``would be accused of treason.'' Espinoza, Guevara and Mendoza denied they were involved in the killing but admitted they took part in the operation. Benavides' deposition was not made available, but court sources said he denies the murder charge. Cpl. Angel Perez admitted fatally shooting the Rev. Joaquin Lopez y Lopez, the sixth Jesuit, inside the house. Sgt. Tomas Zarate admitted shooting the housekeeper, Elba Ramos, and her 15-year-old daughter, Celina. Avalos testified that as he was going out of the building, he ``heard people groaning from within a dark room, and thought they must be people who had been shot but not dead.'' He said he and fugitive defendant Pvt. Jorge Sierra went to the door. Avalos says he ``lighted a match and saw two women on the floor, hugging each other and whimpering,'' so he ordered Sierra to finish them off, and Sierra fired a burst of about 10 rounds from his M-16 automatic rifle ``until they stopped whimpering.'' Several defendants described how the murder squad staged a mock battle, including firing rifles and exploding rockets, grenades and flares after the slayings.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Congressman, Wife Sentenced To 3 Years in Prison
DOC.TEXT: A judge sentenced former U.S. Rep. Robert Garcia to three years in prison but said he would be eligible for parole after six months since his crimes were less serious than others convicted in the Wedtech scandal. U.S. District Judge Leonard Sand said he felt the sentence was the most lenient he could give Garcia, convicted with his wife of extorting payoffs from Wedtech Corp., the now-defunct defense contractor. His wife, Jane Lee Garcia, received the same sentence and parole order as Garcia. Garcia, a 58-year-old Democrat, resigned his congressional seat earlier this month. He had represented the economically-blighted South Bronx, where Wedtech was located, for 12 years. Former New York Knicks basketball star Earl ``The Pearl'' Monroe has agreed to run for the seat in a March special election, according to a report in the Daily News today. Monroe, a Republican, runs a music production company. Sand conceded that Garcia's crimes were less than others convicted in the Wedtech scandal, but said he felt Garcia had to spend some time in prison as a deterrent and as an example. ``You yielded to the temptation of betraying your office so you and your wife might enjoy a higher lifestyle,'' the judge said. Sand imposed no fines on the Garcias after their attorneys said they were completely destitute and recently had lost even their apartment. Garcia asked for leniency for himself and mercy for his wife. He apologized to his former constituents, but said he would pursue and appeal. ``For years, I worked long and hard for the people I've represented,'' Garcia said. ``I never tried deliberately to harm them.'' Mrs. Garcia, 49, told the judge that the hardest part of the ordeal for her and her husband has been consoling those close to them. ``The past three years have been more difficult than anything you can imagine,'' she said. The Garcias were the last major defendants tried in the wide-ranging corruption scandal at Wedtech. Evidence at the trials showed that Wedtech, once a small machine shop, grew into a multimillion-dollar defense contractor through various bribe schemes. The company collapsed in 1986 amid allegations of corruption. A jury, in a verdict returned Oct. 20, found that the Garcias extorted $76,000 from the Wedtech Corp. from 1984 to 1986 in return for help in obtaining government contracts. Wedtech channeled them a $20,000 interest-free loan through Garcia's sister. In 1988, former U.S. Rep. Mario Biaggi was convicted of racketeering charges and was sentenced to eight years in prison. Others convicted in the scandal were former Bronx Borough President Stanley Simon, who received an eight-year term, and E. Robert Wallach, a close friend of ex-U.S. Attorney General Edwin Meese, who was sentenced to six years.

DOC.HEAD: Reporter Who Covered Russian Revolution Dead At 96
DOC.TEXT: Frank H. King, whose news career of more than 50 years included a 7,000-mile odyssey across Siberia while covering the Russian Revolution for The Associated Press, has died at age 96. King died in his sleep shortly before dawn Friday in Oakland. For decades, King was regarded by associates as the best that a reporter could be, a man who once risked his life to rescue women and children trapped in a Vladivostok railway station. For this he won a U.S. Army commendation. King's field of action spanned much of the world during his long career. He was the first American reporter to describe, in eyewitness accounts, what life was like in revolutionary Russia. King's exclusive series won wide play in America and Europe. Later, after a brief assignment with Washington AP bureau, King joined the London bureau, where he was named bureau chief during his 17-year tour. He then went to Dallas as bureau chief, retiring in Dec. 31, 1958 as Southwest AP general executive after a 38-year AP career. ``Frank King lived journalism, and I know of no one who came closer to being the essence of what it's all about,'' said Felix McKnight, former chief executive of the Dallas Times Herald and a newsman in the Dallas AP bureau when King arrived. McKnight said that King ``loved his Texas assignment and became, I guess, the most respected and best-loved newspaper man in this part of the country during his stay as bureau chief.'' Born Dec. 31, 1893, at Excelsior Springs, Mo., King was a graduate of the University of Missouri School of Journalism. He became an AP stringer in Columbia, Mo., reporting to the St. Louis bureau on everything from sports to politics. He joined the St. Louis Post-Dispatch, but his $17.50 weekly pay was not enough to hold him when he got a chance to join the English-language Japan Advertiser in Tokyo in 1917. With Russia in revolution, the United States, Britain, France and Japan sent expeditionary forces to Vladivostok in 1918. The AP and the Japan Advertiser together hired King to cover the action. At one point, he quit taking notes long enough to dodge bullets and help to rescue women and children besieged in the Vladivostok railway station during an attack by revolutionaries. U.S. Army Maj. Samuel I. Johnson, the assistant commander of the local Allied garrison, wrote to the AP in New York: ``I consider it my urgent duty to inform you of the excellent conduct of Mr. Frank H. King, correspondent for The Associated Press. His splendid conduct and coolness convinced me that he is a true type of American correspondent.'' Finally, Admiral Alexander Kolchak, the White Russian leader, was seized and executed by the Bolsheviks and resistance collapsed. In the spring of 1920, the Allies pulled out. King was on his own. King decided to return to Tokyo by an indirect route. He went down the coast to China and Peking, then headed west. He put a small kit together and traveled across Mongolia, Siberia and Russia. He traveled anyway he could. He walked and rode in a pony cart, a river steamer and on the Trans-Siberian Railway. He went through the Great Wall and across the Gobi desert, filing stories from such exotic places as Irkutsk and Urga. He didn't know if the copy was received. Moscow authorities finally ordered King interned in an old Czarist mansion while they debated what to do with him. King was rescued by John Reed, the American radical, author of ``Ten Days That Shook the World,'' who was the darling of the Leninists. The authorities decided the best solution was to shove King across the border into Finland. From there, he made his way through Scandinavia to London. He leaves his wife of 65 years, Olga, and one son, Frank H.H. King, a college professor in New Mexico. Funeral arrangements were pending.

DOC.HEAD: Barco: Colombia Will Continue Fighting Traffickers
DOC.TEXT: President Virgilio Barco told his countrymen that despite an apparent concession of defeat by drug traffickers, the government will continue to fight them to ensure its ``final success.'' In Washington, the Bush administration, which backs Colombia in its fight against the drug lords, said its position also remained unchanged. In a communique Friday, Barco said, ``The country has not allowed itself to be carried away by hasty expectations. It should maintain that attitude.'' He said it was necessary ``to take the best road to ensure the final success of the policy followed by the government, supported by the Colombian people and the international community.'' Officials have mounted a major effort to stamp out the traffickers since August, when cocaine lords were blamed for the killing of a leading presidential candidate. Earlier this week, traffickers from the Medellin cartel released three hostages and issued a message admitting defeat and asking for amnesty. In its message Wednesday, the group used the name ``Extraditables,'' referring to the government's policy of extraditing drug suspects wanted in the United States. Several Colombian officials have said it was merely a ploy to lure Barco into ending extraditions. Since August, Colombia has extradited 13 drug suspects to the United States. Other officials expressed concern that Medellin cartel leaders are trying to persuade the government to include them in an amnesty recently offered to leftist guerrillas for past political crimes. Barco's communique appeared to rule out both an end to extradition and an extension of the amnesty to drug traffickers. ``The national government and authorities, at all levels, will continue completing their duty of enforcing the law and bringing criminals to justice using constitutional and legal procedures and the alternatives offered by the current judicial order,'' it said. Barco reiterated the government's demand that drug traffickers keep their promises to end assassinations and other terrorist violence, to free all hostages, and to abandon their billion-dollar cocaine business. The traffickers responded to the government's crackdown with bombings and assassinations that killed 209 people and injured 1,243. ``Our position is still the same,'' White House secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Friday in Washington. ``We have traditionally been opposed to deals with the cartel ... Essentially it's a matter for Colombia to deal with.'' The cartel currently holds at least 18 hostages, including Alvaro Diego Montoya, the son of Barco's general secretary and closest adviser, German Montoya.

DOC.HEAD: Science Class Experiment Blows Up; Students, Teacher Injured
DOC.TEXT: A high school science experiment blew up and sent glass flying around a classroom, injuring four students and the teacher. The blast Friday afternoon at St. Francis Catholic High School occurred when the freshmen mixed water in a beaker with sodium, an explosive combination, said Los Angeles County Fire Department Inspector Chris Button. ``A glass beaker shattered. It sent glass flying around the desk at the front of the class,'' said Tom Moran, the academic vice principal at the Catholic boys school. Teacher Mike Mudie and three of the students were treated and released from Verdugo Hills Hospital with facial irritation and cuts. A 15-year-old who suffered a badly cut eyelid was being treated by an opthalmolgist, said spokeswoman Jackie Forsythe at Verdugo Hills Hospital in Glandale.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Roger, Columbia, welcome home. An outstanding job ... Great way to start the decade.'' _ Mike Baker of Mission Control congratulating the Columbia crew on the safe completion of the longest-ever space shuttle mission.

``The street is covered with blood.'' _ Vadim Korsh, an editor of Azerbaijan's official news agency, describing the scene of one of the biggest ethnic clashes in the Azerbaijani capital of Baku in the southern USSR.

``So let Daniel Ortega and Fidel take note, like the dinosaur, the day of the dictator is over.'' _ President Bush, addressing a Republican dinner in Miami, saying the demise of former Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega should be a lesson for the Cuba's Fidel Castro and Nicaragua's Daniel Ortega.

DOC.HEAD: Court Overturns Murder Convictions in Job-Related Death
DOC.TEXT: An appeals court overturned the convictions of three former executives believed the first ever to be found guilty of murder for the work-related death of an employee. The Illinois appellate court ruled Friday that the three top officials of the now-defunct Elk Grove Village-based Film Recovery Systems Inc. had been wrongly convicted of murder and other charges in the 1983 cyanide poisoning death of Stefan Golab. Cook County State's Attorney Cecil Partee said he would appeal the ruling to the Illinois Supreme Court. ``We are taking this case to the Supreme Court because we believe workplace safety to be an extremely important issue,'' Partee said. ``The evidence showed that the defendants went out of their way to hide the dangers from their employees and knowingly failed to protect them from obvious harm.'' Golab, 61, a Polish immigrant, worked at the plant where cyanide was used to recover silver from used X-ray film. He collapsed at work after complaining of dizziness and nausea. Prosecutors likened the plant to a ``huge gas chamber.'' The defunct company's former president, Steven J. O'Neil, plant manager Charles Kirschbaum and foreman Daniel Rodriguez were convicted of murder, involuntary manslaughter and reckless conduct in a bench trial before Circuit Judge Ronald J.P. Banks. They were sentenced to 25 years in prison but were free pending an appellate ruling. Their appeal argued the convictions were inconsistent because a murder conviction requires a different mental state than does a conviction for involuntary manslaughter or reckless conduct, said Elliot Samuels, who represented Kirschbaum and Rodriguez in the appeal. Murder requires deliberate intent while a verdict of reckless conduct requires a state of mind ``somewhere between negligence and indifference,'' Samuels said. The appellate court agreed, saying the convictions were ``legally inconsistent.'' Partee said he believes the appellate court ``made the wrong ruling.'' ``The appellate court found that the evidence at the trial was indeed sufficient to sustain the convictions beyond a reasonable doubt,'' Partee said in a statement. ``This issue is much too important to surrender on the basis of a hypertechnical reading of the law.'' Mayor Richard M. Daley, who prosecuted the case while he was state's attorney, supported an appeal. ``The earlier decision was precedent-setting nationally in terms of the protection that it gave to working men and women,'' said Daley's spokeswoman, Avis LaVelle. Witnesses testified at the Circuit Court trial that Film Recovery workers were not told they were working with cyanide or that compounds used at the plant could be harmful. Prosecutors also said the plant was manned largely by illegal Polish and Hispanic immigrants, most of whom spoke or read very little English. The defense said the three officials were responsible managers, had no idea conditions were dangerous and worked at the plant themselves.

DOC.HEAD: Snow, Sleet, Rain From Plains to New England
DOC.TEXT: Cloudy skies spewed snow, sleet and rain from the central Midwest to southern New England today, while a snowstorm lingered in Colorado. High winds that spawned at least three tornadoes moved out of Texas today, leaving battered homes and more than a foot of snow. Nine inches of rain soaked the area west of Gilmer, Texas, since Wednesday. Snowdrifts of 3 to 4 feet were common in the Texas Panhandle. The National Weather Service posted flash flood watches and river flood warnings as the storm system moved eastward. The Southeast looked to continue its mild weather through the weekend. Florida was due for isolated thundershowers. Total Colorado snow accumulations, which reached 14 inches by late Friday, were expected to be in the 10- to 20-inch range before the storm left the state for Kansas today. Several cities in Kansas reported about a foot of snow with unofficial reports of up to 20 inches in some parts of the state, the Weather Service said. Winter storm warnings and warnings of heavy snow were posted for central Kansas, southwestern Nebraska, northeastern Colorado and for much of Iowa. Winter storm watches were in effect for northwestern Illinois, southern Lower Michigan and parts of New York state, including the Susquehanna and Catskill areas and lower Hudson Valley. Winter storm watches for today and tonight were called in southern Wisconsin and in Pennsylvania's middle and upper Susquehanna Valley and the Pocono Mountains. Clear, calm conditions were expected in the West. Record high temperatures set for Jan. 19 included 86 in Ft. Myers, Fla., and 79 in Macon, Ga. In Florida, Tampa's 85 degrees tied a 53-year-old record high reading for January. Friday's high temperature for the nation was 89 at McAllen, Texas. DOC.HEAD: Investigators Find No Evidence of Pre-Crash Explosion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to fix category code.
DOC.TEXT: Federal investigators said there was no evidence that an explosion caused the crash of a private jet that left two dead. Earlier reports said the wreckage was widely scattered, indicating an explosion in the air. But Phillip Powell of the National Transportation Safety Board said Friday most of the pieces of the aircraft were found right at the crash site. ``We don't have any evidence to support a bomb being on board the airplane at this time,'' Powell said. ``From what we can see, this was an aircraft accident.'' The jet, owned by Aero Flight Services Inc., of Ypsilanti, Mich., was flying from Ypsilanti to Louisville, Ky., on Thursday when it crashed in a wooded area in northern Ohio. Killed in the crash were Richard D. Hovarter, 53, of Mount Clemens, Mich., and Octavio ``Julio'' Mendez Jr., 42, of Ypsilanti, Mich.

DOC.HEAD: Azerbaijani City's TV Declares Independence From Soviet Union
With PM-Soviet-Unrest
DOC.TEXT: Iranian media reported today that the TV station in a Moslem city in Soviet Azerbaijan had broadcast a declaration of independence from the Soviet Union. The report came as Soviet troops moved into the Azerbaijani capital of Baku, killing at least 60 people in a crackdown on ethnic unrest, Soviet news reports said. The Islamic Republic News Agency quoted the TV announcement as saying Soviet troops should leave Nakhichevan, on the Iranian border 1,200 miles south of Moscow. Nakhichevan is part of Azerbaijan but separated from the rest of the republic by a strip of Armenian territory. The enclave's capital city also is called Nakhichevan. IRNA, monitored in Cyprus, said its correspondents on the Iranian side reported seeing a power blackout during the night on the Soviet side. The television in Nakhichevan broadcast its resolution three times following martial music, IRNA said. The resolution called for independence from Moscow, a pullout of Soviet troops and an end to alleged Soviet aggressions in Nakhichevan. It also called on Turkey, Iran, the United Nations and world governments to help safeguard Nakhichevan's territorial integrity and prevent a massacre, the agency said. The television said its resolution was taken because of the ``terror'' caused by alleged attacks by Armenians. Violence first broke out in the 2,200-square-mile enclave in November 1988, when Armenian media said gangs of Azerbaijanis ransacked Armenian homes in Nakhichevan. It broke out again a week ago with the current unrest all over Azerbaijan. Meanwhile, official Tehran radio said thousands of Azerbaijanis streamed into Iran this morning across a border bridge in Astara, a resort town on the Black Sea. The radio, also monitored in Cyprus, said most Soviet Azerbaijanis who travel to Iran return to the Soviet Union the same day, after visiting relatives or purchasing goods. IRNA said thousands of Soviet Azerbaijanis crossed the border Friday and staged a demonstration in support of spiritual leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, chanting ``God is Great'' and ``Khamenei is the leader.'' They also participated in the traditional Moslem Friday prayer service, the agency said. Iranian television, monitored in Cyprus, broadcast scenes of Azerbaijanis waving identical copies of the Koran apparently donated by the Iranians, as well as pictures of the snow-covered border region with Soviet armored vehicles patrolling the border. Soviet news media have accused returning Azerbaijanis of smuggling in weapons provided by Iran. Khamenei said earlier in the week that the upheaval in Azerbaijan was caused by Islamic zeal.

DOC.HEAD: China Reports Prisoner Swap With Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: China and Vietnam exchanged a total of 22 prisoners of war at Friendship Pass on the two countries' heavily guarded border, the official Chinese news agency said. The exchange Friday indicated slightly warmer relations after more than a decade of hostility between the two countries. It came a day after the 40th anniversary of China's giving diplomatic recogniation to Vietnam's Communist guerrillas. The prisoner trade took place with an International Red Cross representative watching, the Xinhua News Agency said. China released 17 Vietnamese soldiers who ``illegally entered Chinese territory to carry out armed provocation and sabotage,'' it said. ``During interrogations, the Vietnamese captives pleaded guilty to invading Chinese territory and carrying out illegal activities,'' Xinhua said. It said China released them ``in the spirit of humanitarianism.'' It said Vietnam handed over five captured Chinese soldiers but did provide details. China's Communist Party aided Vietnamese Communists as early as the 1930s and recognized Ho Chi Minh's jungle insurgency as Vietnam's government on Jan. 18, 1950. China supplied the Vietnamese Communists with weapons in their battle against U.S. troops to reunify Vietnam. Relations soured, however, after Vietnam invaded neighboring Cambodia in 1978 and ousted the Chinese-supported Khmer Rouge. China attacked Vietnam in 1979, and border clashes have occurred since, although with decreasing frequency. Vietnam's official Radio Hanoi said Wednesday that Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen had sent a message commemorating the anniversary of relations and pledging to ``strive untiringly to restore the relations of friendship ... at an early date.'' Senior Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping said in October that China was willing to normalize relations with Vietnam if it would end its occupation of Cambodia. China disputes Vietnam's claim to have pulled its last troops out in September. The two countries also have clashed over several island chains in the South China Sea, the Spratlys and the Paracels.

DOC.HEAD: Shaken Residents Startled Awake by Shuttle's Sonic Booms
DOC.TEXT: Slumbering residents startled awake by two massive sonic booms triggered by the landing space shuttle Columbia telephoned authorities with jittery reports ranging from earthquakes to burglars. The shuttle landed at Edwards Air Force Base without a hitch at 1:35 a.m. PST today after passing over the coast near here, jolting people awake with a pair of sonic booms that rattled windows. ``We got quite a few calls,'' said Los Angeles County sheriff's Deputy Sheila Smith. ``Some thought it was an earthquake, others said someone was trying to break in or was on the roof. ``One guy said he thought a car crashed into the house next door,'' she said, adding that the Malibu station received about two dozen calls. All the sleepy callers were asked if what they heard might have been a sonic boom. After being told about the shuttle landing, they agreed it was the likely source, Ms. Smith said. The 11-day shuttle mission was the longest ever for a space shuttle and Columbia, carrying a rescued satellite in its cargo bay, returned to Earth heavier than any previous shuttle.

DOC.HEAD: Guru's Followers Dance, Sing
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Followers of the late Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, the free-love guru who was expelled by the United States, today danced, meditated and chanted the mystic's favorite mantra _ ``hoo, hoo, hoo'' _ a day after his death of a heart attack. Rajneesh also made a final ``appearance'' before 10,000 of his followers in a videotape and told them: ``Think deep. Go deeper.'' The 58-year-old mystic has not named a successor, and his death Friday launched a wave of speculation about the future of his commune, its 500 worldwide branches, and its claimed 500,000 members. The videotape was played at the mystic's southern commune in the city of Poona, where Rajneesh set up an international headquarters after his deportation from the United States in 1985. ``Osho is very much here,'' said follower Ma Yoga, using an honorific name that Rajneesh called himself in recent years. The term means ``on whom the heavens shower flowers.'' ``Bhagwan'' is a Hindu honorific meaning ``god.'' ``It is like any other day here. It does not matter if Osho has left his body,'' said Ma Yoga, a member of the 23-year-old cult's Poona commune, in a telephone interview. ``He lives, the commune lives.'' A statement from the commune quoted the guru as saying hours before his death, ``My work will go on and grow stronger after I leave my body.'' In a statement telexed from Poona, Rajneesh's personal doctor said the guru was in pain for many weeks before his death. ``I asked Osho if he wanted us to prepare for cardiac resuscitation, and he said, `No, if I die it will be relief from the pain,''' said British physician Swami Amrito. Rajneesh died of a heart attack, according to a doctor's death certificate. However, a commune statement released today said the guru died because ``living in the body had become a hell.'' It repeated Rajneesh's charges he was poisoned in U.S. jails before he was deported.``While he was in Oklahoma County jail (in Oklahoma state), he was poisoned with heavy metal thallium. They exposed him to radiation in a way that it will not leave any proof.'' Thallium is used in making rat poison. Local health officials said Rajneesh suffered from AIDS, but the commune denied those reports about two years ago. Rajneesh's most famous commune, the Rancho Rajneesh, was founded in Oregon in 1981. He brought his teachings of free sex and materialism to the scrubby hills near Antelope, Ore., drawing thousands of slavish disciples. They were rewarded with the guru's daily ``drive-by'' in one of his 93 Rolls-Royces _ many painted psychedelic colors, and some decorated with peacocks and lacy curtains. To many nearby residents, the commune known as Rajneeshpuram was a monstrous intrusion. It was disbanded in 1985 when Rajneesh, a native of India, was expelled from the United States in a plea bargain on immigration fraud charges.

DOC.HEAD: Lufthansa and Interflug Plan to Build New Berlin Airport
DOC.TEXT: The West German airline Lufthansa and the East German state carrier Interflug are planning to build an international airport to serve both East and West Berlin. The joint plan, announced by airline officials Friday, calls for the airport south of Berlin to be completed by the year 2005. It would be capable of handling 30 million passengers a year. The project was announced by Lufthansa chairman Heinz Ruhnau and Interflug chief Klaus Henkes at a joint news conference at East Berlin's Schoenefeld airport. Henkes also said he expected Interflug to double its number of passengers to 6 million this year as a result of East Germany's decision in November to open its Western borders. Blueprints for the new airport are expected to be completed by 1995, the two airline chairmen said. The airport will served by a subway. Currently, West Berlin's Tegel airport is served only by U.S., French and British airlines. Regulations of the Allied powers controlling West Berlin ban Lufthansa from flying there. The two airlines also agreed to launch a joint charter company.

DOC.HEAD: R.J. Reynolds Cancels Test Marketing of Cigarette Aimed at Blacks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT spelling of `tobacco.' SUBS 11-13th grafs, bgng `Company spokesman...', with 3 grafs to add quote on future of brand, fix style on minister's title. Picks up 14th graf, `We are...'.
DOC.TEXT: R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co.'s decision to cancel a planned test marketing of a cigarette aimed at blacks is a ``victory for health,'' the nation's top health official said. Reynolds' announcement on Friday came a day after Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan attacked the company for promoting a ``culture of cancer.'' The company said anti-smoking advocates misrepresented Reynolds' plans for a campaign that was to begin in Philadelphia in three weeks for a new menthol cigarette called Uptown. ``We regret that a small coalition of anti-smoking zealots apparently believes that black smokers are somehow different from others who choose to smoke and must not be allowed to exercise the same freedom of choice available to all other smokers,'' said Peter Hoult, Reynolds executive vice president of marketing. Sullivan said he was elated by the company's decision. ``This is a victory for the citizens of Philadelphia, for minority citizens and indeed for all Americans _ a victory for health,'' he said. In a speech in Philadelphia on Thursday, Sullivan, who is black, said Reynolds' message was ``more disease, more suffering and more death for a group already bearing more than its share of smoking-related illness and mortality.'' Officials with the Winston-Salem, N.C.-based company have said they hoped the cigarette would appeal to blacks, who as a group prefer menthol cigarettes, according to the company's market research. Philadelphia was chosen because blacks make up 40 percent of the population, the company said. ``Our intentions in test marketing Uptown in Philadelphia have been misconstrued and misrepresented by the anti-smoking lobby,'' Hoult said. ``Our sole purpose, plainly and simply, was to test market a cigarette among smokers who currently buy competitive products.'' Company spokesman David Fishel said the immediate future of Uptown is unclear, adding, ``We'll just have to evaluate the situation.'' In Philadelphia, leaders of about 30 organizations which had banded together to fight Uptown expressed joy that the company decided to heed their opposition. The Rev. Jesse Brown, president of the Committee to Prevent Cancer Among Blacks, called the decision ``magnificent.'' ``We are glad that R.J. Reynolds decided to hear us,'' he said. ``We don't want this cigarette to be marketed in any city. This sends a signal to R.J. Reynolds that community groups can rise up and deal with them.'' He said that Sullivan's public condemnation of the marketing plan was ``the icing on the cake'' to the local opposition. Charyn Sutton, a member of the Philadelphia chapter of the National Black Leadership Initiative on Cancer and a marketing consultant for the American Lung Association, said R.J. Reynolds had to face marketing facts. ``I'm personally pleased that the company heard the community. They had said this was a cigarette that the community wanted. But we felt there had been no such request that way,'' she said. The company's promotional blitz included ads suggesting glamour, high fashion and nightlife. Sullivan, in a letter to R.J. Reynolds, noted that cigarettes cause an estimated 390,000 deaths _ or more than 1 in every 6 _ annually in the United States, making it the country's leading cause of preventable death. Statistics from the U.S. Public Health Service show that black men have a 58 percent higher incidence of lung cancer than white men, and blacks lose twice as many years of life as do whites because of smoking-related diseases.

DOC.HEAD: Chronology of Events in Azerbaijan, Armenia
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of the unrest between Azerbaijanis and Armenians in the Soviet Caucasus:

Feb. 28, 1988 _ Demonstrations by Armenians demanding Azerbaijan cede control of the mostly Armenian Nagorno-Karabakh region causes rioting in Sumgait, Azerbaijan, that kills 26 Armenians and six Azerbaijanis. Soviet troops help quell the clashes, said to be the most serious outbreak of nationalist unrest in the Soviet Union since the 1920s. May 21 _ Communist Party leaders of both republics are dismissed after protests in Yerevan, the Armenian capital, and Baku, the Azerbaijani capital. July 4 _ Armenian nationalists close the main airport in Yerevan, and widespread strikes are reported in Armenia and Nagorno-Karabakh. July 18 _ The Soviet government rejects a decision by Nagorno-Karabakh to break away from Azerbaijan. Sept. 21 - Further turmoil prompts Moscow to declare a state of emergency in Nagorno-Karabakh.
