Soviet troops are deployed around government buildings in Armenia, where demonstrations and strikes continue. Nov. 24 _ The Soviet military takes control of Baku and Yerevan after several days of clashes that leave at least 28 people dead, including three soldiers, and 126 wounded. Officials say 100,000 refugees have fled the two republics because of the unrest. Dec. 7 _ A major earthquake hits Armenia, killing about 25,000 people. Jan. 12, 1989 _ The Soviet government puts Nagorno-Karabakh under the direct rule of Moscow. June _ Strikes and demonstrations continue. Aug. 29 _ Soviet troop reinforcements are sent to Nagorno-Karabakh after renewed fighting between Armenians and Azerbaijanis. Sep. 25 _ President Mikhail S. Gorbachev calls on leaders of both republics to negotiate an end to an Azerbaijani rail blockade that has halted supplies for earthquake reconstruction. Nov. 28 _ The Supreme Soviet restores Azerbaijan's control over Nagorno-Karabakh. Dec. 1 _ The Armenian Parliament condemns Moscow's restoration of Azerbaijani control over Nagorno-Karabakh and votes to unite with the territory. The nationalist Azerbaijani Popular Front reimposes the rail blockade against Armenia. Jan. 1, 1990 _ Soviet Azerbaijanis seeking freer travel to visit their ethnic brethren in neighboring Iran attack border posts, causing damage and at least one death, according to Soviet media reports. Jan. 14 _ A demonstration in Baku causes rampages by gangs of Azerbaijani nationalists on Armenians living in the city. At least 25 people are reported killed. Clashes break out in other areas. Jan. 15 _ The Soviet Union declares a state of emergency in parts of Azerbaijan and orders army, navy and KGB security forces to help contain the fighting. Jan. 16 _ The Soviet government sends 11,000 army and internal police troops to Azerbaijan. The government puts the death toll at 56 in three days of fighting. Jan. 17 _ Roadblocks in Azerbaijan prevent the Soviet troops from moving freely, hindering their deployment. Reports reaching Moscow indicate Armenians and Azerbaijanis have seized heavy weapons, with some reports calling the violence a virtual civil war. Jan. 19 _ Gorbachev blames the unrest on extremists trying to undermine his reform proposals and also says some nationalist Azerbaijanis want to sececde to form a Moslem state. A government statement warns of a national catastrophe if the unrest continues. In the face of widespread public protest, the government suspends the Defense Ministry's callup of reservists to beef up military units. Soviet reports say weapons have been brought in from Iran by the demonstrating Azerbaijani nationalists. Jan. 20 _ Soviet troops use tanks to break through barricades and enter Baku, exchanging gunfire with Azerbaijani nationalists. Initial reports indicate scores of additional deaths.

DOC.HEAD: Aldo Gucci, Son of Leather Goods Company Founder, Dies
DOC.TEXT: Aldo Gucci, who helped turn his father's Italian luxury leather goods company into an international symbol of chic but whose own son later implicated him for tax evasion, has died. He was 84. No information on when or where he died or the cause was supplied in a statement Friday from Gucci America in New York announcing his death. There was no answer at Gucci offices in Italy today. But the Italian news agency ANSA today reported from Florence, where the company was founded, that Gucci died at a Rome clinic where he had been hospitalized a week ago for treatment of prostate cancer. ANSA said the funeral would be held at a Roman Catholic church in Rome on Monday and that the body would be transferred to Florence for burial in the family mausoleum at a cemetery in that Tuscan city. On Friday, Peggy Rao, who has handled public relations for Gucci in Palm Beach, Fla., told the Palm Beach Post newspaper that she had been informed that he died of a cerebral hemmorhage. Gucci was responsible for marketing his family's products in the United States. In 1986, he pleaded guilty to evading $7 million in taxes and was later implicated in a corporate tax evasion scheme. The Gucci company was founded in 1906 in Florence by Guccio Gucci, a leather goods salesman. It was with some reluctance that he watched his son Aldo expand overseas _ a drive that resulted in 180 stores and about 82 percent of the parent company's sales today. Aldo Gucci opened the company's first American store in New York City in 1953. Aldo also brought his sons Giorgio, Paolo and Roberto and his nephew Maurizio into the executive ranks. Paolo later implicated him for tax evasion, and Maurizio had him ousted in 1984. In a statement issued Friday, Maurizio said of his uncle, ``Aldo Gucci was a man of great vision. His efforts were instrumental in establishing Gucci as the premier name in luxury leather goods in the United States.'' The tax evasion case began when Paolo proposed more inexpensive products and licensing and was opposed by his relatives. In one of two lawsuits Paolo filed against the others, he charged that the family blocked his efforts to trade under his own name and he produced documents showing that Aldo, then 81, had evaded taxes. The Internal Revenue Service obtained the documents, and Aldo pleaded guilty to evading $7 million in personal income taxes in federal court in Manhattan in 1986. He was sentenced to a year in prison but was allowed to serve part of the sentence at a halfway house in West Palm Beach. In 1984, Maurizio used his 50 percent of the company to seize control, oust Aldo, and bring in new, young, U.S.-educated managers. Aldo Gucci resigned as president of Gucci America in 1984 and was replaced by Domenico De Sole. In 1988, Gucci America admitted that the company, under Aldo, had conspired to cheat the government of corporate taxes between 1972 and 1982, and the firm paid the government $20.5 million in back taxes, interest and penalties. A lawyer for the company told a judge at the time that Gucci America had foreign corporations submit false invoices for services never rendered and other phony documents to divert money to Aldo Gucci, who kept some and distributed the rest among other members of the family. At the time of his death, Aldo Gucci was still acting as a consultant to the company.

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Detain Lebanese Journalist Critical of Aoun
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen today seized a Lebanese journalist who has been an outspoken critic of Christian leader Gen. Michel Aoun and his campaign to control the nation's media, but released him unharmed several hours later. In southern Lebanon, a United Nations official touring the Middle East today examined a prison where the Shiite Moslem Amal militia said a kidnapped U.S. Marine was briefly held before his reported hanging last year. And in England, Archbishop of Canterbury Robert Runcie marked the third anniversary of Terry Waite's abduction in Lebanon by saying that he longed to celebrate his personal envoy's release someday soon. Gunmen kidnapped Lebanese journalist George Hajj from his apartment in Christian east Beirut early this morning. He declined to talk to reporters after his release 8{ hours later, but a relative said he was in good condition. The maverick Aoun, who has been trying to muzzle the Lebanese news media for about a week, was accused of masterminding Hajj's abduction from the apartment in the Ashrafiyeh district. ``Colleague Hajj's abduction is the latest move in Aoun's war against freedom of the press,'' said Voice of the Nation, which interrupted regular programming to broadcast the report. Hajj, 55, a frequent critic of the Christian general, works for the weekly Al-Massirah and the daily Al-Bayrak. He also is a member of the executive board of the Reporters Syndicate. His abduction came as journalists, writers, poets, and politicians gathered near offices of the Newspaper Publishers' Syndicate in Moslem west Beirut to protest Aoun's drive to gag the media. Aoun has banned the media from referring to President Elias Hrawi as head of state and has closed newspapers that defied his orders. Hrawi, shortly after his election by Parliament Nov. 24, dismissed Aoun as prime minister of an interim military cabinet and discharged him from the post of commander-in-chief of the armed forces. Hrawi and Aoun are both Maronites, the Christian community which has dominated Lebanon since independence from France in 1943. Parliament elected Hrawi as part of an Arab League-brokered peace plan designed to end 14 years of civil war. Aoun has rejected the accord and declared the one-chamber house dissolved in an effort to prevent legislators from electing a pro-Syrian head of state. Also today, Aoun's soldiers and Syrian troops skirmished with machine guns, tank cannons and mortars in the Madfoun Bridge region, interrupting traffic along the highway which connects northern Lebanon with the Christian enclave. Police reported no casualties. In southern Lebanon, Assistant U.N. Secretary-General Marrack Goulding examined a prison where the Shiite Moslem Amal militia said U.S. Marine Lt. Col. William R. Higgins was briefly held before his reported hanging last year. ``There isn't sufficient evidence that Col. Higgins was held here,'' Goulding told reporters after his tour of the seven-cell prison in the village of Kawthariet Assiad, 10 miles southeast of the port city of Sidon. Higgins, who headed a U.N. observer team in southern Lebanon, was kidnapped near the southern port of Tyre on Feb. 17, 1988. The Organization of the Oppressed on Earth claimed it killed him in July after Israel kidnapped a Hezbollah sheik. U.S. intelligence officials believe Higgins, of Danville, Ky., was killed a year earlier in retaliation for the U.S. missile attack on an Iranian jetliner over the Persian Gulf in which 290 people were killed. In London, Archbishop Runcie marked the third anniversary of Waite's abduction. The Anglican envoy was taken hostage Jan. 20, 1987 while seeking to negotiate the release of hostages in Lebanon. ``I hope we shall not need to keep this anniversary again. We long to be able to celebrate Terry's day of release,'' Runcie said. Besides Waite, 17 foreigners are held hostage in Lebanon, including eight Americans. The longest held is Terry A. Anderson, 43, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Hard-liners Win Delay On Key Reform Document At Communist Congress
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with president's comments, insert that liberals fear document will be watered down in committee. Pickup 6th graf, `Stefan Korosec ...'
DOC.TEXT: Hard-line and liberal Communists today clashed at a key party congress over how quickly to renounce their 45-year-old monopoly on power, and hard-liners succeeded in delaying a vote on democratic reforms. Party President Milan Pancevski told the congress that the current system of one-party socialism had ``objectively exhausted its possibilities for development.'' Delegates at the four-day meeting considered a document that backs free elections and a multiparty system, and proclaims the party's readiness to relinquish its guaranteed grip on power. The opening of the congress, broadcast live on Belgrade TV, was marked by heated debate, with some delegates demanding that the document be adopted as soon as possible and other cautioning against a rushed decision. Several delegates from the liberal northern republic of Slovenia urged the document be adopted as it stands as one of the first agenda items. Hard-liners, mostly from the largest republic of Serbia, wanted it discussed in committee and adopted together with other documents at the end of the congress. The hard-liners succeeded in sending it to committee, leading to speculation that it could be watered down there. Although 780 delegates favored the document's immediate adoption, 645 voted opposed it, denying the motion for a vote the needed two-thirds majority. Stefan Korosec, who presided over the morning plenary session, said the document would be debated in committee sessions and adopted at the end of the congress. Retired Gen. Dusan Pekic proposed that the Communists urge Parliament to quickly delete the party's leading role from the constitution, but delegates voted this down, noting this demand was contained in the draft reform document. The declaration, published last week in the Yugoslav press, admits that the one-party system of monopoly ``has pushed us into autocracy and prevented us from keeping up with the economic, technological, political and social changes in Europe and the world.'' The party advocates freeing the political system ``of any monopoly, including that'' of the Communists, says the document, which was published and distributed to the press before the congress opened. Proclaiming that ``the end has come for authoritarian socialism,'' the document says the system of political monopoly ``has pushed us into autocracy and prevented us from keeping up with the economic, technological, political and social changes in Europe and the world.'' It calls for free, independent trade unions, a legal guarantee of ethnic and other human rights, independent courts, parliamentary control over the government and a market economy with mixed ownership. The draft document also advocates application for membership in the European Economic Community and other European trade groups. Today's congress, originally scheduled for May but moved ahead to keep up with the reforms sweeping Eastern Europe, immediately took up debate on the document and the pace of proposed changes. Deputy Premier Zivko Pregl told a news conference Friday the government also would propose constitutional amendments to Parliament deleting all references to the party's leading role and reforming the electoral process. ``(We) don't feel any political organization or party should be in the constitution,'' Pregl said. Pregl said draft legislation laying the groundwork for multiparty elections would be completed at a government meeting Jan. 25. He predicted it would be adopted by Parliament by March 1. The government of Premier Ane Markovic has begun putting into effect an ambitious, market-oriented economic program, but Pregl said accompanying political changes were also necessary. Yugoslavia broke with the Soviet Union in 1948 and established a largely decentralized Communist system. Pregl noted that Yugoslavia had been the most liberal of the Communist countries until reform surged through the East bloc in the fall, forcing the Communists in most countries to give up their hold on power. Communists in the liberal northern republics of Slovenia and Croatia have long tolerated non-Communist political groups and expressly called for multiparty elections, but hard-line Communists in the largest republic of Serbia had until recently opposed lifting Communist dominance. Last month, the Serbian Communists also said they backed multiparty democracy. The army has repeatedly rejected multiparty democracy. It says parties would be formed along ethnic lines, further aggravating tensions in this fractious country of varied ethnic and religious groups, many of whom still harbor historical rivalries. Petar Simic, head of the Communist leadership in the army, said in a speech published Friday in the daily Borba that the army would ``not retreat from the idea of Communism.'' The army in Yugoslavia has a political role unmatched elsewhere in Eastern Europe. Communist leaders in the military are represented on all local and federal bodies. Fully 95 percent of the army officers are Communist Party members. If multiparty elections are held in April, as promised by Communist leaders, the army would no longer be guaranteed a role in political decision-making. However, Simic said the army ``will accept the arguments and the will of the majority'' at the congress. Yugoslav media this week predicted possible clashes between party hard-liners and liberals, despite tentative agreement on democratic reforms.

DOC.HEAD: National Head Count Two Months Away
DOC.TEXT: After seven years of preparation the Census Bureau is closing in on its biggest job ever: a reasonably precise tally of the estimated quarter-billion people who live in America. The national head count, scheduled for April 1, is just over two months away. But the results will reverberate through American life for a decade or longer, through the distribution of seats in Congress and billions of dollars in federal money. In addition it will offer details on habits, incomes and living arrangements. This will be the 21st time the United States government has set out to make an exact count of its denizens. That goal has never been reached, but census officials expect to come closer than ever. ``We are prepared to chase and chase and chase again,'' said Census Director Barbara E. Bryant. The bureau estimates that it counted 98.4 percent of the population in 1980. This census has already generated controversy over counting illegal aliens and homeless Americans, adjusting the expected undercount to make sure the figures reflect the real number of poor and minority group members, and hiring the 300,000 temporary workers needed. The census is, in fact, the product of a political compromise at the heart of how this nation is governed. Since the states couldn't agree on their representation in Congress they decided to count the population every 10 years and use that result to adjust the House of Representatives. That was done for the first time in 1790, when federal marshals went out and counted heads. They found 3,929,214. That resulted in a complaint from President Washington, who said he was sure there were at least 4 million people in the country. Similar complaints have followed every count since then and have already surfaced this time, in the form of a lawsuit asking that the 1990 count be adjusted upward. ``Adjustment of census data is a demographic Pandora's box,'' says Agriculture Department population expert Calvin Beale, ``I hope it does not happen.'' Regardless of whether there are 4 million or 250 million people, counting everyone is a problem. Some people don't want to be counted. Some are away from home. Some are simply overlooked. Some fear government officials or lack interest in official activities. The distribution of billions of federal dollars is based on census counts, making the tally especially important for the poor, minorities and others who depend on government programs. Cities with large minority populations would like to see the final numbers adjusted to allow for the likelihood that blacks and Hispanics will be undercounted. Another hard-to-count group is the nation's growing army of homeless people. This has prompted a special effort, scheduled for the night of March 20, when census takers will visit homeless shelters, homes for battered women and flophouses, and will walk the streets and alleys looking for homeless people to be counted. Such an effort is reminiscent of the old-fashioned census methods, when enumerators went from home to home to make the count. In recent years that has given way to a mail count, with census forms being mailed March 23 to 80 percent of homes, with people asked to mail them back as of April 1. Officials are hoping for a strong mailback response, since people who don't fill in the form and send it back must be visited later by census takers. That visit costs money, though, and with the count expected to cost $2.6 billion overall, the government doesn't want to spend any more than necessary. One question that has come under nearly continual discussion since census preparations began in 1983 is the problem of illegal aliens, who are believed to shun government workers out of fear of being deported. Politicians from states with few illegal aliens have complained that these people should not be counted, because that would result in an unfair increase in the number of Congress seats given to states with plenty of undocumented aliens. The Constitution, however, specifies that all ``persons'' must be counted, not just citizens, so everyone is included. Census officials note that they don't ask if people are citizens, so they have no way of knowing whether a person is a legal or illegal resident of the country. Overall, 110 million households are expected to be counted, totaling about 250 million Americans. Most will get the short form, taking about 15 minutes to fill out. One home in six will get the long form which takes about 45 minutes.

DOC.HEAD: Ethnic Grievances Boiling Over From Caucasus to Baltics
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: From Central Asia to the Caucasus and the Baltics, ancient ethnic grievances and nationalist fervor are rising in the security cordon the Kremlin built. Grudges among neighbors that simmered quietly under the Soviet facade of brotherhood, and demands for independence, ultimately could erode Moscow's vast empire. The breeding grounds are southern deserts, the Caucasus Mountains, the fields and forests of Moldavia, the black, fertile soil of the Ukraine and the Baltics in the north. In those areas live many of the Soviet Union's more than 100 nationalities. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, facing bitter strife between Armenians and Azerbaijanis, told the country he was struggling with a legacy of ethnic hatred. ``The problems, which have been accumulating for tens _ no, for hundreds of years _ have erupted and acquired the character we are now confronted with,'' he told a meeting in Moscow on Thursday. In Lithuania less than a week earlier, where Gorbachev was trying to rein in a peaceful, but determined secessionist movement, the Soviet leader openly worried that demands for independence could lead to ``the union's disintegration on ethnic grounds.'' Gorbachev's policy of glasnost and democratic reforms has let genies out of bottles, in many cases with violent consequences. Formerly underground and long-repressed groups seek secession from the Soviet Union for Georgia, Armenia, Moldavia, Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia. Long before Gorbachev, the czars pushed south into Central Asia and the Caucasus and west into the Baltics and Moldavia in the 18th and 19th centuries. They brought under their control lands bordering other major empires that frequently threatened invasion. With arrests, deportations, pogroms, discrimination or murder, the Russian czars did little to make the local populations like their masters in Moscow. Alexander III introduced Russification _ to make all Russian in character _ angering non-Russian peoples. His son Nicholas II, the last czar, continued that approach. Soviet founder Vladimir I. Lenin called the Russian Empire that the Bolsheviks inherited a ``prison of nations.'' In 1917, the year of the Bolshevik Revolution, peasants angered by the postponement of agrarian reform struck out at Russian settlers. In the early years of Soviet power under Lenin, nationalist ferment was high in Byelorussia, the Ukraine, Central Asia, Transcaucasia and the Baltics, the same areas where troubles abound now. Many states, like the Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, took Lenin's policy of national self-determination to heart and declared their independence. But Stalin followed Lenin and took the areas back under Kremlin control in his effort to rebuild the security ring. Stalin seized the three Baltic republics in 1940. Stalin was a Georgian, but like the czars he tried to Russify the areas ruled by Moscow. Moldavia, for example, was regained from Romania in 1940 and the language was converted from Latin to Cyrillic letters in an attempt to make it seem more Russian. Armenians and Georgians _ two Christian ethnic groups in the Caucasus that in the 19th and early 20th centuries sought protection of the Russian czar against the Ottoman Empire _ now are among those fighting most vigorously for independence. After Gorbachev took power, Crimean Tatars and Armenians led the way for other nationalities in voicing their grievances. The Crimean Tatars demanded to resettle in the Crimean peninsula, from which they were deported by Stalin. The Armenians wanted to regain control over Nagorno-Karabakh, a small mountainous territory Stalin had transferred to Azerbaijan in 1923. The Nagorno-Karabakh dispute has turned out to be the bloodiest ethnic feud in recent years, and it is the focus of the latest and most dangerous flare-up. But that is just the tip of the iceberg. In Central Asia, where the Red Army reasserted Soviet power after 1917, Uzbeks attacked Meshkhetian Turks last June in the Fergana Valley of Uzbekistan, leaving more than 100 people dead. Abkhazians clashed with Georgians, who also fought with Ossetians. Some experts have estimated there are 40 areas of the Soviet Union where uprooted populations could make territorial claims. Soviet officials worried out loud about a chain reaction or domino effect in the campaigns to assert national rights. Calls for independence were heard in the Ukraine, the second-largest of the 15 republics, in September when activists there formed the Rukh political movement, modeled after the People's Front organizations that are pressing independence in the Baltics and elsewhere. A serious secessionist effort in the Ukraine would bring the problem much closer to Moscow than the unrest in the Caucasus or the Baltics. The Ukraine is the cradle of Russian civilization and a contemporary industrial and agricultural powerhouse with 50 million residents, Gorbachev's position on the Soviet republics seems to ethnic activists to be at odds with his encouragement of democratic reforms in Eastern Europe. While promising the 15 republics and autonomous national regions within them greater control over their economic, cultural and political affairs in a newly restructured federation, Gorbachev has consistently ruled out redrawing borders. He has also emphasized the historical and economic ties linking Baltic residents, Uzbeks, Armenians and Azerbaijanis to the Soviet Union. In a speech in Lithuania, he made clear the solutions must be found in his reform program. ``Only civil peace, the coordination of interests on the basis of reciprocity and the active pooling of efforts on the principles of perestroika to solve tasks and achieve the objectives of this policy can lead the country out of the present difficult situation,'' the Soviet leader said.

DOC.HEAD: Developments in Eastern Europe at a Glance
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief look at the latest developments in the East bloc.
DOC.HEAD: SOVIET UNION:
DOC.TEXT: Soviet troops stormed the Azerbaijani capital of Baku today, punched through barricades erected by militants and reportedly killed dozens of people in an attempt to end ethnic violence and territorial disputes in the region. Up to 60 people were reported killed. The government declared a state of emergency in Baku. The government on Friday suspended the Defense Ministry's callup of reservists to beef up military units in the face of widespread public protest.
DOC.HEAD: YUGOSLAVIA:
DOC.TEXT: Hard-line and liberal Communists today clashed at a key party congress over how quickly to renounce their 45-year-old monopoly on power, and hard-liners succeeded in delaying a vote on democratic reforms. Delegates are considering a document that backs free elections and a multiparty system, and proclaims the party's readiness to relinquish its guaranteed grip on power.
DOC.HEAD: CZECHOSLOVAKIA:
DOC.TEXT: At the Vatican, Pope John Paul II today accepted an invitation to visit Czechoslovakia, and his spokesman said the trip would take place sometime before the Czechoslovak elections in June. The Czechoslovak government said Thursday that it wants to re-establish diplomatic relations with the Vatican that have been suspended for 40 years. The change is possible now because a popular revolution recently ousted Czechoslovakia's hard-line Communist leaders, leading to broad democratic reforms, including religious freedom.
DOC.HEAD: EAST GERMANY:
DOC.TEXT: The West German airline Lufthansa and the East German state carrier Interflug are planning to build an international airport to serve both East and West Berlin. The airport south of Berlin would be completed by the year 2005 and could handle 30 million passengers a year. Officials say they expect Interflug to double its number of passengers to 6 million this year as a result of East Germany's decision in November to open its Western borders.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Eyes Defense Cuts as Deficit Reduction Effort Resumes
DOC.TEXT: Reduced east-west tensions are prompting Congress to weigh possible cuts in defense as lawmakers resume their search for ways to turn back a tide of red ink in the federal budget. Also high on the agenda as lawmakers return to Capitol Hill on Tuesday are ethics legislation, campaign finance reform, President Bush's push to cut the capital gains tax and foreign policy for a rapidly changing world. But crafting a military budget at a time when Americans perceive a lessening Soviet threat and increased need to reduce the deficit is expected to dominate the 1990 congressional session. ``My constituents ask, `Isn't the Berlin Wall now a speed bump?''' said Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., a member of the House Armed Services Committee. ``They really are thinking how do we get out of debt. They just aren't buying that we need everything.'' Already a handful of lawmakers, including liberal Reps. Barney Frank, D-Mass., and George Miller, D-Calif., are talking about how to spend the so-called ``peace dividend'' that remains. Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, says the Bush administration's defense plan for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1 will not produce such a dividend. But Sasser said Bush's proposal, which includes canceling the B-2 stealth bomber, the Advanced Tactical Fighter and the V-22 tilt-rotor transport, would result in $93 billion in savings from 1991-1994. On Jan. 29, President Bush most likely will submit a package totaling about $292 billion, which amounts to 2 percent less than what is necessary to keep this year's $287 billion level at pace with inflation. But with the Soviets loosening their grip on Eastern Europe, domestic programs clamoring for cash and a nagging budget deficit, calls are guaranteed to resound in Congress for substantial defense reductions. ``The budget that comes to us in 10 days will undoubtedly be cut,'' House Armed Services Chairman Les Aspin, D-Wis., said in a speech Thursday. He urged the Bush administration to delay production of costly, high-tech weapons such as the stealth Advanced Tactical Fighter and concentrate instead on research. Weapons systems that have taken large chunks out of the budget in the past, such as the Strategic Defense Initiative, the B-2 stealth bomber and land-based nuclear missiles, will be the focus for lawmakers willing to cut defense spending. ``The defense budget is being looked upon as the cash register, regrettably,'' Sen. John Warner, R-Va., said. With defense cuts likely, and the entire House and one-third of the Senate up for re-election, support is expected to grow for some way to soften the blow for districts dependant on military contracts. Legislation introduced in the past by Reps. Ted Weiss, D-N.Y., Nicholas Mavroules, D-Mass., and Sam Gejdenson, D-Conn., will be fodder for a compromise bill the Democratic leadership hopes to adopt. On other issues, Congress tackles the ethics problems of 11 members, including five senators who intervened with banking regulators on behalf of the owner of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan, Charles H. Keating Jr. Also facing congressional inquiries are three House members accused of improper sexual behavior. Clashes with the administration are expected over Bush's call for a reduction in the capital-gains tax and his rejection of a proposed cut in social security taxes. Democrats narrowly defeated the capital gains proposal in 1989, saying a cut would prove to be a windfall for the rich. But many concede prospects for passage this year are fairly good. A rollback in the Social Security tax proposed by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., is being condemned by Bush as a charade that would force a hike in other taxes or a cut in retirement benefits. But Moynihan's plan has put the administration on the spot, gaining wide support and fueling election-year claims that Bush is espousing a capital gains break for the rich while rejecting relief for poor and middle-class Americans. The foreign policy debate will center on aid for Eastern Europe and whether to reward the new democracies in the crumbling Warsaw Pact. A number of regional hotspots also head the foreign policy agenda. In Central America, the United States must mend fences with nations angered by the U.S. invasion of Panama. And many lawmakers are critical of the administration's overtures to the repressive regime in China. Congress this week weighs Bush's veto last year of a bill that would potentially permit more than 30,000 Chinese students to remain in the United States when their visas expire rather than forcing them to return to their homeland. An override of the veto is possible in the House, but its fate in the Senate is uncertain.

DOC.HEAD: `Independent' Advisers Have Financial Ties to Weapons Business
DOC.TEXT: At least two companies hired by the Energy Department as independent investigators of environmental and safety conditions at nuclear weapons plants are on the payroll at facilities they investigated, government records show. Others participating in the audits had bid for Energy Department contracts at sites they investigated, although they were not yet working there. Still others, while not associated with the plants they audited, are the Energy Department's prime contractors at other nuclear bomb factories. Written department guidelines for carrying out the ``independent tiger team'' investigations include a provision aimed at avoiding organizational conflicts of interest. It defines such a conflict as a situation in which a contractor ``has past, present or currently planned interests that either directly or indirectly ... may relate to the work to be performed'' and which may bias its judgment. The tiger teams were assembled by Energy Secretary James D. Watkins last summer to give an independent view of the plants' compliance with state and federal environmental, safety and health standards. The auditing work is meant to lay the groundwork for actions to correct unsafe and illegal practices at the plants. Virtually all 17 major weapons facilities have severe environmental problems; estimates of the cost of cleaning up production wastes are as high as $100 billion. Watkins publicly stressed the independence of the tiger teams but did not explain that many of the experts would be tied to the weapons business. The Energy Department, which owns the plants, declined to comment on whether the contractors' connections to the weapons industry amount to a conflict of interest that undermines the independence of the investigations or taints the findings. Department spokeswoman Catherine Kaliniak said the department would prefer to use its own employees for this work, ``but we don't have the people to do it.'' Each team is headed by a small number of department officials, but most of the scientific work is done by contract employees. Most have extensive backgrounds in nuclear environmental and safety matters. A review of department records as well as interviews with government and industry officials show that of the eight weapons plant investigations done last year, at least three involved companies that held other Energy Department contracts at the same sites or were bidding for contract work at those facilities. _The engineering and environmental consulting firm NUS Corp. of Gaithersburg, Md., was on the tiger team that investigated the Y-12 uranium processing plant at Oak Ridge, Tenn., last fall. According to department records, NUS at the same time was working for the Oak Ridge reservation on an environmental study of its nuclear and hazardous waste management. The Y-12 plant is one of several operations at the Oak Ridge reservation. NUS's Oak Ridge contract was awarded Nov. 8, 1988, and was valued at $1.4 million. The firm also holds contracts at weapons facilities in South Carolina and Idaho. NUS spokesman Don Couchman declined to discuss any aspect of the firm's work for the Energy Department. _Science Applications International Corp. of La Jolla, Calif., helped evaluate the Nevada Test Site, which conducts underground nuclear weapons tests. The company at the same time was working at the site under two Energy Department contracts with a combined value of $100 million. Most of its work is at a proposed high-level nuclear waste dump at the site that was not part of the tiger team audit. _ICF Kaiser Engineers, an engineering and construction company based in Oakland, Calif., participated in tiger team audits at the Nevada Test Site. ICF held no Energy Department contracts at the test site at the time of the investigation last November, but it was bidding for a $5 million job to help the facility's prime contractor, Reynolds Electrical & Engineering Co., Inc., develop and carry out an environmental cleanup program there. ICF Kaiser announced it won the contract 10 days after the on-site tiger team work ended Dec. 1. Similarly, records show the company participated in tiger team investigations at the Fernald uranium processing plant in Ohio and the Y-12 Oak Ridge plant while it was a bidder for major Energy Department contracts at both sites. The contract at Oak Ridge is valued at $505 million over five years, according to Bob Lynch, deputy director of the department's field office there. Marc Tipermas, executive vice president of ICF, said in a telephone interview that he saw no conflict of interest in his company's involvement in the tiger team work. He said he was not sure whether, in choosing ICF for the work, the department knew or cared about the company's other work at the weapons plants. ``In order to get this job done well and quickly, contractors had to be used,'' Tipermas said. ``Like many other companies, we were drafted. We were helter-skelter pulled onto these teams.'' The Energy Department has used private contractors to run the nuclear weapons plants since they were built as part of the World War II Manhattan Project that produced the atomic bombs dropped on Japan in 1945. The contracting system has left the department with little internal expertise in this area and a tendency to rely on the weapons makers to police themselves. Watkins strongly advocates hiring more federal employees with environmental, safety and health expertise to lessen the dependence on private contractors. Although the department insists that the tiger team members' links to the weapons industry do not compromise their objectivity as judges of environmental and safety conditions at the plants, some outside experts disagree. ``It's inevitably a potential conflict when a contractor is reviewing another contractor, and the reason is that any possible criticism of one contractor might lead to future business for another contractor,'' said Donald F. Kettl, a political science professor at Vanderbilt University and author of a book on government use of contractors. Other tiger team members included companies in charge of running nuclear weapons plants, though not the ones they investigated. These include EG&G Inc., which is the prime contractor at the Rocky Flats plutonium processing plant near Denver, the Idaho National Engineering Laboratory at Idaho Falls, which processes naval nuclear fuels, and the Mound Laboratory near Dayton, Ohio, which makes detonators for nuclear arms. Martin Marietta Energy Systems Inc., which runs the Oak Ridge facilities, participated in some other audits, as did subsidiaries of Westinghouse Electric Corp., which runs several weapons sites, and Mason and Hangar Silas Mason Co., operator of the Pantex final weapons assembly plant near Amarillo, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: US Shifts Stance, Will Allow Involuntary Repatriation To Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: The United States will no longer oppose Britain's decision to forcibly send back refugees from Hong Kong to Vietnam, officials say. In exchange, the United States is demanding that Britain stop the involuntary repatriation of the refugees for one year. During that time, relief workers will try to convince the ``boat people'' it is safe for them to go back to Vietnam, said the officials. The revised U.S. position will be presented at an 18-nation meeting Tuesday in Geneva where a solution will be sought to the growing number of Vietnamese stranded in Hong Kong, Thailand and other Southeast Asian countries. Britain has indicated it will reject the yearlong moratorium, but a compromise _ possibly of six months _ is expected to emerge at the two-day meeting, the officials said. The American decision, adopted after months of agonizing deliberations, will anger a strong lobby of Asian Americans and members of Congress opposed to any forced repatriation. ``There isn't a good solution to this,'' said one official, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``It's simply the lesser of evils.'' For months, the United States rejected any involuntary repatriation to Vietnam, citing the country's repressive Stalinist government and extreme poverty. But the problem has grown increasingly acute with a sharp increase of refugees fleeing Vietnam in rickety boats since last spring. More than 60,000 left Vietnam last year, the highest number since 1981, bringing to about 120,000 the number of boat people in those so-called first asylum countries in Southeast Asia. A majority are in Hong Kong, and the rest in the Philippines, Malaysia and Thailand. A small number reached Singapore and Japan. Under a plan adopted in Geneva by the 18 nations last June, 46,000 of the boat people will be resettled in the West over the next 3 years, about half in the United States. Those who return to Vietnam receive $650 from the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees and a guarantee against reprisal or persecution. The British, citing cramped conditions for refugees on the already crowded island of Hong Kong, decreed that all boat people who sailed to the colony after June 1988 were illegal immigrants unless able to prove they fled persecution rather than economic hardships. The British also sought approval from the international community for sending back Vietnamese even if they refused to go, and forcibly sent back 51 refugees from Hong Kong last month. The United States found itself increasingly isolated among the 18 nations of the Geneva agreement, with only Vietnam and the Soviets on its side. ``We feel we must make some accommodation with the British,'' said the same official. ``Not that we like it, but we're afraid if we don't, we'll lose even the first asylum countries'' such as Hong Kong, Malaysia, Thailand and the Philippines. Fearful of being saddled with thousands of Vietnamese refugees who are ineligible for resettlement elsewhere, Malaysia has pushed away 60 boatloads of Vietnamese, said the official. There have been several cases of Thailand doing so as well. ``We're going to demand iron clad guarantees'' that the international community shoulder the burden of repatriating the Vietnamese and that the U.N. high commissioner can monitor against persecution, he said. So far, about 900 Vietnamese have gone back voluntarily. But the United States believes that with the right counseling, more can be persuaded to return, the official said. ``They basically have to understand that they will receive financial help, that the U.N. will make sure they're not persecuted, and that their only other choice is to rot in camps'' in other countries, he said. The United States will ask Japan, Australia and Britain to contribute heavily to the repatriation fund, he said. The United States has taken in 900,000 of the 1.5 million who fled Vietnam since the war ended in 1975.

DOC.HEAD: Members of the Atlanta Police Bomb Squad Work On The Thin Edge
DOC.TEXT: When members of the Atlanta police bomb squad were called last month to the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, they quickly realized they were dealing with someone whose only interest was murder. ``We knew we had a federal judge in Alabama that had been killed by one that blew up,'' recalled Sgt. William H. Briley, bomb squad supervisor. ``We knew we had an intact item here that was definitely deadly, but if we could disrupt it, we might gain some valuable information. ``I thought that was important enough to stick my neck out on a limb.'' He took the bomb to a police shooting range and dismantled it. Investigators believe the bomb Briley dismantled Dec. 18 is related to ones that killed Judge Robert Vance of the 11th Circuit in suburban Birmingham, Ala., and Savannah attorney Robert Robinson, plus another bomb sent to the Jacksonville, Fla., office of the NAACP at about the same time. A letter to an Atlanta television station said a group called ``Americans for a Competent Federal Judiciary System'' sent the bombs to protest what it called preferential treatment of black suspects. No arrests have been made. Briley would not discuss the contents of the bomb except to say it was a powerful one. But he said handling it or any other bomb, is a test of wits pitting the officer against the bomb builder. ``Nothing is absolute. The building of a bomb is limited only by the imagination and ability of the builder,'' said Briley. ``You realize some day someone is going to build one you can't figure out.'' In the month since the bombings, the Atlanta bomb squad has handled more than 100 suspicious packages but found no more explosives. Each call is handled as if the package were a bomb. Portable X-ray equipment is used to try to determine what's inside. Then the decision is made whether the package is safe, whether to move it, detonate it or dismantle it. After that, it's up to the skill of the individual bomb technician. ``If you mess up, you've done just exactly what he wanted you to do and you might lose your life real easy,'' Briley said. ``We try to do this according to procedures, but there's no way you can guarantee you won't be killed.'' Briley has been with the bomb squad, a small unit within the city police Special Weapons and Tactics unit, since it was founded 12 years ago. Its members have passed a four-week course in explosives handling given by the U.S. Army at Redstone Arsenal in Huntsville, Ala. The squad's equipment includes X-ray machines, a bomb-handling container, an armored trailer for transporting explosives and armored suits that provide some protection in case of explosion, ``but if you're right over it, nothing is going to help.'' While the courthouse episode received a lot of publicity, many lesser known operations are just as dangerous. Briley said there were cases in California of people being killed disposing of fireworks, and discarded dynamite is particularly dangerous because it becomes more unstable as it deteriorates. Briley says he ``couldn't think of any place I wouldn't rather have been'' that Dec. 18, but describes the intensity of feeling that goes through a squad member after a successful mission. ``The relief with something like this is something you can't feel. The blood is flowing through your body at such a rate it doesn't automatically slow down,'' he said. ``You can feel it in your movements.''

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Uses Troops to Oust Governor, Supporters
DOC.TEXT: Government forces on Saturday ousted a provincial governor suspected of backing the December coup attempt, forcing his supporters from the local capitol building with tear gas and clubs, a radio report said. The action was widely seen as a barometer of the resolve of President Corazon Aquino to punish participants in coup attempts. The independent radio station DZRH said local government Secretary Luis Santos ordered troops to disperse about 10,000 supporters of Rodolfo Aguinaldo, governor of Cagayan province in northern Luzon island. The forces were flown in from Manila, about 200 miles to the south. For several days, scores of Aguinaldo's youthful supporters prevented Santos and Vice Gov. Melvin Vargas from entering the capitol building at Tuguegarao. ``I will not allow the dignity of this office (to) get trampled upon by your governor,'' Santos said. Of the defiant supporters, he said, ``We will clear them up.'' The Supreme Court upheld a government decision to suspend Aguinaldo on Jan. 6 because he allegedly threatened to send troops and tanks to Manila last month to support the bid to oust Mrs. Aquino. DZRH said the government forces Saturday fired several rounds of tear-gas canisters, and units armed with truncheons and shields pushed back the crowd to allow Santos, Vargas and military officials to enter the provincial capitol. Santos swore in Vargas as acting governor after Aguinaldo was seized. Aguinaldo was ordered suspended 60 days while authorities investigate his alleged role in the Dec. 1-9 coup attempt, the radio station said. On Thursday, Defense Secretary Fidel Ramos claimed Aguinaldo agreed to vacate his office at midday Friday, but Aguinaldo later denied that report. In addition to the latest accusations, Aguinaldo was implicated _ but never charged _ in an August 1987 coup attempt. Afterward, he resigned from the military and raised his own private army, ostensibly to fight Communist rebels. He was elected governor of Cagayan by a landslide in January 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Mitterrand and Thatcher Discuss European Upheaval
DOC.TEXT: The leaders of France and Britain on Saturday held another in a series of meetings to discuss the political developments in Eastern Europe. Neither President Francois Mitterrand nor Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher commented after their 90-minute meeting, described as a working lunch. The meeting was the latest of several between the two leaders that have focused on the democratic reforms sweeping Eastern Europe and the possibility that the two Germanys may eventually reunify. Both leaders believe that to secure the recent democratic changes in the Soviet bloc, the West must strongly support Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his ambitious program of political and economic reforms.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Soviet Troops Battle Extremists in Baku, Dozens Reported Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with speech by Gorbachev explaining why the crackdown was ordered. Pickup 12th, `Today's violence...' TRIMS to tighten.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY6,7,8
DOC.TEXT: Soviet troops stormed the Azerbaijani capital today, punched through barricades erected by militants and reportedly killed dozens of people in an attempt to end ethnic violence and territorial disputes in the region. ``The street is covered with blood,'' Vadim Korsh, an editor of Azerbaijan's official news agency, Azerinform, said of the scene of one of the biggest clashes, the military garrison in the capital, Baku. Corpses were strewn on the road to Baku's airport, he said in a telephone interview from the southern Soviet city of 1.8 million. The government declared a state of emergency in Baku, which was reported to be paralyzed and heavily patrolled by troops with tanks. Authorities say Armenian and Azerbaijani ``warriors'' are armed with stolen helicopters, tanks and even ground-to-ground missiles. The government on Friday suspended the Defense Ministry's callup of reservists to beef up military units in the face of widespread public protest. Reports of the number of deaths conflicted. Korsh said the office of Baku's mayor reported the death toll was 60. Alexander A. Bessmertnykh, first deputy Soviet foreign minister, said eight soldiers and more than 40 people who attacked the troops were killed. He told a briefing in Moscow his information came from Azerbaijan's Interior Ministry, which oversees the republic's police. Activists spoke of much higher death tolls. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev discussed the crisis in a nationally televised address tonight in which he said the crackdown was necessary because two years of trying to solve the ethnic conflict peacefully had failed. Militants were forming their own bands of warriors, arming them and killing people, Gorbachev said. ``This had to stop,'' he said. Azerinform reported hundreds of wounded, but no exact figure was available from the agency or other sources. If the death toll of 60 is confirmed, the toll in the Caucasus violence that began a week ago would be more than 140 people killed and more than 220 wounded. Western reporters have been banned from the region. Gorbachev has repeatedly warned that the violence between Azerbaijanis and Armenians, which has deep historical roots, could cause a national tragedy by igniting other territorial disputes and pro-independence movements that could jeopardize his program of economic and political reforms. Today's violence and confusion were further complicated by more daring and unexpected political moves by Azerbaijanis. The legislature of the Nakhichevan Autonomous Republic voted to secede from Azerbaijan as well as from the U.S.S.R., the Interior Ministry in Moscow and Iran's official news agency reported. Nakhichevan is a small Azerbaijani enclave of a quarter-million people surrounded by Armenian, Iranian and Turkish territory. It has been under Azerbaijan's jurisdiction since 1924. Asked about the decision, Bessmertnykh told reporters it was unprecedented and condemned it as an illegal act violating the Soviet Constitution, which requires the consent of the host republic for autonomous districts to secede. Iran's official news agency said the Nakhichevan's Supreme Soviet demanded that Soviet troops leave the enclave and called on Turkey, Iran and the United Nations to help safeguard its territorial integrity and prevent a massacre. Territorial disputes are at the heart of the unrest that is sweeping Azerbaijan and the neighboring republic of Armenia. Armenians launched a campaign two years ago to wrest control of the district of Nagorno-Karabakh from Azerbaijan. On Jan. 13, Azerbaijanis staged anti-Armenian riots in Baku, and fighting between both ethnic groups spread throughout the region. Azerbaijanis are predominantly Moslem, and Armenians are mostly Christian. Troops were reported to have moved into Baku, a Caspian Sea port city, early today. Official media said military units entered Baku, were fired on by militants of the Azerbaijan's Popular Front, a group that has organized anti-Armenian protests, and ``were forced to retaliate.'' The rebels reportedly blocked roads with buses, trucks and cars in an effort to prevent troop movements. Nazim Ragimov, an unofficial journalist, said he saw 12 corpses and that battles continued overnight. Korsh said shots were ringing out and tanks and armored personnel carriers patrolled during the day. A Radio Moscow correspondent reported from Baku that cordons of soldiers were massed in the capital's main square and that they wore flak jackets and helmets. Activists said tens of thousands of people poured into the square, outside the Communist Party headquarters, this afternoon to demand that the republic's legislature meet in emergency session to demand the resignation of party chief Abdul-Rakhman Vezirov and the lifting of the state of emergency. Gorbachev signed a decree today extending to Baku a state of emergency imposed earlier in the week in other strife-torn parts of the Caucasus. Radio Moscow said the action by the government's highest executive body followed ``attempts by criminal extremist forces, through violence and mass disturbances, to depose the legally functioning state bodies.'' The broadcast said the measure forbids strikes, and street processions, the use of duplicating equipment and the use of transport without special permission. Bessmertnykh told reporters the measures and introduction of troops had improved the situation. ``Things are better than they were before troops were introduced,'' he said. But the reports of mass rallies and the continued sound of gunshots ringing out in the capital indicated otherwise. Soviet army and internal security troops have been building up in Armenia and Azerbaijan for several days, but they had not entered Baku until today. Leila Unusova, a spokeswoman for an organization calling itself the Azerbaijani Social Democrat Group, reported by telephone from Baku that Soviet troops had surrounded the square near the Communist Party headquarters where 30,000 Azerbaijanis had gathered in an anti-government protest. She said the forces included armored personnel carriers, water cannons and other military equipment, but she did not know whether soldiers there had opened fire. ``Our citizens blockaded roads on the south and north with cars and buses,'' she said. ``Young people, 20 to 25 years old, were there'' manning the barricades. Korsh said tanks and armored personnel carriers plowed through the barricades, running over anyone in their way. Shortly after midnight Friday, Ms. Unusova said, Soviet army troops entered the city from the north and from a base inside the Baku military academy and opened fire on the militants' positions. The biggest battles reportedly raged around the airport and military garrison, where armed protesters had been trying to prevent troop reinforcements from traveling to the strife-torn areas. Wounded were being taken to three hospitals in the city, Ms. Unusova said. ``It's very dangerous on the street,'' Ms. Unusova said four hours after the shooting started. ``Battles are still going on.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Soars in Polls, Tops Reagan's Rating After Year in Office
DOC.TEXT: President Bush gets a higher approval rating in polls than Ronald Reagan did eight years ago, though only one in five Americans realizes it, a group that studies public awareness of the news said Saturday. ``That perception may prove to be as important to the president as his actual standing in the opinion polls,'' said Andrew Kohut, director of surveys for Times Mirror Center for People and the Press. Times Mirror said its latest survey, conducted just after Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega surrendered to American authorities, showed 81 percent approval of the way Bush is handling his job after a year in office. This compares with 49 percent for Reagan in January, 1982, when the country was slipping into a recession from which it later recovered. The latest Washington Post-ABC News poll, also conducted after the U.S. invasion of Panama, gave Bush an approval rating of 79 percent, six points higher than what Reagan ever achieved as president. Only one person in five, however, had the impression that Bush is more popular than Reagan was at the corresponding point in his first term. ``If fifty years of history tell us anything, Bush's approval ratings are likely to fall well below their current mark,'' Kohut said. ``The question for Bush watchers is whether the president's quiet popularity, at what may be the peak of his approval ratings, can cushion him during the trough in his ratings.'' ``In Washington politics, perceptions of popularity count a lot,'' he said. ``A serious decline in the approval rating of a popular president, who is not perceived as popular, might prove more costly than it did for a leader like Reagan, whose perceived public esteem was often ahead of his actual scores.'' Forty percent of the people surveyed by Times Mirror said they thought Bush was less popular than Reagan, compared with 20 percent who said he was more popular. Another 36 percent said the two were about equally popular. ``To some extent, this disparity between perception and reality may be explained by the difference in intensity of public feelings toward the two leaders,'' Kohut said. ``But, so far, those differences tend to be relatively small.'' Over the course of the Reagan presidency, about half of those who approved of the president did so strongly, the Times Mirror official said. In the Washington Post-ABC poll about one out of three persons in the sample strongly approved of Bush's job performance, the highest level of strong support for him since he took office. A Gallup poll earlier this month showed Bush with an 80 percent approval rating, higher than that for any other president at the same point in his first term since World War II.

DOC.HEAD: Teen Arrested in Slashing Of Actress Viveca Lindfors
DOC.TEXT: An 18-year-old man was arrested Saturday morning and charged with slashing actress Viveca Lindfors and a second person with a razor in Greenwich Village last weekend, police said. Peter Bedford was arrested at a friend's house in Brooklyn after police received an anonymous tip, said police spokesman Sgt. Norris Hollomon. Bedford was charged with two counts of assault and criminal possession of a deadly weapon, Hollomon said. The razor allegedly used in the attacks was not recovered. Hollomon said he didn't know what the motive was. He is accused of slashing Ms. Lindfors, 69, and Dennis Beal, 36, on the face and head in separate incidents as they walked through Greenwich Village early in the morning of Jan. 13. The attacks occurred about three blocks and five minutes apart. Both victims said they were accosted by a gang of young people and one member of the gang did the slashing. The Swedish-born Ms. Lindfors, who appeared in the movie ``The Way We Were,'' needed 27 stitches after the attack. Beal required 40 stitches to close his wound.

DOC.HEAD: Thai-Malaysia Border May Be Opened At Night
DOC.TEXT: In a bid to attract tourism, the government may change a policy that has kept the Malaysia-Thailand border closed at night for 41 years, the prime minister said Saturday. The minister, Mahathir Mohamad, said security along the border has improved since the government and guerrillas of the outlawed Communist Party of Malaya reached an agreement recently ending the party's 41-year insurgency. The guerrillas had operated mostly in border areas. Mahathir told reporters the proposal is in line with the government's objective of attracting more tourists to the country, especially from Thailand. The decision to extend the checkpoint hours, now 6 a.m. to 6 p.m., will be made after Mahathir meets with security officials about tightening anti-smuggling controls along the border, the National News Agency Bernama reported.

DOC.HEAD: Booze Consumption Rises After Iceland Lifts Beer Restriction
DOC.TEXT: The consumption of alcohol shot up more than 20 percent in Iceland last year after the nation lifted a 73-year ban on the sale of strong beer, a study indicates. Figures released Friday by the state alcohol monopoly show that Icelanders over the age of 15 consumed an average of 9.7 pints of pure alcohol in beer, spirits and other drinks in 1989, compared with 7.88 pints the year before. The organization said the 22.9 percent rise in consumption was largely due to the legalization March 1, 1989 of beer with more than 2.25 percent alcohol. The move was greeted with many parties, bar openings and offers of free drinks, and by dire predictions that public drunkeness would increase. Before that, Icelanders could drink spirits, wine and low-alcohol beer but could not legally buy strong beer except at airport duty-free stores.

DOC.HEAD: Rally of Four White Supremecists Brings Throngs of Police, Protesters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Williams skirting Atlanta demonstration and arriving in Forsyth County, details of Atlanta rally, two arrests. Picks up 9th graf, `Many Americans ...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AX3
DOC.TEXT: Four white supremacists demonstrated near the gravesite of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. today as more than 2,500 police and National Guard troops kept counterdemonstrators a distance. The Mississippi-based leader of the Nationalist Movement, Richard Barrett, was accompanied by three supporters as he read statements reviling King at the King National Historic Site, across the street from the civil rights leader's tomb. ``That grave is not a throne. That corpse is not a king. We are here to bury a tyranny,'' Barrett said. His group left with a police escort less than an hour later, to jeers from about 75 mostly young and racially mixed counterdemonstrators who gathered in fog and drizzle. Plans for what President Bush denounced Friday as ``a rally of hate'' caused the adjacent Martin Luther King Jr. Center for Nonviolent Social Change to close for the day. Civil rights activist Hosea Williams, who had planned to gather supporters at King's tomb, settled for briefly parking two busloads of people near the police lines and then headed north to virtually all-white Forsyth County, where Barrett planned to march later. Around noon, about 60 supporters of Williams, a former King aide and Atlanta city councilman, were marching toward Cumming, about an hour ride from Atlanta. Some onlookers greeted the civil rights supporters with Confederate battle flags. Some of the Atlanta counterdemonstrators, who took to the streets against the wishes of civil rights groups, used bullhorns to criticize police for protecting the white supremacists. The counterdemonstrators, including members of the Revolutionary Communist Youth Brigade, could get no closer than 200 yards to Barrett. Atlanta police said there were two arrests _ one for disorderly conduct and one for public drunkenness _ in the vicinity of the rally. Many Americans regard King's tomb _ and the surrounding blocks where he grew up and preached _ as a sacred place, said Randolph Scott, director of the King federal historic site. ``We feel the same way,'' Scott said. ``But he (Barrett) does have the right to protest, like any other group. We would have hoped he would have selected some other site ... but we couldn't deny him.'' President Bush, in Atlanta on Friday at a homebuilders' convention, denounced the Barrett protest. ``Atlanta is a great, cheerful city that has proudly risen from the ashes of a distant past,'' Bush said. ``And so, for those who plan to revel in a rally of hate here tomorrow, let them know this: Atlantans, like all Americans, turn their backs on bigots.'' The security surrounding today's events was nothing new; more than 2,400 police, National Guards troops and other law enforcement officers were called out to seal off the state Capitol area two weeks ago for a rally by a Ku Klux Klan group. The estimated total cost of the security was $500,000, and the governor said this week he was ``very troubled'' by the burden such demonstrations were placing on Georgia taxpayers. Forsyth County, a virtually all-white rural and suburban area north of Atlanta, is the site where Williams and a group of ``brotherhood marchers'' in January 1987 were pelted with rocks by a jeering crowd. After publicity over the violence, Williams returned the next week with 20,000 supporters in one of the largest civil rights marches in the United States since the 1960s peak of the movement. In January 1988, Barrett and a small group of demonstrators were pelted with rocks, bricks and cement during a protest march through downtown Atlanta.

DOC.HEAD: Solidarity Leaders Wonder if Gdansk Shipyard Can Be Saved
DOC.TEXT: With their American backer's role now in question, Solidarity leaders wonder if anything can save the rough-and-tumble shipyard where Eastern Europe's revolution began a decade ago. In spite of a rare sunny stretch for selling ships, the century-old Gdansk Shipyard faces collapse, a victim of the system its workers sought to change and the upheaval they unleashed. ``What happens next?'' reflected Zbigniew Lis, the union's delegate at the yard, echoing a reporter's question. ``That's what we'd like to know. This is an hourglass, and the last grains are dropping.'' Negotiations suddenly cooled with Barbara Piasecka Johnson, the Polish-born heiress who last May said she would spend up to $100 million to take the enterprise out of the red. She emerged with Lech Walesa from a church in Gdansk and pledged to buy a 55 percent interest. Walesa, in an interview last week, eluded questions on what went wrong. But Lis made no effort to mask bitterness at a proposal which, he said, ``turns her generous offer into a Trojan Horse.'' An aide to Mrs. Johnson said she still wanted to invest in the shipyard, despite reports the deal had unraveled. ``Mrs. Johnson is still very interested and enthusiastic about the shipyard,'' John Peach, her assistant, said by telephone from Princeton, N.J. He said the group of advisers Mrs. Johnson assembled to work on the deal remains intact. ``We plan to be over there as soon as the government says `Come on over.''' According to Solidarity and shipyard officials, Mrs. Johnson wanted a guarantee that there would be no strikes for five years along with a five-year wage contract of 50 cents an hour. Zbigniew Lis, a Solidarity representative, was quoted in the youth daily Sztandar Mlodych on Jan. 8 as saying other joint ventures pay about $1 to $1.50 per hour. Also, they said, Mrs. Johnson wanted to halve the work force to about 3,700 men, limiting production to 10 ships a year, a third of capacity. ``We are not interested in running at our lowest level in 45 years,'' said Hans Szye, operations director. ``We want to build it up. In 29 years in this business, I've never seen a better world market.'' Experts agree. Many European shipbuilders closed down in recent years, faced with Asian competition, and aging vessels must be replaced. Specialized ships are in growing demand. But ships take two to three years to build, and credit is essential. Polish banks charge 58 percent a month interest, Szye said, and foreign banks recoil in fear. In October 1988, Communist authorities said they would close the yard for economic reasons, throwing its already troubled affairs into turmoil. Violent reaction helped to topple the government. More recently, a Solidarity-based government decided to offer the company to shareholders, as soon as enabling laws are passed. Meantime, authorities are looking for foreigners with capital. Although Walesa said four or five investors are interested, Szye said the only serious candidate after Mrs. Johnson is Vulkan of Bremen, West Germany. And that raises another problem. For centuries, Poles and Germans have fought bitterly over the Gothic glories of Gdansk, or Danzig, a historic port on the Baltic. ``We would like to see Vulkan participate, and we would like to cooperate,'' Lis said. ``But German ownership? I don't think so. This is a very delicate matter.'' Lis said that although Solidarity wanted the government to advance some capital, he had few expectations. ``The government has a lot of good will but no money.'' On Mrs. Johnson, he said, ``I think the intention diverged from the possibility, and we did not get the help she was talking about all over the world.'' Whoever steps in, if anyone, all parties agree there is no time to lose. In 1975, as the Lenin Shipyard, the 320-acre complex turned out 32 ships, with a total deadweight of 300,000 tons. Last year, production was seven ships, 70,000 tons in all. Repeated strikes since 1980, and Poland's chaotic situation, have cost business. Each new order requires at least a year of preparation to design tools and await deliveries. At first glance, the shipyard looks a rust-flecked museum to Socialist central planning, a vast sprawl of half-finished ideas decorated by faded slogans emblazoned on billboards. Its dramatic skyline of giant blue cranes reveals little movement. In the afternoon, when the lone shift goes home, it is a neo-industrial Victorian ghost town. Work is paralyzed on a giant Soviet factory ship, for processing fish at sea, until the shipyard's administrative status is made clear. But the slipways and crucial workings remain intact, and shipbuilding goes on at a pace which engineers say could be easily enhanced. A West German car ferry and a little fleet of Polish and Soviet trawlers are taking shape. Two freighters and several wood transports are nearly done. ``It's a fine old place,'' said Leon Sobolewski, a yard official who beamed at a visitor's interest. He mused aloud at the yard's tall ships, three-masted sailing vessels for the Soviet and Polish navies. ``There's a lot of life left here.'' For many Poles, the yard's main attraction is outside of its front gate, three soaring steel crosses commemorating the 28 people killed in the 1970 food riots before workers organized. Nearby, a glass case displays memorabilia of Solidarity's triumphs. Someone has quietly removed the color photograph of Mrs. Johnson.

DOC.HEAD: Crash In New York Suburb Kills New Ambassador to Gambia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT spelling of Greenburgh.
DOC.TEXT: Ruth Washington, the newly appointed ambassador to Gambia, was killed early Saturday in an auto accident involving a drunken driver, police said. Washington, 67, was killed when a car crossed the center line and struck her car head-on about 2:05 a.m., said Sgt. Robert Brown of the Greenburgh police. Washington was pronounced dead at the scene, he said. The driver of the other car, Angela Penessa, 23, of Scarsdale, was in critical condition at White Plains Medical Center, a spokeswoman said. Brown said she was arrested for driving while intoxicated. Washington, a former U.S. magistrate for the Southern District of New York, was sworn in as ambassador to Gambia on Dec. 18, succeeding Herbert E. Horowitz. Washington was headed for her home in Greenburgh when the accident occurred, Brown said. She was due to leave for Gambia within a few days.

DOC.HEAD: `Welcome Home': Columbia Lands Safely in California Desert
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, `The shuttle's...', with 2 grafs to UPDATE with inspection showing more tile damage than originally seen, but still below average, maneuvering system repair possibly needed and brakes hotter than expected; SUBS 14-15th grafs, `It looked...,' with 3 grafs with astronauts' departure and comments. Picks up 15th graf pvs: `Mission controllers...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos EAB1, HTN1
DOC.TEXT: The space shuttle Columbia landed in darkness today with a rescued satellite aboard after overcoming weather and computer problems that extended the mission to a record of nearly 11 days. The shuttle touched down about 1:35 a.m. PST and rolled to a stop showing no apparent problem from its heavy cargo, which gave Columbia a landing weight of 228,400 pounds, more than 8,000 pounds heavier than the previous shuttle record. ``Roger, Columbia. Welcome home. An outstanding job,'' said Mike Baker, capsule communicator. ``You showed us the shuttle at its best, at deploying and retrieving satellites. ``Great way to start the decade,'' he said. Before retrieving the scientific satellite, Columbia's crew deployed a Navy communications satellite. Despite Columbia's record weight, ``it was a beautiful landing,'' with the nose gear touching down gently and no sign of brake damage on initial inspection, said William B. Lenoir, NASA's associate administrator for space flight. A closer but still preliminary inspection later found that the brakes heated up more than expected, because of Columbia's heavy load, and an orbital maneuvering system may need repair, said shuttle processing manager Larry Ellis. The examination also found that the shuttle's heat-shield tiles sustained eight ``dings'' larger than one inch and 85 smaller than that, he said. Another tile may need to be replaced, but the overall tile damage rate is ``a little below average,'' Ellis said, adding that Columbia ``is in excellent condition.'' The spacecraft approached Edwards unseen to the human eye, but revealed itself with a whooshing noise, then suddenly appeared out of the dark like a ghost, backlit by powerful searchlights illuminating the runway. The shuttle's trademark twin sonic booms woke residents on the coast in Malibu as the orbiter streaked toward its desert landing site. About two dozen people called Malibu police. ``Some thought it was an earthquake, others said someone was trying to break in or was on the roof,'' said Los Angeles County sheriff's Deputy Sheila Smith. Shuttle commander Daniel Brandenstein, pilot James Wetherbee and mission specialists Bonnie Dunbar, Marsha Ivins and G. David Low left the shuttle 2 hours, 5 minutes after landing. NASA astronauts usually disembark from shuttles about an hour after landing. It took them longer this time because they underwent extended onboard medical exams and took longer to readjust to gravity after the record-long flight, Lenoir said. Eventually, missions of up to 16 days are planned. ``It looked like all five crewmen were quite healthy,'' he said during a news conference. ``We've been spending time with the docs doing a lot of grunts and groans,'' Brandenstein said before he and his crew boarded two jets to to Johnson Space Center in Houston eight hours after Columbia landed. The shuttle's return already delayed a day by poor weather, Columbia was to have landed at 12:01 a.m. today until a problem occurred in a computer that served as a backup to four primary computers aboard the orbiter. Mission controllers canceled an 11 p.m. PST Friday deorbit burn and instead fired the rockets 90 minutes later. The new touchdown time extended the mission to 10 days and 21 hours, more than half a day longer than the previous shuttle duration mark. The faulty computer was taken out of service and its duties as backup were reassigned to one of the other four computers, leaving three primary computers. About 2,000 people came to see the landing although NASA warned that darkness would conceal Columbia until moments before it touched down on a concrete runway illuminated by six 800 million candlepower searchlights. The paved strip was preferred to the recently rain-soaked clay runways on the expansive bed of Rogers Dry Lake. The shuttle carried the 11-ton Long Duration Exposure Facility, an experiment-laden satellite placed in orbit in April 1984 and originally scheduled to be retrieved by a shuttle 10 months later. Subsequent delays and the loss of the shuttle Challenger in 1986 stranded the LDEF for nearly six years, and a decaying orbit threatened to pull it to a fiery end in March until Columbia's robot arm snared and stowed it aboard. Among the 57 experiments carried by the LDEF were 12.5 million tomato seeds to be distributed to schools for study of long-term space effects on growth. The structure of LDEF itself is expected to yield valuable information about space effects on materials which will help in designing a permanent space station. The 12-sided, 30-foot-long LDEF will remain in the cargo bay until the shuttle arrives back at Kennedy Space Center in Florida. The two-day ferry flight atop a jumbo jet is scheduled to begin in about six days. Columbia was launched Jan. 9 and the crew successfully deployed a Navy communications satellite and performed a variety of scientific and medical experiments in addition to capturing the LDEF. The shuttle originally was to land at 2:55 a.m. Friday. However, patchy fog at the Mojave Desert landing site pushed back the landing a day and lengthened the mission to a record. Columbia set the old duration record of 10 days, seven hours, 47 minutes and 24 seconds in late 1983. That flight carried the Spacelab-1 module, which gave the orbiter the old landing weight record of 220,000 pounds.

DOC.HEAD: Communists Debate Democratic Reforms; Hard-liners Win First Round
LaserPhoto BEL1
DOC.TEXT: The outgoing leader of Yugoslavia's ruling Communist Party told delegates to a key congress Saturday that the old model of one-party rule had failed, and he urged them to support free elections.
