Yugoslavia must embrace market-oriented economic reform, free expression and political pluralism, party president Milan Pancevski said, adding that one-party socialism had ``objectively exhausted its possibilities for development.'' Hard-liners won the first round in the four-day meeting, blocking a quick vote on a document that backs free elections and formation of independent political parties and expresses a willingness to surrender the Communists' 45-year monopoly on power. The debate indicated a deep split within the party between those backing rapid political change in conjunction with economic reforms already under way and those reluctant to fully relinquish the Communists' hold on power. Several delegates from the liberal northern republic of Slovenia urged that the document be adopted as it stands as one of the first points of the agenda, apparently to show the party's commitment to reform. But hard-liners, mostly from the largest republic of Serbia, wanted it to be discussed in committee and adopted with other documents at the end of the congress, leading to speculation it could be watered down. The hard-liners successfully blocked a motion calling for an immediate vote. Although 780 delegates favored a quick vote and 645 opposed it, the measure failed to win the needed two-thirds majority. Stefan Koresec, who presided over the morning plenary, said the draft document would be discussed in committee and adopted at the conclusion of the congress with other resolutions. The debate was indicative of ``a deep split within the Yugoslav Communist Party over the issue of a multi-party system,'' said Joze Smole, president of Slovenia's Communist-dominated mass organization Socialist Alliance. He told The Associated Press that Slovenian Communists want to see the declaration be even more explicit on the party relinquishing power, while the Serbs consider the party should retain a dominant role. Serbian delegate Slobodan Jovanovic said delegates needed more time to discuss the document because they had been unable to review it in advance. The declaration, published last week in the media, admits that the one-party system of monopoly ``has pushed us into autocracy and prevented us from keeping up with the economic, technological, political and social changes in Europe and the world.'' The government Friday announced plans to submit to parliament constitutional amendments that would formally scrap the party's guaranteed leading role in society, as well as draft legislation setting forth the legal groundwork for multi-party elections. In his opening address to the congress, Pancevski said Yugoslavia must enact democratic reforms and reform its economy. ``This also means the definite abandonment of the single-party view of political relations. Through the affirmation of new democratic reforms, we must ensure ... the freedom from any monopolies on power,'' Pancevski said, according to an advance text carried by the national news agency Tanjug. A new party chief is to be elected at the congress. ``The building ... of a system that will constantly increase human rights and freedoms, that will strengthen democracy and that will ensure the free expression of political pluralism and an efficient state based on the rule of law'' are imperative to the country's development, he added. The congress, which will also elect a new leadership, was called four months early in the wake of Yugoslavia's growing political and economic crisis. The ruling party, embroiled in internal clashes over how far to go in implementing reform, has stalled on making changes deemed necessary to overcome the country's problems. With spiraling inflation currently at an annual rate of 1,500 percent, a $17 billion foreign debt, dropping living standards and growing unemployment, traditional ethnic rivalries have resurfaced in recent years and added to internal tensions. Non-aligned Yugoslavia, once considered the most liberal of the Communist countries in Europe, has lagged behind some Warsaw Pact countries in recent months on political reform. No foreign delegations were invited to the congress, because delegates wanted the meeting to have a working character. Delegates made another break with tradition when they sang the national anthem at the start of the congress instead of the Communist anthem, the Internationale.

DOC.HEAD: No More Booze at Official Gatherings, and Maybe Dry Flights
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE with ban on liquor aboard flights to Arab and Islamic countries. Pickup 4th pvs, `The airline...
DOC.TEXT: The government Saturday announced a ban on liquor at official gatherings and said it may outlaw liquor on Royal Jordanian airline flights in response to demands by Islamic activists in Parliament. Islamic fundamentalists won more than 30 of the 80 parliamentary seats in November's election, and the Koran, Islam's holy book, forbids liquor consumption. Prime Minister Mudar Badran said no liquor would be sold on flights to Arab and Islamic countries by Royal Jordanian, the national air carrier. He said a study was being conducted to see whether a ban on liquor aboard all flights was feasible. The airline has agreements with other airlines and ``we cannot just ban alcohol immediately and disregard the agreements,'' Madran said. But he issued a written order ``to ban serving spirit drinks on official occasions ... held by ministries, government departments and institutions and Jordanian embassies abroad.'' Earlier, Abdul Munem Abu Zant, a Parliament member from the fundamentalist Moslem Brotherhood party, called for an immediate ban on alcoholic beverages aboard Royal Jordanian. Abu Zant argued that Royal Jordanian should follow the examples of airlines in Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, which have stopped serving liquor. ``We have enough drunk people on earth and therefore we do not need more drugged people in the sky too,'' Abu Zant told Parliament.

DOC.HEAD: A Month After Invasion, Civilian Casualty Count Still Controversial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, However, accounts ...' to fix spelling of Chorrillo; SUBS 16th graf, `Catholic priests ...' to restore first reference to Noriega.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Army claims its ``disciplined fire'' during the invasion of Panama kept civilian deaths to a minimum, but the nation's top medical examiner said the toll was at least 202, and some say it was far higher. ``We have no evidence to say there are thousands, but we know they are not 200,'' said Carmen Miro, a university professor and member of a church group. Some church groups said the number of Panamanian dead could be as high as 1,000, and former U.S. Attorney General Ramsey Clark suggested it could run as high as 7,000, though there is little evidence to support the higher figures. ``We have asked our people throughout the country to make a survey. We think it is closer to 1,000 civilian and military, but nobody knows,'' said Mario Rognoni, a leader of the political opposition to the new government of President Guillermo Endara. The Panama Defense Forces suffered 314 dead as a result of the Dec. 20 invasion; 23 U.S. troops died, along with three American civilians. Clark said his figure of ``anywhere from 4,000 to 7,000 but most likely 2,000'' had come from people he met during the two days he spent here early in January, and not from his own investigation. Roger Montero, director of the national office of forensic medicine, said the civilian death toll nationwide came to 202. Most of the higher estimates were based on the destruction of the crowded neighborhood of El Chorrillo, which is next to the Defense Headquarters building, the main target of the U.S. Army fire the night of the invasion. El Chorrillo, a neighborhood of two- and three-story old wooden buildings that was home to more than 20,000 people, burned to the ground during the fire that broke out after the fighting began. However, accounts from the night of the invasion indicate that many residents had fled El Chorrillo soon after the invasion began and escaped the destruction, so the death toll there was not as high as originally feared. Most artillery and tank fire was directed at the three-story Defense Forces Headquarters. Sheridan tanks fired from Fort Amador, several hundred yards away across an arm of Panama Bay, and from a hill at Quarry Heights, also only a few hundred yards away. ``We had enough time to rehearse. This was an extremely well-executed operation,'' said Lt. Gen. Carl Stiner in an interview. He said the coordinated attacks had been organized to avoid loss of civilian life. For months before the invasion, U.S. forces, arguing that the Panama Canal Treaties allow them to move freely on Panamanian roads, engaged in almost daily maneuvers that included mock takeovers of towns and installations around Panama. In addition to El Chorrillo, civilian deaths also occurred near the airport, in the San Miguelito neighborhood where paramilitary groups fought U.S. forces for several days, and at Rio Hato, a Panamanian military base about 60 miles to the southwest. There was practically no shooting involving civilians in cross-fire throughout the rest of the country, according to U.S. military sources. Catholic priests at an El Chorrillo church told The Associated Press they estimate that about 20 people died in El Chorrillo, many in a fire that was set by retreating paramilitary supporters of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. ``Nearly 10,000 people sought refuge in the church and the school and old folks' home next to it,'' said the Rev. Jose Castano. The Rev. Javier Arteta added that members of the paramilitary Dignity Battalions ``came out of their homes shooting in every direction. They wounded a 6-year-old boy. They did not know what to do.'' ``The U.S. soldiers never fired in the direction of the church,'' Arteta said. ``It was a night of terror,'' said Maria Salgado, who lost her home in the battle and ensuing fire. ``We did not know what was happening.'' Arteta said that about an hour before the attacks, people heard explosions in the direction of Fort Amador, about a mile away, and many fled their homes. ``Throughout the morning, Americans used loudspeakers to warn people to stay away from the area,'' Arteta said. ``The Americans did not care about the dead,'' Arteta added. ``Three days later we had to set fire to six bodies.'' The civilian dead at El Chorrillo were taken to the nearest Panamanian hospital, Santo Tomas. Dr. Leonardo Diaz told journalists the first two days that there were never more than 100 bodies in the morgue. In Colon, 50 miles northwest of Panama City, there were reports of at least 20 civilian dead. In the days following the invasion there were also reports of some dead in isolated encounters with U.S. patrols.

DOC.HEAD: Moynihan's Social Security Plan: Democrats Are Scared, Too
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to cut the Social Security payroll tax already has Republicans running scared, but the New Yorker's fellow Democrats aren't exactly enchanted either. With the White House opposing Moynihan, the Bush administration finds itself opposing a tax cut, an unusual position for the president who made the phrase ``no new taxes'' famous. But Democrats are wary of the budgetary repercussions of Moynihan's idea. Some top Democrats _ trying to not sound harshly critical _ have already publicly raised questions about Moynihan's idea. The support of other top congressional Democrats is conspicuous by its absence. House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., calls the proposal ``very attractive,'' but adds, ``I don't think we ought to add that loss of revenues to the deficit.'' The chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, James Sasser, D-Tenn., has taken open delight at Republican squirming over Moynihan's idea, but warns, ``We can't look at it in isolation from our fiscal condition, and unless we offset the cut our deficit problem will get even worse.'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, called the plan ``an important proposal'' on Friday but stopped short of endorsing it. He said he would withhold a decision on whether to support the plan until he receives studies from his aides on how it would effect the federal budget shortfall. Not heard from at all have been three other major players in any revenue legislation: House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash.; House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill.; and Senate Finance Committee Chairman Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas. ``I haven't seen any bandwagon on the Moynihan thing,'' Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said Friday. Moynihan, considered one of the Senate's experts on Social Security, has said his plan is aimed at preventing the growing surpluses the system generates from artificially lowering the federal deficit. The Social Security system pocketed $50 billion more last year than it paid out, allowing the government's books to show a $152 billion shortfall, rather than one reaching $202 billion. The New Yorker's proposal also gives the Democrats a tax slash that helps lower- and middle-class Americans most of all, since the payroll tax does not apply at all to earnings above $51,300. Moynihan's plan stands in stark contrast to Bush's coveted reduction in the capital gains levy rate, a cut that studies show will be of most benefit to the wealthiest Americans. The cut would add $7 billion to this year's already formidable budget deficit, and $55 billion more to the gap in fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. That's $62 billion more in just two years in spending cuts, borrowing, or increases in other federal taxes that the government would be forced into to compensate for the payroll cut. Even out of a $1.2 trillion budget, the amount of savings to be found is huge. To provide quick perspective, lawmakers will have to find about $35 billion in savings this year for the 1991 budget, and partisan battles over that amount will probably last until Congress adjourns in the fall. So far, just two Democrats have announced support for Moynihan's measure, which he plans to introduce Tuesday, the day lawmakers return from their winter recess. Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., said he would co-sponsor the bill, saying continued use of Social Security funds to hide the full size of the federal deficit are ``a gigantic, although unintended, fraud on the working people of this country.'' Rep. Byron Dorgan, D-N.D., said he would introduce a companion bill in the House, calling it ``the only way to force an addressing of the key issue of the deficit.'' The proposal can't be ignored. Since he announced the plan on Dec. 29 _ the middle of the winter recess _ it has attracted mounting attention by the day. It now looms as one of the major budget issues facing returning lawmakers. ``What can we do,'' mused one Democratic aide. ``If we walk away from it now, someone else will pick it up.'' Moynihan would cut the 7.65 percent payroll tax _ paid separately by workers and their employers _ by 0.14 percent immediately and by 0.96 percent more next January. The levy would begin to rise again in the year 2015 so the Social Security system could begin building up a reserve to pay for the 75 million Baby Boomers who will begin to retire at around that time.

DOC.HEAD: Followers Flock to Commune After Guru's Death
LaserPhoto BOM2
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of followers of Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, the guru of free love, flocked to his commune Saturday a day after his death to celebrated what they consider the release of the Rajneesh's spirit. Rajneesh, 58, died at his commune in the city of Poona on Friday. The official cause of death was heart failure, but a statement released by the commune said he died because ``living in the body had become a hell'' after the Rajneesh's alleged poisoning in U.S. jails. Commune spokesman Swami Chaitanya Kirti said at least 15,000 followers visited the center Saturday and chanted mantras, meditated and danced. ``They celebrated. They came to hear Osho's last words,'' Kirti said in a telephone interview. Since 1988, Rajneesh had gone by the name Osho Rajneesh, having dropped the honorific ``Bhagwan,'' which means ``god'' in Hindi. Osho is a Buddhist term that means ``on whom the heavens shower flowers.'' The spokesman said the guru's last message, communicated through his doctor, said he would be always among his followers. ``Never speak of me in the past tense,'' Rajneesh said in his last message, according to Kirti. ``My presence here will be greater without the presence of my tortured body.'' Rajneesh was deported from the United States in 1985 after pleading guilty to two counts of immigration fraud, which alleged he arranged sham marriages so his followers could remain in the United States illegally. He often claimed to have been poisoned while in jail awaiting trial and deportation. Rajneesh spent four years in central Oregon, where he set up a huge commune that became home to thousands of slavish disciples whose big thrill of the day was seeing the guru drive by and wave from the windows of one of his 93 Rolls-Royces. Rajneesh preached that materialism was good, and his followers lavished him with riches. The commune eventually collapsed after both Rajneesh and his personal secretary were arrested. His secretary was convicted of a variety of crimes, including attempted murder, in connection with a plot to take over the Oregon county in which the commune was located. ``In his final message, Osho said that since the days in jail in Charlotte, North Carolina, his body has been deteriorating,'' said the statement, read to The Associated Press by telephone. ``While he was in Oklahoma County jail, he was poisoned with heavy metal thallium, they exposed him to radiation in a way that it will not leave any proof,'' it said. ``Osho had said he had kept the pain to himself but living in the body had become a hell,'' the statement said. Rajneesh's death has triggered questions on the fate of his commune, which has 500 branches across the globe. A 15-member group has taken over adminstration, Kirti said. ``There are very capable people to take us through,'' he said. ``Nothing has changed and nothing will change.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Speech on Unrest in Azerbaijan
With AM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Following is the text of a nationally televised speech President Mikhail S. Gorbachev made Saturday on the fighting in Azerbaijan. The English-language translation was provided by the official Tass news agency. Comrades, we all are witnessing a protracted inter-ethnic conflict between Azerbaijan and Armenia. We all are seriously concerned over the fact that the tension that arose there not only fails to subside, but becomes aggravated from time to time, leading to serious consequences every time. Over the past two years central authorities have sought to act, for their part, patiently and in thoughtful manner, trying to solve difficult problems exclusively by peaceful, political means. A comradely dialogue, discussions in the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet, the Central Committee of the party, in the government, through visits by U.S.S.R. People's deputies and repeated meetings in Moscow with the leadership of the two republics and with deputies _ all have been used, with the sole aim of achieving harmony, and restoring good neighborly and simply human relations, to find a way out of the dead end and, in the final analysis, to normalize the situation concerning Nagorno-Karabakh. By acting in this way, we proceeded from the conviction that violence, enmity and continuation of the conflict would not result in anything good but would only poison the atmosphere still further and lead to still greater loss of life and breed more violence. Unfortunately, under these conditions party, local government and state bodies of the two republics did not show due responsibility and thoughtfulness and quite often conceded principled positions under the pressure of nationalist groups. This is how it happened lately when sessions of the Supreme Soviets of Armenia and Azerbaijan took decisions that run counter to the Soviet Constitution. They not only failed to promote the normalization of the situation but, on the contrary, aggravated it and heightened confrontation. Neither side listened to the voice of reason conveyed with particular forcefulness from the rostrum of the second congress of the U.S.S.R. People's deputies. The situation was made use of by anti-social, anti-popular elements for further stirring up enmity and exacerbation of the conflict. Armed clashes began, particularly in border areas and in places where Armenians and Azerbaijanis lived side by side. On Jan. 15, this year the Presidium of the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet had to adopt a decree introducing a state of emergency in the Nagorno-Karabakh autonomous region and in some other areas of Azerbaijan and Armenia. It would seem, this measure should have stopped violence and brought to reason extremists and the leaders of popular fronts that plunged their peoples into an abyss of chaos and suffering. But the voice of reason, the voice of the Soviet public and all peoples of our country was ignored this time also. The calls for dialogue, conciliation and tolerance remained unheeded. Moreover, militant national-careerists continued to heat up the situation, form groups of militants and to blockade roads and airports. Attacks on servicemen, arms depots and law enforcement agencies became frequent. The events assumed a particularly tragic character in Baku: rampages, killings, and the driving of innocent people out of their homes and to beyond the republic. Extremist forces' actions in Azerbaijan assumed increasingly overt anti-state, anti-constitutional and anti-popular character. The legitimate authorities were forcibly barred from performing their functions, and government structures were disrupted in a number of areas. Engineering and technical facilities were destroyed along hundreds of kilometers of the state border. The aim of a forcible seizure of power in the republic was not practically concealed. It could no longer continue so. Along with deep compassion for the innocent victims, wrath and indignation at criminal actions, facts of brutal violence, vandalism and the violation of laws have mounted in the country. Soviet people demanded from the country's leadership resolute measures to restore law and order, to ensure safety for people. You already know that the decree of the Presidium of the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet has imposed a state of emergency in Baku, that units of the Interior Ministry and the Soviet army have moved into the city. They occupied key objects and took under control government buildings. Resolute measures are taken against ransackers, organizers and instigators of disturbances. Fire arms and ammunition are seized from criminal elements. To our deep regret there are victims. Military units were met by fire from terrorists in some places and had to use weapons in response. Grief came today into some houses. I convey to these families my most sincere condolences. The tragic events in Baku, the border areas of Azerbaijan and Armenia, other regions of the Caucasus have laid bare the price of nationalist rampage, speculation on sacred national feelings. It is a crime to push people to blind enmity, to the madness of fratricidal war. The state is duty-bound to put an end to lawlessness and inhumanity, to resolutely curb criminal actions of extremists, who have lost human face, who are prepared to take other people's lives for the sake of personal ambitions, selfish interests and power. The state is duty-bound to return peace and security to people and the possibility to develop in a free and democratic way, to work normally, live peacefully, to raise and upbring children to the peoples of the two republics. Soldiers and officers of the Soviet army and interior troops are fulfilling their duty in defending the U.S.S.R. Constitution and law. The leadership hopes that the measures will be understood and supported by all peoples of our country. At this hour I call on all citizens of Azerbaijan and Armenia to show wisdom and common sense, not to give in to provocative slogans and actions. I call on all those who have been deceived and misled or forcibly drawn into criminal actions to come to their senses and to stop. I ask all of you to render every assistance in restoring civil peace, in jointly overcoming the trial that befell our lot. I deeply believe that common sense and responsibility would triumph, would gain the upper hand. Today as never before we need national accord, close cooperation and assistance to each other in the name of better life for all peoples of our state.

DOC.HEAD: New East-West Cooperation on Air Pollution Reported
DOC.TEXT: Pollution has never respected frontiers, but there's something new in the air when a member of a Soviet delegation pleads with Americans to help block a new dam that would damage a wilderness valley in Siberia. ``The vocal support of environmentalists from around the world is critical to our efforts to save the valley,'' said Maria Cherkasova, secretary of the Socio-Ecological Union, one of the Soviets' largest private environmentalist groups. She was a private citizen among the Soviet officials at a meeting in Washington last week of the U.S.-Soviet Joint Committee on Cooperation in the Field of Environmental Protection. She called for a campaign of letters to President Mikhail Gorbachev and other Soviet leaders on behalf of the Katun valley near the Chinese border. Pollution _ domestic and international _ is expected to be a lively issue in Washington in the next few months. This week the Senate takes up a clean air bill that originated with the Bush administration. A similar bill is working its way through the House and agreement this year is widely expected, though Bush has threatened to veto it if changes in Congress make it cost too much. Ms. Cherkasova's plea was cited by Worldwatch Institute as evidence of new East-West cooperation on the environment. The institute, a non-profit advocacy group, found other examples: _ The Soviet government is already getting advice on more efficient use of energy, which also means less pollution, from the Natural Resources Defense Council in New York and the Rocky Mountain Institute in Colorado. _ Congress has decided to allocate a symbolic $40 million to help the environment in Poland and Hungary _ Volkswagen of West Germany will join with East Germans to make a new, less polluting ``Super-Trabbi'' to be sold in both countries. The Trabant (Satellite) _ familiarly known as the Trabbi _ has been the only readily available car in East Germany. The need for something else struck West Germans sharply as more and more of them began to appear on their beloved autobahns, driven by East Germans and spewing thick streams of black from their two-stroke engines. _ Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway and Sweden will set up an investment company for joint environmental ventures in eastern Europe. Hilary F. French, author of an article to appear in the March-April edition of ``Worldwatch Magazine,'' also found some cause for concern in the prospect of new relations between East and West. She said environmentalists are worried that the rush to help Eastern Europe's economy could lead to disasters. ``Even in the environmental area, `technology transfer' could do more harm than good if it is simply a way for western companies to find new markets,'' she wrote. She suggested that western companies could try to sell obsolete equipment and emphasize what she called ``technological band-aids'' rather than root out pollution at the source, as she urges. In a longer study, called ``Clearing the Air: A Global Agenda,'' she pointed out that pollution comes from both East and West. Norway, for example, ``imports'' 96 percent of the sulfur that falls on its soil _ most of it presumably from the East. But it also ``exports'' 76 percent of its own emissions. In the early 1980s, the latest period for which French has figures, Milan, Italy, had the highest annual average of sulfur in its atmosphere. Shenyang _ the old Manchurian city of Mukden _ was second. Shenyang also had more days in the year when the quantity was above the standard considered dangerous: 146 days compared with 66 days for Milan. She quoted the Natural Resources Defense Council as saying that New York violated the federal standard for ozone on 34 days a year, two or three times a week all summer. In Los Angeles it was 172 days a year, almost every other day. She added that counties in which more than half of all Americans live are out of compliance with ozone standards.

DOC.HEAD: Journalist Foe of Aoun Kidnapped, Held Eight Hours
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with claim of casualties in fighting. Pickup 6th pvs, `Hajj was...
DOC.TEXT: A journalist who has been an outspoken critic of Christian leader Gen. Michel Aoun was seized by gunmen Saturday and held more than eight hours before being released. Aoun was accused of planning the abduction. The reporter, George Hajj, refused to talk to reporters after he was set free at about 2:30 p.m. A relative who did not want to be identified said he was not hurt. Aoun's soldiers and Syrian troops skirmished with machine guns, tank cannons and mortars in north Lebanon, interrupting traffic along the highway connecting north Lebanon and the Christian enclave. Police said no casualties were reported. But Aoun's command claimed in a communique that one Syrian soldier was killed, three were wounded and two Syrian tanks destroyed by Lebanese army fire. A police spokesman, who cannot be named under standing regulations, said Aoun's claim could not be verified. It was not known who started the fighting. Hajj was dragged from his apartment in the Christian enclave at about 6 a.m., according to his mother, Mrs. Badr Hajj. Mrs. Hajj told The Associated Press that ``gunmen knocked on the door early in the morning. George opened and they took him.'' ``They didn't talk much. They dragged him out,'' Mrs Hajj said, her voice choking with emotion. Hajj, 55, works for the daily Al-Bayrak, a newspaper that Aoun closed last week as part of his attempt to muzzle dissent in the media. He also is a member of the reporters' syndicate executive board, which has come under verbal attack from Aoun. The Moslem Voice of the Nation radio and the leftist Voice of the People, which operate from west Beirut, accused Aoun of arranging Hajj's abduction. ``Colleague Hajj's abduction is the latest move in Aoun's war against freedom of the press,'' said Voice of the Nation, which interrupted its regular broadcast to report on the incident. Hours after the abduction, about 1,000 people, including journalists, poets and politicians, marched in Moslem west Beirut to protest Aoun's crackdown on the media. The general has ordered media not to refer to Elias Hrawi as Lebanon's president, or to Salim Hoss as the nation's prime minister. Aoun opposed the peace plan that cleared the way for their elections, and he considers himself the legitimate head of state. ``The civil war did not break our pens and Aoun will not be able to break our pens,'' the Voice of the Nation announcer said. Since Aoun issued his media directive Tuesday, he has suspended operations of the Al-Bayrak and Ad-Diyar newspapers, and the Akhbar Al-Yom newsletter, for defying it. Al-Massirah, the newspaper of the Lebanese Forces right-wing Christian militia, said it was not publishing Saturday to protest Aoun's measures. The nation's most prestigious daily paper, An-Nahar, has not been publishing since Tuesday to avoid either accepting the directive or defying it. Radio stations have observed a newscast strike to protest Aoun's move. Aoun opposed the peace plan because it did not include a deadline for the withdrawal of 40,000 Syrian troops, who were deployed in Lebanon in 1976 to quell civil war fighting. Aoun said the Syrians violated the peacekeeping mandate by siding with the Moslems in the war.

DOC.HEAD: Mine Workers Reach 100th Anniversary on Thursday
DOC.TEXT: A century ago this week, Irish immigrants stood with British, blacks stood with whites, and rival work gangs stood together for the first time in an Ohio meeting hall to unite coal miners across the East. The United Mine Workers of America union was born 100 years ago Thursday. ``One of our proudest traditions is our solidarity and our unity, the willingness of our membership to fight and stay together,'' said UMW President Richard Trumka. The modern-day UMW faces plummeting membership in the face of mechanization and has taken steps to ensure its survival. In recent months the union has had informal discussions with the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers union to affiliate with it, an idea that already fell through once, in 1988. It reaffiliated with the AFL-CIO last year, and during the 1980s altered its constitution to allow it to represent non-miners such as machine shop workers. Its membership now stands at about 150,000, including about 100,000 miners; at its peak in the 1940s, there were nearly 600,000 miners on the rolls. ``The biggest challenge is keeping our members working and keeping our safety standards intact,'' said Joy Huitt, UMW secretary-treasurer from Price, Utah, who in 1986 became the first woman elected to a UMW national office. The Mine Workers union was formed from the National Trades Assembly and the National Federation of Miners and Mine Laborers, organizations that fought as often with fists as with words. Their fighting legacy has carried over to the union's battles with coal mine operators, armed security guards and the federal government. There were battles within the union as well. Violent organization battles raged in the coal fields from the union's inception until the 1920s. Often, organizing miners were killed by company guards seeking to put down dissent. Sometimes the guards were killed. Sixteen people were killed in a 1912 Paint Creek organizing battle. Ten people were killed eight years later in the Matewan Massacre, a tragedy revived in the 1987 film ``Matewan.'' During the 1920s Battle of Blair Mountain, federal troops moved in to quell a labor march to Logan. ``I went to work before we got the union in here and remember the battles and the shootings,'' said Porter Cotton, 78, of Chesapeake in Kanawha County. Cotton started work as a trapdoor operator at age 13, before the union sought a minimum age for mine workers. In the early days, coal companies controlled their workers' lives, forcing them to shop in company stores, see company doctors and live in company houses. John L. Lewis became UMW president shortly after World War I and stayed in charge into the 1960s. He won health and pension benefits and shorter work weeks for union members but nearly tore the UMW apart with his tyrannical rule and manipulation of votes and conventions, said Ron Lewis, a historian at West Virginia University who is no relation to the labor leader. ``Lewis nearly destroyed the union in 1929,'' Ron Lewis said. ``Lewis purged all his enemies ... throwing out his best organizers.'' Membership dropped from 650,000 in the early 1920s to about 20,000 in 1929, in part because of Lewis' purge but also because of a depression in the coal fields due to excessive production, the historian said. Membership rebounded during the 1930s and '40s. Lewis' reach extended to other industries. He helped found the Congress of Industrial Organizations and pound out labor agreements in the steel and auto industries, and his union helped create the United Steelworkers of America union in 1942. ``He was a man of vision, without a doubt probably the greatest labor leader,'' Trumka said. ``Look at what he did with the health funds and the vision he created for the union of bringing health care within 25 miles of every one of our members and then setting up a system of clinics.'' Three years after Lewis stepped down, W.A. ``Tony'' Boyle tried to maintain a similar hold on the UMW. Miners grumbled at Boyle's inability to deliver the same contract gains and backed Joseph ``Jock'' Yablonski for president. Boyle tried to steal the 1969 election, but a federal judge questioned the results and ordered new balloting. Before it could be held, however, Yablonski, his wife and daughter were murdered in their Pennsylvania home. Boyle was convicted of ordering their deaths. The deaths brought the union's darkest days. ``There are moments in our history that I would like to change, but I don't know if I'd like to get rid of them,'' Trumka said. ``You have to look at your mistakes and you have to remember them.'' He said the union also must learn from the history of deaths in the coal fields, including the shooting death on a West Virginia picket line last week, and the half-million cases of black lung disease. Trumka expresses optimism that total union membership in the United States will expand in the 1990s as workers recognize what he calls an anti-labor sentiment in the country. ``I think you will see workers standing up, walking out and banding together in the streets to demand that will happen,'' Trumka said. ``There will be one group of people who will be proudly in front in that movement and that's going to be the United Mine Workers.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: A seafood restaurant waitress said she had a dream table _ Don Johnson, Kurt Russell and a big tip. Johnson, of ``Miami Vice'' fame, was at Port Canaveral on Friday to test-drive his new racing boat. He and Russell, known for such film roles as ``Tango & Cash'' and ``Overboard,'' had lunch with seven others at Captain Ed's Seafood Restaurant. ``They were all very nice, very quiet,'' said waitress Pat McSparin, who served Johnson a chicken plate and the others chicken sandwiches, with iced teas all around. ``I just want to say Don Johnson's a terrific tipper,'' she said. The men signed autographs on the way out, so restaurant manager Rick Griffis picked up the tab, he said.

New York's Edward I. Koch has added still another cap to his mounting collection of post-mayoral occupations. The outspoken ex-politician, already working as a television program host, radio and newspaper commentator, university lecturer and diet plan hawker, has just signed on with a real estate brokerage and management firm, the company announced Friday. Koch, replaced by David Dinkins as New York City mayor on Jan. 1, has been hired as a part-time director of Wm. A. White-Grubb & Ellis, to ``advise on new business development and consult with members of the firm,'' a spokeswoman said. His pay was not disclosed.

A 22-room mansion owned by John Lennon and Yoko Ono and once rented by Hustler magazine publisher Larry Flynt has been sold for $4.31 million. Alan Curtis, 52, a sales manager for Dillion Read & Co. of New York, bought the oceanfront mansion, El Salano. He said the celebrity ties did not influence his decision to buy the property. ``I am looking to retire soon, and South Florida is where I want to live,'' said Curtis, who also owns a house in Boca Raton. The two-story mansion, built in 1919, was bought for $750,000 by Lennon and Ono in 1980, shortly before the former Beatle was slain in New York City. Ono spent $3 million restoring it. The house, which features a guest apartment and two swimming pools, was once leased for $10,000 a month to a real estate company operated by Flynt, the company said. It also has 7{ bathrooms, a fountain and a stretch of private beach.

Donald Trump, the millionaire from Queens, is being wooed westward. Los Angeles Mayor Tom Bradley is petitioning the New York real estate mogul to bring his brand of redevelopment here, couching the welcome with hints about social responsibility. In a letter to Trump, Bradley wrote that Los Angeles ``continues to provide unprecedented economic opportunities.'' Trump announced earlier this month that he bought an interest in Wilshire Center Properties, owner of the 23.5-acre Ambassador Hotel. The Ambassador property is the site of the now-closed Cocoanut Grove nightclub, once a haven for Hollywood screen legends. He promised a massive commercial, office, residential and hotel complex on the site, which was coveted by the Los Angeles Unified School District for a badly needed new midcity high school. In the letter, Bradley urged Trump to work with local community leaders and said any development in the city's more affluent areas should be matched with projects in poorer neighborhoods. Norma Foerderer, an executive assistant to Trump, said that the letter was being reviewed and she had no immediate response.

Newspaper publisher Darrow ``Duke'' Tully pleaded innocent to shooting a neighbor's dog in the head with a pellet gun. Tully, 57, editor and publisher of the Ojai Valley News and former publisher of the Arizona Republic and the Phoenix Gazette, was ordered Friday to return for trial March 2. He is accused of shooting the dog after it got loose on Oct. 24. The dog survived with a pellet imbedded in its head. Charges were filed after the Ventura County Humane Society complained to authorities. The publisher could be sentenced to up to six months in jail if convicted of the misdemeanor cruelty to animals charge. Tully resigned in 1985 as publisher of the Phoenix newspapers, Arizona's largest, after admitting that he had fabricated a heroic military record that included service in Korea and Vietnam.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Warns Recruits: Test Positive for Pot and You're Out
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS to paragraphs of other services' policy after 9th pvs, ``Acting on ...
DOC.TEXT: The Navy, reversing its forgiving approach to recruits who test positive for marijuana use, has decided that they will be barred from entering the service. ``You test positive for marijuana use _ you're gone,'' said Vice Adm. J. Michael Boorda, the Navy's chief of personnel, in an interview on Friday. ``It's an important twist'' and shows an increasing lack of tolerance for drug use in the military, Boorda said. ``We don't want to lose the battle against drugs.'' Adm. Carlisle A.H. Trost, the chief of naval operations, sent the anti-drug message to his recruiting commanders earlier this month. The new policy will go into effect Feb. 1. Previously, the Navy has given a second chance to recruits who tested positive for marijuana use in boot camp. They were allowed to enter the service but only if their periodic drug tests showed they no longer used drugs. The policy was designed to give recruits who might not have known better a chance to change. At the same time, the Navy barred recruits who tested positive for cocaine and other hard drugs. Acting on the orders of Congress, all the services began testing recruits and officer candidates for drug and alcohol abuse in 1988. The Air Force allows recruits to admit to marijuana use, but once they are signed up they must quit using any drugs, said Maj. Lou Figueroa, a spokesman. Afterward, those who are discovered or admit to drug use are released from the service, he said. Army spokeswoman Paige Eversol said Army policy allows anyone who tests positive for marijuana to try again six months later to enter the service. If they test positive for cocaine, they must wait a full year before reapplying. In his message, Trost said he was taking the step ``to improve force quality.'' Boorda said the Navy found those who tested positive in boot camp more prone to return to drug use and less likely to complete their four-year enlistments. ``If a person is not able to stop using drugs for 30 days before joining the Navy, they didn't want to be in the Navy in the first place ... and we'll accommodate them,'' he said. The admiral, who drafted the policy for Trost, said exceptions will be allowed, but only for ``the most exceptionally deserving cases.'' The waivers must be approved by Boorda or his deputy and the cases are ``anticipated to be small in number,'' Trost's message said. While the move allows the Navy to be more selective about its personnel, it is also a decision that has impact on the service's ever-tightening budget. About 2,000 sailors tested positive for marijuana use during the past fiscal year of 1989 out of some 95,000 recruits, said a personnel officer who spoke on condition that he not be identified. He said it costs $3,000 to put a sailor through boot camp and that the Navy could save money if it could ensure that those who do make it through remain in the service _ and maybe even reenlist. ``We're tightening the screws. We're serious about this,'' he said. ``Every time we can keep a kid who is productive, who has gone through advanced training, who doesn't have to get new uniforms _ that saves money. But if you keep a kid who turns out to be trouble, it's just not cost effective.'' ``Every dollar that we save, we can put into programs to improve the quality of life for those people who want to serve,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Myles Horton, Civil Rights Leader and Teacher, Dead at 84
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT spelling of Monteagle. Story first moved for PMs; one graf added on funeral. A basic obit first moved for Saturday AMs.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY11
DOC.TEXT: Myles Horton laughed when authorities padlocked his civil rights center 30 years ago. ``You can padlock a building,'' he said, ``but you can't padlock an idea.'' Horton, who survived attacks by the Ku Klux Klan and McCarthyites, died Friday at age 84. He had slipped into a coma Jan. 13 after a 2{-year battle with cancer. His Highlander Folk School, one of the most influential training grounds in the U.S. labor and civil rights movements, was derided by his opponents as a ``finishing school for communists.'' Its adherents were called ``a cancerous growth'' spreading throughout the South. The state of Tennessee raided and padlocked Highlander in 1959, alleging it had violated its charter and illegally sold beer. Those rushing to the school's defense included Martin Luther King Jr., Eleanor Roosevelt, Andrew Young, Pete Seeger, Rosa Parks and Ralph David Abernathy. The school lives on today in the rolling foothills 20 miles east of Knoxville as th``Kighlander Research and Education Center, serving as a network for activists in battles over the environment, racism, poverty and illiteracy. Battles are nothing new to the school's students. ``The Long Haul,'' an autobiography written with Judith and Herbert Kohl and soon to be published by Doubleday, relates Horton's role in the 1930s, when Highlander provided training for the Congress of Industrial Organizations, the CIO, and supported coal miners, textile workers and farmers. Highlander and Horton served as a bridge between the labor and civil rights movements, Herbert Kohl said. Rosa Parks, for example, had been to Highlander two months before she sparked the 1955, Montgomery, Ala., bus boycott. In the book, Horton describes himself as a catalyst for social change: ``If you want to change people's ideas, you shouldn't try to convince them intellectually. What you need to do is get them into a situation where they'll have to act on ideas, not just argue about them.'' Perhaps the best illustration of the philosophy was the Citizenship Schools project launched by Highlander in 1956 on South Carolina's Sea Islands. Septima Clark, an activist and close friend of Horton's who helped organize it, said it taught 100,000 poor Southern blacks to read and write _ and vote. The schools encouraged emerging leaders to form community groups that became the backbone of the civil rights movement. Highlander now is adapting the concept to the environmental movement. Last year, 400 people from more than 40 states and five other countries took part in a Xrqgram called ``STP,'' or Stop the Pollution. STP schools this year will be held throughout the country to reach fledgling groups. The son of a sharecropper, Horton grew up in Savannah, Tenn., and felt a moral obligation to act against injustice. ``He is someone who ... always took responsibility for what is happening in the world,'' Kohl said. Horton attended Cumberland University in Tennessee and studied under theologian Reinhold Neibuhr at Union Theological Seminary in New York before moving to the University of Chicago. After a year in Europe, he returned to Grundy County, Tenn., to help establish Highlander Folk School in 1932. The school blended seminars on politics and economics with square dances and tales of local history. The civil rights anthem, ``We Shall Overcome,'' was adapted from a black hymnal by Horton's first wife, Zilphia Johnson Horton. Highlander was investigated by a Senate internal security subcommittee in 1954 for its alleged ties to the Communist Party, which Horton denied. While under investigation by a Tennessee legislative committee five years later, the school was raided and staffers arrested on charges of public drunkeness and possession of liquor. One witness testified Highlander was ``an integrated whorehouse.'' It was ordered closed that year for violating its charter and selling beer without a license. Horton said guests and staff would take beer from a cooler and leave a few coins behind to cover its cost. The state auctioned the Highlander Folk School but it reformed under its present name and moved to a black neighborhood in Knoxville. In 1971, it moved to its present location. One year later, Horton retired as director but continued working and studying adult education movemgus in New Zealand, South Africa, India, Nicaragua and Europe. In 1983, Andrew Young and U.S. Rep. Ronald Dellums, D-Calif., nominated Highlander for a Nobel Peace prize. Funeral services were set for Sunday afternoon in Monteagle, where the Highlander school used to be located.

DOC.HEAD: Roseanne Barr Marries Tom Arnold
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Alana is cq in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: Roseanne Barr, television's caustic television mom, married comedian Tom Arnold on Saturday, four days after her divorce from her first husband became final. ``For the first 4he in our lives, we feel truly happy and are both eager to learn and enjoy living our lives day to day,'' the couple said in a statement released by publicist Alana Rothstein. No information was released about the second marriage of the ``Roseanne'' television star. Life magazine has exclusive story rights, Rothstein said. The ceremony and reception at Miss Barr's home was a private affair attended by 40 close friends, relatives and cast members, Rothstein said. She refused to identify any of guests or give details about the ceremony. Miss Barr called off the wedding last month because of Arnold's drug abuse. He has since been released from a drug rehabilitation facility. Arnold, Miss Barr's longtime companion and collaborator, showed some of the World Series opening-game audience at Candlestick Park how much he cared for Miss Barr by baring his bottom, revealing a ``Rosie'' tattoo. The feisty ABC-TV star, a former cocktail waitress, returned the favor by showing a matching buttocks tattoo that read ``Tom.'' Miss Barr divorced Bill Pentland, her husband of 16 years, citing irreconcilable differences. The divorce became final Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: First Direct Air Links Since 1982 Falklands War
DOC.TEXT: Argentina and Britain resumed direct air links Saturday for the first time since the 1982 Falkland Islands War, the latest in a series of moves to re-establish their historically strong ties. An Aerolineas Argentinas flight took off from Buenos Aires Saturday evening, and a British Airways jetliner left London 2{ hours later en route to this South American capital. Both were to arrive Sunday. ``We're planning a little celebration'' for the arriving British airliner, said Ian Gillespie, regional manager for British Airways. ``Six pipers from the Buenos Aires St. Andrews Society of the River Plate will pipe the passengers off.'' The two countries severed relations after Argentina invaded the South Atlantic islands, claiming it inherited the archipelago from Spain upon declaring independence in 1810. Britain counterattacked and recovered the sparsely populated territory of sheepherders and fishermen, which it has ruled since 1833. The issue of sovereignty blocked talks for years. Since taking office in July, President Carlos Menem backed improved ties with Britain and temporarily set aside _ without giving up Argentina's claim _ the issue of ownership. Trade and travel restrictions were lifted 9nOctober. Interest sections were upgraded to consulates last month. Shipping ties resumed earlier this month. Talks set for February in Madrid will mark ``a decisive stage toward renewing diplomatic relations between Great Britain and Argentina,'' Menem said last week. Britain was once one of Argentina's main trading partners, with substantial landholdings and interests in the South American county's meatpacking industry. By resuming direct flights, Aerolineas' Britain-bound flights will continue to London from Madrid, where passengers had been dropped off and picked up by British Airways. British Airways' Argentina-bound flights will continue to Buenos Aires from Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paolo, Brazil, where passengers had been dropped off an4 Licked up by Aerolineas. Nonstop direct flights will be possible when Boeing 747-400s are brought into service, Gillespie said. He said about 25,000 passengers fly the route each year.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Mid-Section Gets Snow, Ice
DOC.TEXT: A storm spread snow and freezing rain from Nebraska to Michigan on Saturday after dumping heavy snow on the Great Plains. Snow, freezing rain or rain fell over much of the East, triggering flash-flood watches in several states. The storm, which began Friday, left up to 14 inches of snow in Nebraska, as much as a foot in Kansas and up to 6 inches in South Dakota. The University of Nebraska-Omaha canceled all Saturday classes, and closed its library and recreational facilities during the morning, said university spokesman Tim Fitzgerald. Advisories warning of snow, blowing snow, freezing drizzle or sleet were in effect in Nebraska, Iowa, Minnesota, Wisconsin and Illinois. Snow and freezing rain also fell from the lower Great Lakes region to southern New England. Winter weather advisories were in effect in Pennsylvania, New Jersey, New York, Massachusetts, Connecticut and Rhode Island. Rain prevailed from the Middle Atlantic States and the Ohio Valley to the lower Mississippi Valley, with thunderstorms over the central Gulf Coast. Flash flood watches were issued for southern and central Mississippi, east central Louisiana, southeastern Kentucky, western Pennsylvania, and the northern Panhandle of West Virginia. In six hours ending at 7 a.m. EST, Cape Girardeau, Mo., received 3.16 inches of rain, Monroe, La., had 2.71 and Evansville, Ind., got 2.61. Heavier rainfall in six hours ending at 1 p.m. EST included 2.04 inches in Centreville, Ala., and 1.03 in Muscle Shoals, Ala. A few snow showers lingered over the Rocky Mountains, and fog continued to shroud some valleys in Oregon, California and Washington, but fair weather prevailed across most of the rest of the nation's western half The low for the Lower 48 states was 19 degrees below zero in Jackson, Wyo.

DOC.HEAD: Doubts Grow Over Strongman's Pledge to Relinquish Power
LaserPhoto NY28
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ This impoverished country's military leader has pledged to hand over power in elections this year, but political and human rights leaders are increasingly skeptical. Rather than moving toward democracy, critics say, Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril's regime is more and more taking on the trappings of a dictatorship, complete with staged demonstrations of mass support and intolerance of opposition. The government declared a state of siege Saturday night, hours after police rounded up opposition leaders. It reinstituted powers to deport Haitians, a move one pro-democracy leader, Jean-Claude Bajeux, said could be used to throw them out of the country. ``The possibility of elections is slim,'' said Joachim Pierre, general secretary of the centrist Haitian Christian Democratic Party. ``Even if Avril were sincere, his only support, the Presidential Guard, is opposed to them.'' The Presidential Guard is the 1,100-member military unit that put down an army rebellion last spring that nearly toppled Avril. Avril, 51, who took office promising democratic reforms in a September 1988 soldiers' revolt, has scheduled presidential elections Oct. 28, with a runoff, if necessary, Nov. 25. It would be Haiti's first attempt to hold independently run elections since Nov. 29, 1987. The vote then was called off after squads of men in collusion with soldiers shot and hacked to death at least 34 people at polling stations. In many ways, the political climate today, though far less violent, is reminiscent of the months preceding the Election Day massacre. At that time, Haiti was under the tyrannical rule of Lt. Gen. Henri Namphy, the man Avril ousted. Before the massacre, for instance, loyalists appeared on government television to urge Namphy to cancel the vote and punish election organizers for allegedly serving foreign interests. Recently, excrement was smeared on the headquarters of an opposition union and of the Communist Party, along with graffiti urging Avril to stay in power. ``We recognize the authors by their signature. The Duvalierists governed us for generations, leaving behind them a trail of blood and excrement,'' said human-rights activist Jean-Claude Bajeux. He referred to the 29-year reign of the late Francois ``Papa Doc'' Duvalier and his son, Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc,'' who fled into exile in February 1986. Avril has denounced his opponents as ``alien elements'' who are ``betraying Haiti.'' Last week, the popular radio satirist Jean-Andre Destin, 33, was shot to death while walking home from a late-night broadcast. There was no proof of government involvement in the killing, but Dischler Marcelin, general secretary of the Haitian Association of Journalists, said: ``In past months, journalists have been targeted by the verbal attacks of the government, and now the attacks have ended in bloodshed.'' The state-run media, meanwhile, appear to be promoting an Avril personality cult similar to Namphy's. Like Namphy, Avril has made frequent, highly publicized visits to provincial barracks and marketplaces to garner popular support, though he is constitutionally ineligible to run in elections this year. On his televised return from a weeklong state visit to Taiwan, Avril was greeted by several thousand people, many waving placards with such slogans as ``If Avril Goes, Haiti Will Be Finished.'' A reception cortege accompanied the 20-member presidential party from the airport to the presidential palace, passing through a triumphal arch erected for the occasion. Prominent opposition leader Sylvio Claude accused the government of staging the reception and of paying people to greet Avril at the airport. Avril has said his was an interim government that would relinquish power to civilians. He has partially restored the suspended 1987 constitution and permitted establishment of an independent Electoral Council to organize and supervise the vote this year. ``The principle of elections should be defended,'' said the prominent conservative politician Hubert de Ronceray. ``But the conditions have not yet been created, when you consider Avril's contradictory statements.'' Haiti has been ruled by a succession of dictators virtually since winning independence from France in 1804 after a slave revolt, and Avril's promise of democracy met with skepticism from the start. Avril himself reinforced doubts in an interview published this month by the state-run newspaper L'Union. It quoted him as saying that while Haiti ``is undergoing one of the most severe economic crises in its history, it is hardly desirable that elections take place.'' Unlike the democratic euphoria that preceded the 1987 Election Day bloodbath, Haitians appear wary of another massacre and have not shown much enthusiasm for elections. Only one group, a coalition of three parties called the Alliance for Progress and Democracy, has fielded a candidate, prominent center-right politician Marc Bazin, who was also a front-runner in 1987. ``The already bad political climate has worsened after Avril's spiteful comments about the opposition,'' said Arnold Antonin, co-leader of the socialist National Progressive Revolutionary Party, which supports Bazin. Even if Avril allows elections, there is no guarantee they will be fair. Less than two months after the 1987 massacre, Namphy staged army-run elections, which were widely boycotted by voters and denounced by most foreign observers as fraudulent. Political scientist Leslie Manigat was declared the winner, but Namphy ousted him in June 1988 after only four months of civilian government. As a former close aide to the Duvalier family, Avril has never been popular. Both the political right and left have criticized his economic policies, such as a recent austerity program, as likely to cause social unrest. Avril's credibility has been further damaged by his purge last year of radical soldiers and his frequent arrests of opposition leaders. In November, the government displayed three radical leaders on television with their faces badly swollen from apparent beatings. The three had been jailed on charges of plotting to kill Avril and blow up the presidential palace. The arrests triggered a general strike that paralyzed the country for three days.
