DOC.HEAD: Noriega Was Conduit for Banned Cuban Trade With US, Panel Says
DOC.TEXT: Manuel Antonio Noriega helped Fidel Castro subvert a U.S. trade embargo against Cuba through phony shipping labels and a free-trade zone in Panama, Senate investigators say. The conclusions are contained in the report of a three-year investigation by the Foreign Relations subcommittee on terrorism, narcotics and international communications, headed by Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass. The report, issued in December 1988, is receiving renewed attention in the wake of the U.S. invasion of Panama that ended Noriega's military rule. The 170-page document on ``Drugs, Law Enforcement and Foreign Policy'' cited U.S. dealings with Noriega as ``one of the most serious foreign policy failures for the United States.'' According to the report, Cuban seafood and tobacco entered the United States while U.S. high technology products made their way to Cuba. The report said Noriega used the free-trade zone in Colon to help Cuban companies in Panama. The zone at the eastern entrance to the canal was established in 1953 as a center for the duty-free transshipment of goods. The panel relied heavily in that section of the report on the testimony of former Noriega associate and adviser Jose Blandon. He told the subcommittee that a firm in Panama, Reciclaje S.A., ``is used by the Cubans to import high technology to their country, and they take it from Panama to Cuba.'' Blandon also said the free zone was used by Cuba to avoid the U.S. ban on the import of Cuban products. ``There is a system set up by the Cuban government and Noriega allowing Cubans to export shrimp and lobster to the United States,'' Blandon said. He said the shrimp and lobster were harvested by Cuban fishing boats and brought into the Panamanian port of Vacamonte. ``Then they are sent to the United States as if they were shrimp fished in Panama,'' Blandon said. He said the crates containing the Cuban seafood were labeled ``Product of Panama.'' Panama also harvests shrimp and lobster, Blandon said, adding that the Cuban catch was included in the Panamanian seafood export figures. He said Panamanian seafood exports had increased, but said that was because of the addition of the Cuban seafood to the total, not because the size of the Panamanian fishing fleet had been enlarged. Examining other Noriega business interests, the Kerry subcommittee said Noriega's brother-in-law, Ramon Serio, owned a company known as Marinac which had been given a monopoly on issuing identity cards for the officers and crew members manning the 15,000 ships carrying Panamanian registry. Blandon testified that sailors paid $80 for each pass while officers paid $100. The subcommittee concluded: ``The identity card business produces more than $20 million a year.'' Blandon also testified that Noriega controlled the liquor concessions at Panamanian airports, the leather export monopoly, the company controlling the free zone, a television station, a number of banks, and other businesses. The witness said that all of Noriega's enterprises _ legal and illegal _ produced a huge income and a lifestyle that included a dozen houses, luxury furnishings, BMW automobiles, vans, helicopters and executive jets. Blandon said Noriega also received some $3 million a year from the National Bank of Panama. ``This is what he calls his petty cash which he carries in his own briefcase,'' Blandon testified. Large amounts of cash were reported to have been discovered when U.S. troops occupied Noriega's homes and offices last month.

DOC.HEAD: Reform Communists Threaten to Break Off and Form Social Democratic Party
With AM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A group of progressive Communists decided Saturday that if the party leadership does not accept democratic reforms, they will split off and form a social democratic party. Non-Communist political parties are not yet legal under national law, but the Baltic republics of Lithuania and Latvia in recent weeks have dropped their constitutional guarantees of Communist supremacy and legalized multiparty systems. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev dropped his longstanding objection to alternative political parties last week, saying it would be no tragedy if they cropped up in the Soviet Union. The Soviet Communist Party has already suffered one break. The Lithuanian Communists voted in December to form their own Communist Party, which favors independence for Lithuania. Saturday's decision to threaten a party split came at a meeting in Moscow of 494 progressive Communists, activist Andrei Koptyaev said. The majority, led by historian Yuri Afanasiev and economist Gavriil Popov, leaned toward forming a social democratic party if their demands for democratic changes are not met, Koptyaev said. In that case, the group plans to hold an alternative party congress, he said. A minority led by former Moscow Communist Party boss Boris Yeltsin preferred to try renovating the party by achieving a majority in the party leadership, hopefully at the party congress set for October, Koptyaev said. The reformers are principally concerned with the means of selecting delegates to the full party congress set for October, he said. In the past, the delegates have been chosen from the top, ensuring continued support for the status quo. Reformers are hoping for free election of delegates by the party's rank-and-file in the belief they will force further reforms throughout the Communist Party. In another sign of impending change in the party's structure and operations, an article in Saturday's Sovietskaya Kultura newspaper called for the party to give up its powerful bureaucracy and pass control of society to the Soviet government. A brief item on the same page said that a poll found that 56 percent of the respondents favor abolition of Article 6 of the Soviet Constitution, which guarantees the party the leading role in all levels of Soviet society. However, it also said 54 percent favored a proposal to retain the Communist Party as the only party in the country, ``in equal partnership with other elements of the political system.'' The article did not say who was polled, who conducted it, how many people were involved or what the percentage of error was. An attempt to place the question of abolishing Article 6 on the agenda of the December session of the Congress of People's Deputies failed, but the vote of 1,139 to 839 was closer than many had expected.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Party Apparently Defeats Move To Split; Rallies Draw Thousands
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th pvs, `Gysi said...' to RESTORE first reference to party leader; picks up 5th pvs, `After the...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BER1
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's Communist Party chief early Sunday called for ``radical reform and consolidation'' after an emergency session, indicating a bid to dissolve the embattled party was unsuccessful. The marathon meeting took place Saturday while more pro-reform rallies drew tens of thousands of people. Party leaders met after factions called for dissolution, saying reforms proceeded too slowly since hard-line leaders were ousted in October. The Communist leader, Gregor Gysi, told the session that demands to split up ``are irresponsible and endanger the stability of the German Democratic Republic,'' according to a statement issued by the leadership. After the session ended shortly before midnight Saturday, Gysi said: ``Radical reform and consolidation are standing further in the forefront for the Communist Party. ``Party leaders decided during the daylong session to use their powers in the interest of the people and the country and less for the party,'' Gysi added, according to the brief dispatch from the official news agency ADN. ``That's designed to counteract the growing polarization among the people.'' ADN did not say how may leaders attended or if there was a formal vote. But Gysi's comments indicated the leaders had not agreed to dissolve the party. About 5,000 doctors and other medical personnel demonstrated for higher wages and better working conditions in East Berlin, government television reported. In the southern city of Plauen, about 35,000 people took to the streets against the Communists, while 10,000 farmers rallied in the city of Neubrandenburg to demand higher prices for their products, the television reported. A conspicuous absentee from the party meeting was vice-chairman Wolfgang Berghofer, a leading reformer who was quoted Friday as saying he would abandon the Communists to join the opposition Social Democrats. Berghofer's departure likely would spur others to leave the party, which is under fire for being too slow to embrace reforms and relinquish control over many aspects of East German life. Desertion from party ranks is already in full swing. Gysi said the membership had plunged to 1.2 million from nearly 2.3 million in 1987. However, the party still has a grip on much of the nation's business and political life. West German leaders are actively seeking to help pro-democracy opposition forces and cautiously considering support for smaller, established parties that are breaking with their decades-long alliance with the Communists. Free elections are scheduled in May, the result of a fall pro-democracy movement that ousted the hard-line leadership of Erich Honecker. The West German government is convinced that the leadership to be elected in May will favor German unification, and for weeks it has been outlining the Bonn view of how the process will work. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Saturday proposed a joint government commission as part of his overall plan to speed the two countries toward unity. The chancellor unveiled the idea of a joint German-German government commission during a speech in Bremen. He said the commission would handle ``permanent consultations and political agreements between the two German nations.'' Kohl said he hopes the panel could be set up shortly after the elections. Despite democratic reforms introduced in East Germany since Honecker's fall in October, thousands of East Germans continue to leave the country for the West. In downtown East Berlin's Alexanderplatz on Saturday, thousands of shoppers lined up for the chance to buy western groceries at eastern prices. The West Berlin store King's Weekly Market set up a stand and sold bread, fruit, fish, eggs, beer and other items for East German marks to raise money for environmental projects in East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Police Show of Force Separates White Supremecists, Foes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 6 grafs at end to UPDATE with governor unsuccessfully asking park service to delay rally, with Ku Klux Klan rally in Louisiana. No pickup. ^LaserPhoto AX3
DOC.TEXT: More than 2,500 police and National Guard troops brought their guns Saturday to the tomb of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., the apostle of nonviolence, to protect five white supremacists demonstrating nearby. ``The enemy is at the front door. They want us to hide under the bed,'' shouted Frankie Johnson, a 20-year-old Atlanta woman was among 75 counterdemonstrators who showed up despite suggestions by civil rights groups that they ignore the white supremecists. Authorities reported no violence at the rally led by Mississippi-based white supremacist Richard Barrett, which was condemned in advance by President Bush. However, the security arrangements caused the Martin Luther King Jr. Center for Nonviolent Social Change to close for the day. The demonstration, lasting less than an hour, took place near the spot where a parade marking the King national holiday began Monday, across the street from King's gravesite. ``That grave is not a throne. That corpse is not a king. We are here to bury a tyranny,'' the Mississippi-based white supremacist said. The Georgia Bureau of Investigation said four supporters joined Barrett; a reporter earlier counted three. As he left with a law enforcement escort, Barrett was jeered by some of the counterdemonstrators, a racially mixed and mostly young group kept at least 200 yards away in the morning fog and drizzle. Barrett then went to Forsyth County, a virtually all-white area an hour to the north, where he drew a crowd of about 15 people at Cumming's city hall. Ten of the onlookers said they were members of Ku Klux Klan groups and came to denounce Barrett because he was an outsider and because of a past dispute in which Barrett had opposed the use of Klan robes. Barrett and one other man then staged a short march in the rain as 50 state and local officers kept watch. Hosea Williams, a city councilman and former King aide, led about 60 civil rights supporters in two busloads from Atlanta in a separate march through a quiet suburban area of Forsyth County. The buses passed about 75 onlookers, some carrying Confederate battle flags. The civil rights group, protected by about 225 local and state officers, disbanded after a rally at which Williams complained the county has failed to open sufficient opportunities for blacks since a huge civil rights march there in 1987. Williams said he did not want a confrontation with Barrett, but he said he was saddened to see King's gravesite made inaccessible by the protest and police. ``Dr. King was the epitome of nonviolence,'' Williams said in Forsyth County. ``To see his grave surrounded by guns and violence certainly hurts me.'' Atlanta police reported two arrests _ one for disorderly conduct and one for public drunkenness _ in the vicinity of the rally there. No arrests were reported in Forsyth County. The security effort in Atlanta could cost more than $500,000, Harry Heath of the Georgia Department of Defense estimated. Officials in Forsyth County said security could cost an additional $100,000 there. Groups led by both Barrett and Williams have been pelted with rocks in past marches. Georgia Gov. Joe Frank Harris objected to the Park Service decision to allow the white supremacist rally just a week after the federal holiday honoring King. A Harris aide contacted the White House twice to ask that the date of the groups permit be pushed back, said the governor's press secretary, Barbara Morgan. ``We thought that was pretty insensitive to issue it at that time, when there are people here from all over the country, all over the world,'' she added. ``We think it is rather unthinking and unfeeling.'' Jim Howard, a park service spokesman in Atlanta, said there was no record of the park service being contacted by the White House on the matter. He said park service officials visited Barrett in Mississippi but failed to convince him to change his plans. Elsewhere Saturday, about a dozen robed Ku Klux Klan members ambled through downtown Bossier City, La., in a rally that attracted more police than demonstrators or spectators. More than 50 officers, including a SWAT team and horse patrols, sealed off the government complex. There were about 20 spectators, many of them reporters, said City Attorney Jimmy Hall. The Klan's area leader, Wayne Pierce, said earlier he expected 200 to participate in the march, which he billed as a show of strength to celebrate the rebirth of the Klan in Louisiana.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Accepts Invitation To Visit Czechoslovakia
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II will visit Czechoslovakia before June, accepting the invitation of the new non-Communist government in Prague, a Vatican spokesman said Saturday. The announcement comes two days after the Czechoslovak government said it wanted to re-establish diplomatic relations with the Vatican, which have been suspended for 40 years. The Vatican spokesman, Joaquin Navarro, said the date of the visit had not been determined but that it will would take place before the Czechoslovak elections scheduled for June 8 and last two or three days. He said the pope generally avoids visiting countries at the time of an election. He said the pope ``had accepted with graditude'' the invitations from President Vaclav Havel and Cardinal Frantisek Tomasek, the Roman Catholic primate of Czechoslovakia. A thaw in relations is possible now because a popular revolution recently ousted Czechoslovakia's hard-line Communist leaders, leading to broad democratic reforms that, among other things, loosen restrictions on religious freedom. The Vatican spokesman said officials would have to find a break in the pope's schedule which includes a Jan. 25 to Feb. 1 trip to five African countries, a May 6-14 visit to Mexico and a May 25-27 trip to Malta. The Austrian Catholic news service Kathpress, citing unidentified Vatican sources, reported Friday that the pope would visit Czechoslovakia on April 21-22. The Rome daily Il Tempo also said the trip would be made on those dates. Navarro said those could be reasonable dates but ``for the moment there is no precise indication'' on when the pope will travel to Czechoslovakia. John Paul formally accepted the invitations after meeting with Archbishop Jan Sokol of Trnava, Archbishop Frantisek Vanak of Olomouc and a Czechoslovak government delegation that included First Vice President Jan Carnogursky; Vice President Josef Hromadka and Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier. Navarro said the invitation from Tomasek came in the name of the priests and faithful in the three Czechoslvak regions of Bohemia, Morovia and Slovakia. He said the papal trip could include a stop in each of the three regions.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyers Make Opening Statements in Gotti Trial
LaserPhoto NY39
DOC.TEXT: John Gotti ordered a union leader shot in 1986 to avenge a slap in the face, a prosecutor said as the reputed mob boss's assault and conspiracy trial got under way Saturday. Gotti's attorney said in opening arguments in state court that the charge was false and that his client was the victim of a ``modern-day vendetta, persecution and witch hunt.'' Assistant District Attorney Michael Cherkasky described Gotti, 49, as the ``CEO'' of the Gambino crime family and co-defendant Anthony Guerrieri, 60, as a Gotti ``soldier.'' Cherkasky said the defendants arranged with the Westies, a gang of ``vicious, brutal killers'' from Manhattan's Hell's Kitchen, for the May 7, 1986, shooting of John O'Connor, vice president of a Carpenters Union local. O'Connor, who was shot four times in the buttocks and legs, survived. The prosecutor told the jury that O'Connor, who survived the attack, was shot because he had sent thugs to trash a restaurant owned by Gotti associate Phillip ``Philly'' Modica. Cherkasky walked to the defense table, stared, pointed and said, ``This man, John Gotti, head of the Gambino crime family, ordered that assault.'' Then, pointing at Guerrieri, Cherkasky said, ``This man, Anthony Lee Guerrieri, assisted in the planning and execution of that assault. ``The evidence will show that John Gotti struck back because he could not allow a challenge to go unpunished,'' the prosecutor said. Gotti's attorney, Bruce Cutler, said government agents had followed his client to weddings and bar mitzvahs for 12 years ``and not once have they seen him commit a crime.'' ``Mr. Gotti hasn't been convicted of a crime in 15 years,'' Cutler said. ``His friendships are not crimes.'' Cutler wondered how the state can find money to prosecute Gotti because of ``who they say he is,'' but is unable to find funds to house the homeless who huddle against the courthouse each night in cardboard boxes. Cutler said his client, married to the same woman for 30 years and about to become a grandfather for the fifth time, is ``not an ogre, not a gangster.'' The jury is expected to hear several tapes, some of them barely audible, which prosecutors say link Gotti to the shooting. One tape, which acting Justice Edward McLaughlin ruled admissible as evidence, contains a bugged conversation in which a voice said to be Gotti's, talking about O'Connor, said someone would have to ``bust 'im up.'' Attorneys for both sides say jurors will also hear testimony from killers, drug addicts, wife-beaters and liars. Cherkasky said that although O'Connor was the victim, he would not be testifying, and dismissed him as corrupt. O'Connor has been indicted on extortion, perjury and larceny charges in the restaurant attack. The jury has been sequestered, and their names and addresses have been withheld to lessen the chances of them or their families being harassed.

DOC.HEAD: Dockworkers' Walkout Idles Port of Baltimore
DOC.TEXT: The Port of Baltimore was idled Saturday when dockworkers went on strike, and managers claimed the walkout could cause a permanent loss of business to competing ports. About 2,000 members of the International Warehousemen's Association put up picket lines at the port, where 13 ships were scheduled to call this weekend. The strike was was triggered by a dispute between two of the port's five union locals over allocation of jobs under a tentative contract agreement that was to have been voted on by the rank and file on Friday. Economic issues had been settled for the longshoremen, who are paid $18 an hour. Port managers and elected officials warned that a strike of more than two weeks could prompt shipping companies to take their business to competing East Coast ports, dealing the city an economic blow. ``That means we're going to lose business, some irretrievably,'' said William J. Detweiler, president of Steamship Trade Association of Baltimore, an employers' group. ``There'll be no ships coming here.'' U.S. Rep. Helen Delich Bentley, R-Md., said as many as 30,000 people could suffer direct or indirect loss of income because of the strike. ``Unfortunately, so many people are going to be hurt, so many families,'' Bentley said. ``Efforts to improve Baltimore's name will be put way back for a long time.'' Most of the ships due at the port were expected to be diverted to other harbors. About 2,500 ships call at Baltimore each year, but the number has been declining as shippers move to competing ports. Baltimore has lost 29 steamship lines in the last five years to the port of Hampton Roads, Va. Virginia ports have been especially effective in luring away much of the cargo that moved by rail between Baltimore and the Midwest. Gov. William Donald Schaefer has threatened in recent weeks to take over the port's operations if there was a strike, but he declined to comment on the walkout Saturday. The ILA in Baltimore is alone in the nation in having failed to reach an agreement on local work rules. Negotiations between the union and waterfront employers have dragged on since the contract expired in October. The agreement that was to be voted by workers Friday would have eliminated what management says is one of the port's worst problems: rules allowing the union to decide when crews stop work for bad weather. But the tentative accord prompted a dispute between two union locals, one representing clerks and the other cargo handlers. The pact would have reduced the number of clerks and increased the number of handlers. When the clerks' local complained to Bowers, the New York union president, he ordered the workers' vote blocked and recommended the dispute be submitted to a labor-management committee.

DOC.NOTE: EDS: New throughout with source saying Barry will enter substance abuse treatment and delay political decisions; and U.S. attorney on possibility of charge being dropped; Jackson remarks; and editing to conform ^By RICHARD KEIL
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion S. Barry, his political career jeopardized by his arrest on a cocaine possession charge, plans to enter a substance abuse treatment program, a close adviser to the mayor said Saturday. ``He knows that he needs help, and that he can't deal with it under the pressure that he now has,'' said the adviser, who spoke only on condition of anonymity. ``There's political wisdom to it, but also there is his personal condition to think of here.'' Barry spokeswoman Lurma Rackley said that the mayor will make a statement on his personal life Sunday, but declined to elaborate. WRC-TV reported on Saturday that the mayor will postpone making any public statements about his political future for at least 30 days. Barry, 53, relinquished day-to-day administration of the government Friday to his top aide just hours after he appeared before a federal magistrate to answer charges stemming from his arrest in a downtown hotel Thursday. Prosecutors say they have audio and video recordings of the mayor purchasing and using drugs in the company of a female acquaintance. The aide said he did not know whether Barry would seek treatment on an in-patient or out-patient basis or whether the treatment would take place in Washington or another location. The aide also said the treatment decision would be considered independent of other tough choices the mayor now faces, including whether to resign from office. ``Even though everything here is intertwined with the other problem, treatment must come first,'' said the aide. ``We persuaded him he needs help, and you can't put a time limit on it, but solutions to the other issues will evolve later.'' A Barry cabinet member, also speaking on condition of anonymity, said the mayor has at least considered the political ramifications of entering a treatment program. ``That's not to say the mayor is ready to admit he has a problem,'' said the source. ``He realizes that getting treatment would be helpful to him if only because it would reduce the pressures he is under both politically and legally.'' The issue of drug treatment, Barry's control of the government and whether the mayor should seek re-election were first raised during a stormy two-hour meeting Friday between Barry and his top political advisers. Barry tentatively agreed not to run for re-election. Barry's decision to enter a treatment program after further discussions with top aides and advisers late Friday and on Saturday, aides said. One adviser said that Barry has been persuaded of the futility of running for re-election in a city plagued by drug abuse and drug-related homicides. ``He is resigned to it,'' said one adviser who urged the mayor to scuttle his re-election effort during a tense two-hour session on Friday and in a later strategy meeting. ``It is a foregone conclusion, and the mood in there was like that of an Irish wake.'' The adviser said he was uncertain when Barry's decision would be made public. Barry's re-election announcement, which had been scheduled for Sunday, ``was postponed, obviously,'' the aide said. ``Maybe that postponement will just go and go and go indefinitely,'' the aide said. Jim Vance, one of a handful of television reporters called to Barry's home Saturday evening, reported that the mayor is ``not going to make any decisions about his political life for at least 30 days.'' The WRC-TV reporter noted that he had known Barry for about 20 years, both personally and professionally, and agreed to the mayor's request that most of their hour-long conversation be held confidential. However, he said he could report the mayor's plans to delay a political decision and that Barry planned a statement Sunday morning on his ``personal life.'' The Barry adviser, who spoke only on condition that he not be named, said he is confident that the mayor will honor his pledge to drop plans for a fourth four-year term in November. However, Barry has frequently changed his mind on city issues without informing his aides. ``If he is willing to go back on minor decisions involving the day to day operations of the government, he could certainly do so here,'' said a longtime associate of the mayor's. ``But when he has time to reflect on this, he will realize that there really is no way he can run again. The decision he apparently reached Friday is one that eventually he will have to honor, even if he tries first to go back on it.'' Even if Barry does not run for re-election, he has not yet indicated any willingness to resign, the sources said. ``We haven't talked about whether he will resign yet,'' said one adviser who participated in Friday's meeting. ``These things will all be dealt with, in time, but the immediate concern was making a change for now.'' Jeff Gildenhorn, a fund-raiser for the mayor who participated in Friday's meeting, stopped short of saying Barry had agreed not to seek re-election. However, Gildenhorn said he was confident the mayor ``will do what is best for him, mentally and physically, and for the city.'' ``These are very trying times, and we want to direct the mayor in the right direction,'' Gildenhorn said. ``At this point, we have suggested that the mayor re-evaluate his position, and ... we want him to be thinking clearly and lucidly.'' WRC-TV, citing law enforcement sources, reported that the cocaine possession charge Barry faces will not be dropped unless the mayor resigns. In an interview on WUSA-TV, U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens said it was ``not appropriate'' for him to comment on whether the charges would be dropped if the mayor resigns. But he said he was ``very sensitive to the concerns of this community, to the people in this community and the need to have an effective government in place.'' ``There are a broad range of considerations as United States attorney that I would consider beyond the simple issue of holding Mr. Barry accountable for his criminal conduct,'' Stephens said. Barry burst into tears when informing his cabinet that City Administrator Carol B. Thompson would be handling the routine chores of government, said a cabinet source. In a statement released by his office on Friday, Barry suggested that he will stay involved in the government, saying he would be in touch with Thompson and other officials several times a day to monitor how his administration is functioning. Barry's departure from the race would open the door for a mayoral candidacy by Jesse L. Jackson, who moved to the nation's capital last April and has refused to rule out a bid for the mayor's chair if Barry is not in the race. Jackson told ``NBC Nightly News'' Saturday that he had talked with Barry, but not about politics. ``My concern at this poinht is intensely personal,'' said Jackson. ``We will have the time ... to meet and discuss the legal ramifications and the moves he will make as to how he was a part of this process.''

DOC.HEAD: Afghan General Says U.S. Envoys Directed Rebel Attacks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3 grafs for 6th pvs, `The general...' to UPDATE with Washington reax, guerrilla report; picks up 7th pvs, `Pakistan has...'
DOC.TEXT: A top military general alleged Saturday that the U.S. ambassador to Pakistan and a State Department envoy directed Moslem rebels in their attack on the eastern city of Jalalabad in March. Lt. Gen. Abdul Haq Ulumi, a secretary for military forces, also claimed that two Pakistani artillery units participated in the fighting. ``The plan to attack Jalalabad was directed under the leadership of Robert Oakley and Peter Thomsen, with the direct participation of two artillery military units of the Pakistan armed forces,'' Ulumi told foreign journalists. Oakley is the U.S. ambassador to Pakistan, and Thomsen is a State Department envoy. Ulumi said there was ``clear evidence'' to support his allegations, but he did not elaborate. In Washington, State Department spokesman Mark Dillen said, ``It appears to be an old allegation that had very little currency back then because it was so preposterous.'' He added that he had no firsthand knowledge of what the Afgan officer said Saturday ``but it does sound reminiscent of charges heard earlier and quickly dismissed.'' Afghan guerrillas said Saturday they killed 16 government soldiers, including Gen. Ajab Khan, and destroyed a cargo plane during heavy fighting around the eastern city of Khost. The guerrilla report from Islamabad, Pakistan, which could not be independently confirmed, said the plane was downed Saturday but it did not say when the 16 soldiers were reportedly killed. In his talk with journalists, Ulumi claimed Pakistani troops dressed in ``Afghan clothes'' fought alongside the guerrillas in eastern Afghanistan four times in 1989. Pakistan has denied its troops ever participated in the neighboring civil war between the Soviet-backed government and Moslem guerrillas known as mujahedeen, or Islamic ``holy warriors.'' The guerrillas launched an all-out attack on Jalalabad, a strategic city, on March 6, three weeks after the Soviet Union withdrew the last of its forces from Afghanistan. The city of about 65,000 people is about 40 miles from the border with Pakistan, where the guerrillas are based, and it would have given them a major foothold in the country. Guerrillas overran a key army garrison outside Jalalabad, but their drive to capture the city eventually halted under withering artillery fire and aerial bombing by Communist forces. Casualties on both sides were estimated in the thousands. It was seen as a humiliating defeat for the guerrillas, who have yet to conquer any major Afghan city. Ulumi lashed out at foreign backers of the mujahedeen, who include the United States. ``Still the attacks continue in the frontier provinces of the country with the support ... of the governments of the United States, Pakistan, Saudi Arabia and their allies,'' he said. ``Such activities can only be called terrorism.'' Afghanistan's ruling Marxists seized power in a 1978 military coup that sparked the insurgency. Soviet troops came to their aid in December 1979.

DOC.HEAD: `Invincible' Mayor Faces Toughest Test
DOC.TEXT: For years, Marion Shepilov Barry Jr., mayor of the capital since 1979, bragge that he was the fellow who hadn't been caught, even as so many of his chums and associates, even a wife, had seen the back side of a cell door. He had his vices, he acknowledged. But, as he told The Los Angeles Times in a memorable barroom interview just a month ago: ``I'm not stupid enough to have done the things they accuse me of. God gave me a good brain.'' ``What I have done,'' he repeated, ``nobody knows about, because I don't get caught.'' In that same conversation, Marion Barry, 53, had pronounced himself politically ``invincible.'' And for a few moments Friday, he seemed just as cocksure when he was led into a federal courtroom to be arraigned on a misdemeanor count of possession of crack cocaine, the very drug which is the scourge of the city and has turned it into the nation's murder capital. In customary, regal stride, he headed for the table marked ``defendant'' and, with rock-steady nerves, poured a glass of water to the brim. He teased a courtroom artist, who was focusing on him through tiny binoculars, by encircling his own eyes with his fingers. Then the magistrate noted that, if convicted, Marion Barry could go to jail for a year. Suddenly, the mayor's facial muscles betrayed him. The cool smile vanished, replaced by clenched teeth. Perhaps, only then, had reality sunk in. Barry, despite dozens of prior stories alleging episodes of drug abuse, womanizing, mystery trips and inattention to the city's business, had planned to formally announce on Sunday his candidacy for a Nokrth term. And with a political machine rivaling that of the late Richard Daley of Chicago, few would have ruled out his chances, even against the prospect that Washington's other pre-eminent black hero, the Rev. Jesse Jackson, was himself eyeing the office. No more. Barry, in tears, late Friday yielded day-to-day control of city government, which employs one out of every 12 D.C. residents, to a deputy, Carol B. Thompson, to prepare his defense. The government's case includes a positive drug test, and video and audio tape which prosecutors say recorded him buying and smoking crack in a hotel room occupied by a longtime girlfriend who cooperated with the FBI. And aides portrayed the mercurial Barry on Saturday as having accepted the notion that he cannot run again; the decision now, they said, is whether he should resign. A close adviser to Barry said Saturday the mayor planned to enter a substance abuse treatment program and a local television station reported decisions about his political future were on hold for at least 30 days. For years, Barry's black supporters, including Jackson, a fellow lieutenant in Martin Luther King's civil rights crusade, had lined up behind the mayor when he denied misconduct and swore, time and again, that he had never used drugs. By his account, such reports were generated by a venal white media and a Republican administration eager to reclaim the reins of city government from the black community. But, while Jackson, rarely at a loss for words, held his tongue over the Mayor's arrest, others felt pushed over the brink. Especially in the schools, where Barry, like Jackson, routinely preached against the evils of cocaine, the sense of betrayal erupted in shouts of pain and despair. ``What makes me so mad is that the mayor is black, representing us, our race,'' declared Anthony Witcher to his high school history class. ``Doesn't he know the stereotypes someone like me already faces? This just makes it worse. I just know it will be worse.'' And this, from junior classmate Terri Dantzler: ``He goes around telling us not to do drugs, then does them himself. I feel pitiful. And he should be ashamed.'' Among community and political allies, the dismay extended to another question as well. At that was how a man, who so prides himself on his intelligence, who already was under scrutiny for prior, unexplained forays into a hotel room occupied by a confessed drug dealer, have walked into so such a trap? ``It raises the Gary Hart question: How can one person be so stupid?'' said Democratic pollster Mark Mellman, referring to the former presidential candidate who challenged the media to track his personal life, then spent time with a woman other than his wife. U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens said Barry's arrest at a downtown hotel was ``part of the ongoing investigation of a broad range of allegations'' against the mayor, dating to the discovery that he had visited a former D.C. employee, Charles Lewis, in a separate hotel a year ago. Lewis was sentenced Friday to 15 months in prison for conspiracy to distribute and possess cocaine. He told the court that he had obtained at least $140 worth of crack for Barry on at least three occasions, and once believed that he ``should lie and go to jail to protect the mayor.'' As an outgrowth of the Lewis investigation, authorities enlisted the help of Rasheeda Moore, a former model who had been intimate with the mayor for several years, according to several news reports which quoted anonymous sources. It was she who lured him to the FBI's ``sting'' setting on Thursday, the reports said. Reports that Barry had used cocaine date to 1981, when police were tipped that patrons at a nightclub, ``This Is It,'' had seen him snorting the drug. Police said that report, and others, could never be corroborated. Another female acquaintance of the mayor, Karen Johnson, a convicted drug dealer, was jailed for eight months for refusing to testify over whether she sold cocaine to Barry. A month before he was elected in 1979, Barry acknowledged to The Washington Post that he ``used to run around with guys who went to prison or are dead. I was lucky. I was the one who didn't get caught ... when we were out shooting dice or something.'' Since then, a dozen more of his close associates, including his second wife, Mary Treadwell, and two deputy mayors, have been jailed over various charges of misconduct as Barry built a city government unrivaled, on a per capita basis, for its size. And, just a month ago, Barry was still boasting, this time to a Los Angeles Times reporter, that no cop had laid a glove on him. On Thursday, with a few alleged puffs on a drug pipe, all that went up in smoke.

DOC.HEAD: Archbishop of Canterbury Says Aid Agreement Reached
DOC.TEXT: The archbishop of Canterbury said Saturday the Soviet-backed government agreed on a church-organized relief plan for an estimated 4 million drought victims in northern areas where rebels are fighting army troops. Robert Runcie, spiritual head of the Anglican Church, told reporters he hoped the relief operation led by a consortium of three churches will start soon and that ``no obstructions will be allowed to block'' it. ``Famine must never be used as a weapon of war,'' Runcie added. Under the plan, Runcie said a consortium of three churches known as the Joint Relief Partnership would be allowed by the government of President Mengistu Haile Mariam to distribute food in the embattled northern provinces of Tigre and Eritrea. The Joint Relief Partnership consists of the Ethiopian Orthodox Church, the protestant Mekane Yesus Evangelical Church and the Ethiopian Catholic Church. The archbishop did not say if the agreement between the government and the consortium has been signed or whether the churches have been assured of safe passage for relief supplies by rebel groups in the two provinces. The Eritrean People's Liberation Front has been fighting a war of secession in Ethiopia's northernmost province for nearly three decades. Just to the south, the Tigrean People's Liberation Front seeks the overthrow of Mengistu. Runcie was ending a six-day visit in which he met with Mengistu and other top government officials and visited Asmara, the provincial capital of Eritrea, which remains in government hands. The United Nations has appealed for 700,000 tons of food and called for an ``international relief operation of major proportions'' to avert a repeat of the 1984-85 famine when an estimated 1 million people died in Ethiopia.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Begin Crash Probe
DOC.TEXT: Federal investigators Saturday retrieved the flight data recorder from the wreckage of a corporate jet that crashed while trying to land in a downpour, killing all seven people aboard. The crash Friday night of the Eastman Kodak jet strewed debris across Little Rock Regional Airport's main runway, forcing officials to close the airport and stranding scores of passengers. Crews cleared smaller debris from an alternate runway, and air traffic resumed on a limited basis late Saturday morning, said airport Manager James Rodgers. ``Right now we have a team of investigators out there documenting the scene, trying to get all the information we possibly can from the physical evidence,'' said Clint Thorpe, head of the National Transportation Safety Board team investigating the crash. Officials plan to investigate the possibility that wind shear or lightning played a role in the accident, Thorpe told an airport news conference. A thunderstorm was reported in the area at the time. Thorpe said the flight data recorder would be sent to Washington for analysis and that the device was expected to yield information in the next three or four days. Investigators also will review tapes from the airport tower of conversations between the jet's crew and air traffic controllers, and maintenance records on the aircraft were being flown in at the agency's request, Thorpe said. A preliminary report on the crash could be filed with the NTSB as early as next week, he said. Rodgers said operations were normal before the crash despite the weather. ``The weather was extremely bad on this particular flight, but it had been deteriorating all day,'' he said. The crew was attempting to make an instrument landing during the storm when the jet hit a tower 2,500 feet short of the main runway, lost a wing and a wheel, spun into the ground and disintegrated in a fireball, Thorpe said. The twin-engine Gulfstream jet was flying officials of Kodak's Arkansas Eastman subsidiary and family members from Longview, Texas, to Batesville nearly 80 miles northeast of Little Rock. The flight originated in Kingsport, Tenn., with 10 people aboard, said James M. Jones, a spokesman for Arkansas Eastman. In Longview, two Texas Eastman officials and a spouse got off the plane. The crew then decided they couldn't get to Batesville because of the weather and headed for Little Rock, Jones told the news conference. Among the dead were former Arkansas Eastman President H.L. ``Bud'' Gernert, 65, who retired last year; his wife, Marian, 65; and Arkansas Eastman employees William Schirmer, 56; Randy Wood, 39; and Nathan Casteel, 49, all of Batesville, company officials said. Also killed were Eastman pilots Don Mason, 59, and Ed O'Neal, 55, both of the Kingsport, Tenn., area.

DOC.HEAD: Candy Maker To Close Two Plants, Lay Off 650
DOC.TEXT: Leaf Inc., maker of such candy as Whoppers, Milk Duds and Rain-Blo bubble gum, will abandon two Chicago factories and lay off 650 employees, the company announced. Leaf said Friday it would close its 60-year-old chocolate candy plant on the city's Near North Side early in 1992 and would shutter a 62-year-old gum-producing plant on the Northwest Side one year later. Corporate headquarters will remain in Bannockburn, Ill. Leaf said the closings are part of a companywide modernization and simplification. ``We made these announcements very, very early so we could make fair arrangements for the future of our employees,'' James Grubiak, senior vice president for operations, said in a statement. Production of the candy will be shifted to plants in Memphis, Tenn., and Robinson, Ill., where the company makes Heath bars. Leaf, the world's 12th largest candy maker, had more than $500 million in U.S. sales in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: China To Allow Half of Hong Kong's Legislature To Be Elected
DOC.TEXT: China said Saturday it will quicken the pace of democracy in Hong Kong as a critical meeting came to a close on the future of the British colony, which reverts to Chinese rule in 1997. But Beijing's position, which it called a ``major concession,'' fell considerably short of the wishes of the territory's politicians. China also announced further restrictions on top officials of the British colony, ruling that only 15 percent of the territory's legislators could hold foreign passports after Beijing assumes control. And it indicated it would effectively split the post-1997 legislature into two houses in a decision that could facilitate China's control over the lawmaking body. The decisions were taken in Canton by a sub-group of the Basic Law Drafting Committee, which is writing the blueprint for Hong Kong's future under Chinese rule. Arguments broke out throughout the day between the six delegates from Hong Kong and the 10 from China. All have been appointed by Beijing. At the end of the day, four Hong Kong delegates announced that none of the territory's six delegates supported the pace of direct elections. ``We regard ourselves as accountable to the Hong Kong people,'' they said in a statement. On July 1, 1997 Hong Kong will revert to Chinese rule. Faith in China's promise to retain the colony's free-wheeling capitalist system for 50 years evaporated after the June 3-4 military crackdown on the pro-democracy movement in Beijing. The crackdown sparked greater calls for democracy in Hong Kong. Politicians began pushing for 20 of the legislature's 60 seats to be directly elected in 1991, rising to completely direct elections in 2003. They said a strong democracy would enable Hong Kong to resist an unstable government in Beijing and slow Hong Kong's ``brain drain.'' Saturday, the Basic Law Committee agreed to speed up democratization but not as fast as Hong Kong politicians would like. Under the majority decision, 18 seats would be directly elected in 1997, rising to 30 seats by 2003. China previously said there would only be minor changes after 18 legislators were elected in 1997. But, in a move interpreted by some as a limit on democracy, the committee also decided to effectively split the Legislative Council into two houses _ one of directly-elected members and one of members chosen by special interest groups, such as labor unions and professionals. Under that plan, any laws must pass a majority of each group.

DOC.HEAD: China Issues New Restrictions on Foreign Journalists
DOC.TEXT: China on Saturday announced new restrictions on foreign journalists, banning them from filing reports it considers false or endangering ``national security, unity or society's common interests.'' The broadly worded regulations give the government wide latitude for controlling foreign journalists following the Jan. 11 lifting of martial law in Beijing. The martial regulations had placed tight restrictions on reporters. The Information Department may give warnings or revoke the accreditation of journalists who violate the regulations, one clause said. ``Foreign journalists and resident foreign news organizations should observe professional news ethics and not distort the facts, create rumors or use improper methods to interview or report,'' said the regulations, which were signed by Premier Li Peng on Friday and took effect immediately. ``Foreign journalists ... cannot carry out activities that are incompatible with their status or that endanger Chinese national security, unity or society's common interests,'' the rules said. China criticized as distorted most foreign reporting on the pro-democracy protests last spring and the June 3-4 army attack that crushed them, killing hundreds and possibly thousands of people. The government maintains the protests were a foreign-instigated plot to overthrow the Communist system. During the protests, Chinese consulates abroad stopped issuing work visas for visiting journalists, and dozens entered with tourist visas. In June, the government expelled two American reporters based in Beijing, one an Associated Press reporter and the other from the U.S. government-funded Voice of America radio. The new regulations do not explain what are considered improper methods of gathering information. Under martial law, all interviews had to be approved by military authorities. The regulations make no mention of informal or on-the-street interviews, which were permitted before martial law was imposed May 20. Even since martial law was lifted, however, few Chinese have dared to give on-the-street interviews. Even officials often regard interviews as political risks. It was not clear if the new regulations supercede a 1986 set of rules that required foreign journalists to get approval 10 days in advance before leaving Beijing to report elsewhere in China. That rule has been used mainly to keep journalists from visiting Tibet, where Buddhist monks and nuns have repeatedly demonstrated for independence.

DOC.HEAD: Gay Man, Lesbian Couple Ordained by Lutheran Congregations
DOC.TEXT: A lesbian couple and a homosexual man who refuse to renounce sex were ordained Saturday by two Lutheran congregations defying church policy at the risk of expulsion. ``Our congregation felt this was a social justice issue, that gays are part of the rainbow coalition of God's creation,'' said the Rev. John Frykman of First United Lutheran Church in a working-class neighborhood. Jeff Johnson, 26, was ordained before 600 members of the congregation, which voted last month to hire him. Johnson has refused to take a vow of celibacy, required of homosexual pastors but not normally mandated for heterosexuals. ``We see this as what God is asking us to do; we have no vested interest,'' said Frykman, adding that to his knowledge none of his congregation's 120 members are homosexual. At St. Francis Lutheran Church near the largely gay Castro district, Ruth Frost, 42, and Phyllis Zillhart, 32, were ordained. The two congregations hope the homosexual ministers, who will not be recognized by the denomination, can bring many homosexuals back to the flock. Among other things, the three endorsed the concept of ``gay marriages.'' The ordinations _ along with that of a homosexual Episcopal pastor in Hoboken, N.J., last month with an acknowledged male mate _ represent a foothold in mainstream Christianity by homosexuals. The 5.2 million-member Evangelical Lutheran Church of America, formed in 1987 by the merger of three Lutheran groups, bans ordination of ``self-avowed, practicing homosexuals.'' Bishop Lyle Miller has asked a disciplinary committee to consider punitive action against the congregations. The dissident parishes could be censured, suspended, permanently removed from the denomination or exonerated. During the two-hour ceremonies, the ministerial candidates took the customary vows, then added another: to be ``diligent workers for justice on behalf of lesbian and gay sisters and brothers, supporting our coming out, championing our rights, challenging society's prejudices, and encouraging our relationships and marriages.'' ``Our church's policy requiring celibacy for lesbians and gay men is an unjust vow of life,'' Johnson said before ordination. ``It is a politically motivated scandal which would deny the reality of life-giving, intimate, creative, sexual relationships among lesbians and gay men.'' Despite official church objections, a sizable minority of the denomination's lay activists and several dozen pastors have openly supported ordaining active homosexuals. The local congregations say they cannot be ordered to refuse recognition of the new ministers. ``We decided that punishment, even expulsion, is a risk we would run for the sake of what's right,'' said the Rev. James Delange, senior pastor at St. Francis. Johnson graduated last year from Pacific Lutheran Seminary in Berkeley, Calif. Frost and Zillhart are recent graduates of Lutheran Northwestern Theological Seminary in St. Paul, Minn., and have been a couple for the past five years. The three will serve as assistant pastors and manage an outreach program for northern California homosexuals. The special ministry was organized to ``encourage gays and lesbians to come back into the church and to encourage congregations to welcome them as members,'' said Delange. ``We have allowed people who neither share nor understand our experience to define our lives for us,'' Frost said at a news conference. ``This must stop. It is time we embraced ourselves as well as one another.'' Miller has said that because the three have declared they practice homosexuality, the ordinations cannot be recognized.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Israel Sent Cluster Bombs to Marxist Ethiopia
DOC.TEXT: The United States suspects that Israel has sent cluster bombs to the Marxist Ethiopian government, The New York Times reported Quoting unidentified administration officials, the newspaper said in its Sunday editions there were unconfirmed reports that the Ethiopian government has already used the bombs against rebels in the northern part of the country. The State Department officials didn't tell the Times when the bombs might have been sent to Ethiopia. Also, it was unclear how many bombs were involved or whether the bombs were made in the United States or Israel. One unidentified official told the newspaper that descriptions of attacks correspond to the sound and effects of cluster bombs although no physical evidence has been recovered. A cluster bomb is a destructive anti-personnel weapon consisting of a canister packed with small bombs. When the bomb is dropped from an aircraft, a small explosion opens the canister in midair and the bomblets spread over an area several hundred feet in diameter. Israel has developed its own version of the bomb but the United States contends that Israel cannot export it without U.S. approval because it was manufactured using American technology. Ethiopia restored diplomatic ties with Israel last year and, since then, the United States has been concerned about Israel's intentions to send arms to Ethiopia. Israel wants to build a strong relationship with the government in Addis Ababa because it wants cooperation in allowing Ethiopian Jews to emigrate to Israel. The matter first was made public last month by former President Jimmy Carter. After a trip to Ethiopia, Carter said at a news conference he had been told the Ethiopian air forced had obtained cluster bombs ``from one of our Middle East allies to be used against rebel villages.''

She won two of her three television Emmy Awards for her starring role in the series ``The Big Valley'' in the late 1960s, and another in 1983 for the miniseries ``Thorn Birds.'' In 1987, Miss Stanwyck left a hospital where she was being treated for back injury to to accept the American Film Institute's Life Achievement Award. The actress, who was revered by film crews as Missy, starred in ``Night Nurse,'' with a young Clark Gable; ``Stella Dallas,'' which led to the first of her four Academy Award nominations; ``Double Indemnity; ``Meet John Doe''; ``Sorry, Wrong Number''; ``Clash by Night'' and ``Cattle Queen of Montana,'' in which she had a passionate kiss from co-star Ronald Reagan.
