DOC.HEAD: Military Declares State of Siege, Arrests Political Opponents
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with the United States deploring gov't actions as endangering Haiti's demoncratic transition; picks up 10th pvs, `Privately owned...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Haiti, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ The military government declared a state of siege Saturday night after the slaying of an army colonel, and police reportedly arrested and beat several opposition leaders. The government led by Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril said the 30-day decree was needed ``to protect democratic accomplishments against terrorism,'' but opposition leaders said it was an attempt to silence dissent before promised elections in October. The United States deplored the actions by the government, saying they ``put at risk the democratic transititon in Haiti.'' Government television said under the state of siege four articles of the constitution were suspended, including one that forbids the deportation of Haitian nationals. At least one of the opposition leaders, conservative Hubert de Ronceray, later was reported deported. Max Care, a coordinator of de Ronceray's party, said de Ronceray was deported Saturday night to Miami. The government said it also re-established an entry visa requirement for Haitians returning from abroad ``to prevent the infiltration of terrorist agents.'' The practice, abolished shortly after dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier was ousted in 1986, often was used to screen Haitians returning home. An earlier statement, also read on the TV, said the government is taking all steps to prevent ``destabilizing maneuvers liable to compromise the democratic process under way.'' One opposition leader, Jean-Claude Bajeux, said in Puerto Rico he expected that all the opposition leaders rounded up Saturday will ``certainly get put on a plane'' and be deported. ``Avril will go to bed tonight with lots of enemies. He's turning against everyone on at once,'' Bajeux said. In Washington, the State Department issued a harsh criticism of the decree and the arrests, and urged the Haitian government to rescind his actions and reiterate its commitment to free elections. ``By suspending four articles of the constitution, declaring a state of seige and arresting a number of political leaders, the government of Haiti has put at risk the democratic transititon in Haiti,'' said the statement, read by department spokesman Richard Boucher. ``Especially disturbing is the deportation, without charges, evidence of due process, of democratic opposition leaders,'' the statement said. Privately owned Radio Antilles said police earlier Saturday arrested de Ronceray and Louis Roy, a well-known civic leader who founded the Haitian Red Cross and is co-author of the 1987 constitution. Roy's nephew, Jean-Claude Roy, confirmed the arrest. Roy's whereabouts could not be determined Saturday night, but relatives said they believed he was at the airport awaiting deportation. Eight plainclothes gunmen also arrested socialist leader Serge Gilles and three members of his Progressive National Revolutionary Party at Gilles' home, witnesses said. Gilles was thrown to the ground and stomped on in front of his two small children, while the others were beaten in the groin with the butts of the guns, witnesses said. Radio Antilles said police also arrested Dr. Sylvain Jolibois, leader of the small radical Jean-Jacques Dessalines Group; Jesner Prudent, coordinator of the center-right Movement to Establish Democracy in Haiti party, and several members of de Ronceray's rightist Mobilization for National Development party. Care said all of de Ronceray's activists were released late Saturday. He said he thought Jolibois, who was beaten on the head, and other arrested opposition leaders and militants would be released as soon as they were treated for their injuries at police headquarters. ``An overzealous soldier crushed his lighted cigarette in my eye,'' Care said, adding that his back was covered with bruises from beatings. Georges Werleigh, a member of Gille's party, said he, Gilles, Prudent and five other activists of various parties were transported to the National Palace, beaten again, and taken to police headquarters. There, Werleigh said police released them and said the arrests were ``a mistake.'' The police sweep came after Col. Andre Neptune, his wife and a servant were shot to death while riding home Friday night in the Port-au-Prince suburb of Fontamara. Sgt. Emmanuel Eugene, duty officer at the National Palace, said the motive for the killings was unknown. Earlier Saturday, de Ronceray said 10 heavily armed soldiers entered his home without a warrant before noon and searched it. De Ronceray said one of the soldiers asked Mrs. de Ronceray where their weapons were hidden. ``She responded, pointing to the Bible: `This is the only weapon we have against brute force,''' de Ronceray told The Associated Press before his arrest. De Ronceray, who has urged Avril to resign, also was a key leader of the opposition to Duvalier, who fled to France in 1986 following months of protest. Avril, who took power in a September 1988 soldiers' revolt, has promised to hand over power after elections this year, but political and human rights leaders are increasingly skeptical.

DOC.HEAD: Grazing Fee Up Some Plains, Mountain States
DOC.TEXT: Livestock producers who use national grasslands administered by the Forest Service will pay higher fees beginning March 1, the Agriculture Department agency said Friday. Chief F. Dale Robertson said the monthly rates for grazing livestock on grasslands in Colorado, Kansas, Nebraska, New Mexico, North Dakota, Oklahoma, South Dakota, Texas and Wyoming will rise 57 cents to $2.86 per head month. The Bureau of Land Management, an arm of the Interior Department, announced last week that the fee for grazing on its lands in 17 western states would fall 5 cents to $1.81 per month. The Forest Service charges the same fee for grazing on some of its other lands. Fees are determined through formulas that take into account changes in private grazing rates, costs of livestock production and other factors. The $2.86 fee is expected to affect more than 1,000 permit holders who graze more than 200,000 animals on the grasslands each year. The fees are charged per head-month, which is ``a month's use and occupancy of range by one weaned or adult cow, bull, steer, heifer, horse, burro, or mule, or five sheep or goats,'' the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: European Astronaut Named to Fly on Space Shuttle
With AM-Space Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: A European Space Agency astronaut will be among the international crew aboard the space shuttle Columbia on its December mission, ESA announced Friday. Dr. Ulf Merold will serve as one of two payload specialists on the 9-day flight that will also carry Dr. Roberta L. Bondar of the Canadian Space Agency, mission specialists Mary L. Cleave, Norman E. Thagard and William F. Feaddy, Air Force Col. Ronald J. Grab, the commander of the flight, and pilot Stephan S. Oswald. The microgravity mission will be the first of a series using a European-developed spacelab module. A team of more than 200 scientists in 12 countries will conduct experiments in materials and life sciences, including gravitational plant physiology and space physiology. The materials experiments in the microgravity environment will focus on vapor crystal growth systems and protein crystal growth among others. This will be Merbold's second space mission. In December 1987, he was chosen from among 2,000 European applicants to fly aboard the first spacelab on the 10-day mission launched Nov. 28, 1983. Born 1941 in Greiz, West Germany, Merbold worked as a solid-state physicist at the Max Planck Institute for metals research before joining ESA.

DOC.HEAD: Arson Suspected In Fire Aboard Aircraft Carrier
DOC.TEXT: Arson is suspected in the fire aboard the USS Forrestal which injured 11 sailors in October and caused an estimated $2.5 million in damage, according to a Navy report. Navy investigators, however, have not determined who started the fire and no arrests have been made, a newspaper that obtained a copy of the report said in its Friday editions. Although investigators have not been able to pinpoint the exact cause of the fire, they found no evidence to suggest that it was started accidentally. ``Most logically, the fire was intentionally set,'' said the report obtained by The Florida Times-Union in a Freedom of Information Act request. The fire broke out at 8:30 p.m. on Oct. 9, three days before the Forrestal was to leave Mayport Naval Station, northeast of Jacksonville, on a scheduled six-month deployment to the Mediterranean Sea. Repairs delayed deployment until Nov. 3. Lt. Frank Thorp, a Navy spokesman in Washington, said he could not speculate whether the fire may have been set in an attempt to delay the ship's departure. The blaze started on the second deck in a funnel-type structure, called an uptake, in the ship's No. 1 main machinery room. The uptake forces combustion air into propulsion boilers. Investigators also said materials used to clean up a fuel spill on the carrier four days earlier were improperly stored, allowing the blaze to quickly spread. But the report praised crew for limiting damage to the ship. The fire traveled through electrical cable to the No. 1 elevator machinery room on the second deck, then ignited a blaze off one of the carrier's hangar bays. The elevator is one of four used to transport aircraft from the hangar deck to the flight deck. The machinery room houses the motors and cables used to raise and lower the elevators. In addition to the injuries, smoke spread through the carrier, forcing the evacuation of 1,000 sailors.

DOC.HEAD: Wayne Williams Attorney Says Appeal Filing May Include `Shocker'
DOC.TEXT: An attorney for Wayne Williams said Friday he would file petitions next month appealing Williams' murder convictions in the Atlanta child killings, and the papers might include a confession from another person. ``We may have a shocker in the way of a confession,'' New York civil rights attorney William Kunstler said in a telephone interview. ``It's not been reduced to writing at all. It's something in that line (a confession) but we can't commit to it.'' Kunstler, a member of Williams' legal team, said he notified Butts County Superior Court Judge William H. Craig of his intention to file papers in the case Feb. 9. Also participating in the conference call with Craig on Friday was a representative of the state attorney general's office, which must respond to the Williams filing before a hearing is held. Attorney General Michael Bowers was out of his office Friday, and could not be reached for comment. An assistant said he had no immediate comment on Kunstler's plans. Kunstler declined to elaborate on the confession, other than to say it is from someone other than Williams. ``I am hopeful that the state of Georgia will recognize that a monumental miscarriage of justice has occurred,'' Kunstler said. Williams, a self-proclaimed talent promoter and freelance photographer, was convicted of murder in 1982 of two of 29 young blacks killed in Atlanta from 1979 to 1981. He currently is serving two life sentences. During his trial, in which the prosecution used fiber evidence, Williams was linked to 10 other deaths in the string of slayings that gripped the city for more than two years. The Georgia Supreme Court upheld Williams' convictions in 1983, but a team of lawyers including Kunstler launched a new round of appeals. Kunstler said he expected a hearing could be held within a month of his filing.

DOC.HEAD: State Team Turned Back From Proposed Cortland County Dump Site
DOC.TEXT: Protesters formed human roadblocks Friday to twice block a state team from touring one of two proposed sites for a dump for low-level radioactive wastes. Members of Citizens Against Radioactive Dumping, or CARD, prevented a three-member crew from the state Low-Level Radioactive Waste Siting Commission from reaching a farm owned by Arthur Allen, who has offered 730 acres of his property to the state as a site for a waste dump. ``They can come back as often as they want, they'll still find us here,'' said Margie Schlegel, who had spent the previous 32 hours on alert at the anti-dump group's base camp. There were no arrests and both incidents were orderly, said Cortland County Sheriff's Lt. Chauncey Bennett. ``Both times, after lengthy confrontations, the commission people withdrew,'' he said. During the morning, a large throng of protesters backed by about a dozen cars and pickup trucks blocked the team from entering on a back road to Allen's farm, said Paul Yaman, a co-chairman of the group. The car carrying the commission workers was spotted by one of CARD's patrols, he said. The protesters kept the car trapped for about 30 minutes before a Cortland County sheriff's deputy arrived and told them they were illegally blocking a public road. CARD members in four cars followed the inspection team the remainder of the morning. At about noon, the protesters again formed a roadblock on another road, stopping the state car about three miles short of Allen's farm, said Schlegel. The crew sat in their car for two hours before leaving, she said. Protesters did not prevent other cars from passing on either road, said Bennett. Siting commission officials say they need to inspect the five proposed dump locations _ three in Allegany County and two in Cortland County _ before they can begin preliminary tests on the sites. Following those tests, the number of sites will be narrowed to two or three for more extensive testing. Under a federal mandate, the state has until Jan. 1, 1993, to designate and develop a site to store the low-level radioactive waste generated annually in New York by nuclear power plants, hospitals and other facilities. Earlier this week, protesters turned out in the hundreds to block the team for doing walking surveys at one of the Allegany County sites. Thirty-nine people were arrested. Last month, 20 protesters were arrested during the siting commission's first visit to Taylor, in which the state team had to be escorted from the site by sheriff's deputies.

DOC.HEAD: Conservatives Accuse Opposition Over Widely Unpopular New Tax
DOC.TEXT: The Conservative government on Friday accused local authorities controlled by the opposition Labor Party of deliberately inflating their spending in a bid to stir up anti-government hostility over a new tax. The Conservatives on Thursday prevailed in voting in the House of Commons on legislation tied to the new tax, despite defections within the party and warnings that it could lead to a Tory defeat in the next general election due by mid-1992. The new tax is called the community charge by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservatives and the poll tax by its opponents after a tax on individuals that was levied in the Middle Ages. It goes into effect in England and Wales in April. It already is in use in Scotland. Local authorities are funded partly by a grant from the government and partly by local taxation. The new tax, introduced by the government, replaces the previous system of local taxation known as the rates. The rates were levied only on property and were judged by the government to be unfair. This was because the burden of the rates fell unevenly and many people legitimately escaped paying them but benefitted from garbage collection, street maintenance and other local authority services. The new community charge tax, assessed against every adult in a house instead of on the building, means bigger bills for many households. Millions of people, such as adult offspring living at home, who did not have to pay the rates will have to pay the new community charge tax. The government says the average cost of the new tax per person will be $470 a year. Opponents say it will be more. Conservative Party chairman Kenneth Baker in a radio interview Friday with the British Broadcasting Corp. said the government had evidence that local authorities controlled by Labor were busy loading various items of expenditure on to their budgets. He said their aim was to inflate their spending in order to push up the level of the new community charge tax and thereby increase resentment against the government. He urged local authorities to cut back their budgets to reduce the cost of the new community charge tax to individuals. But John Cunningham, Labor's campaigns coordinator, said Baker's accusations were ``a deplorable deception.'' Cunningham described the new community charge tax as ``the harshest, most regressive and unfair tax imposed on the British people in almost 400 years.'' In the Commons on Thursday night, the government, which has a 100-seat majority in the 650-seat elected lower house of Parliament, managed majorities of 46 and 36 in two votes on issues related to the new tax. The figures indicated that about 26 Tories voted against their government the first time, and more joined in the next. The House voted 318-272 and then 313-277 to approve several motions on local government finance. It endorsed a $37 billion central government grant to local authorities. Mrs. Thatcher's original aim over the new tax was to bring home to people the high cost of electing high-spending Labor representatives to local authorities.

DOC.HEAD: Veteran Administrator Seen as Force for Stability
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 6-7 with statement from Ms. Thompson
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Barry, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: City Administrator Carol Thompson, a 10-year veteran of the District of Columbia government named Friday by Mayor Marion Barry to take over the daily running ot it, has earned high marks from officials as a good manager. Barry was charged Friday with possession of crack cocaine following his arrest Thursday night at a downtown hotel. Ms. Thompson, 36, a native Washingtonian and graduate of Smith College, was appointed as Barry's second-in-command _ the highest non-elected position in the city government _ in 1988. The administrator functions much like a deputy mayor for operations. Department heads deal with the mayor through the administrator. As several departments have lost veteran leaders recently, notably the police and health departments, Ms. Thompson has more and more been seen as a component of stability in the city administration. She declined to speak with reporters immediately, and issued a statement which said, among other things, that she had been in touch with department heads, members of the City Council and members of the House and Senate appropriations subcommittees dealing with the city's budget on Capitol Hill. ``I feel confident I will have the support of these legislative branches,'' she said. ``I know we all will rise to the occasion. ... We are proud of our city.'' Ms. Thompson was appointed by Barry to the city's housing department in 1979 and worked there until 1981. She then became acting director of the former Department of License Investigations and Inspections. She directed the Consumer and Regulatory Affairs Department from 1983 to 1986 before becoming deputy mayor for economic development for two years.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Held On Abuse Charges Following Neighbors' Protest
DOC.TEXT: A divorced couple was held on child-abuse charges Friday after about 20 neighbors angered by mistreatment of the pair's children surrounded their home and threw rocks at it, police said. James Dolney, 37, and Virginia Coulter, 27, were arraigned Thursday, four days after the hands of three of their children were burned on the grates of a gas kitchen stove. ``He heated the burner on the stove and put their hands on it,'' said Police Chief Daniel Kochman. ``The mother stood by with a cold pail of water and dipped their hands in it. When the fingers all blistered on their hands, she broke the blisters and then poured peroxide on them.'' The abuse allegedly occurred Sunday evening after the children _ Jonathan and Jeffrey, both 5, and Steven, 3 _ got into Dolney's tool box, Kochman said. Jonathan and Jeffrey spent four days in the West Penn Hospital Burn Unit, and Steven was treated and released. Those three children, and another son, 22-month-old Thomas, have been removed from the family and placed in foster homes by the Allegheny County Department of Children and Youth Services, Kochman said. McKeesport detectives arrested the couple Thursday when they showed up at a Juvenile Court hearing in Pittsburgh seeking to regain custody of the children, he said. More than a year ago, the children were taken out of the home because they were being abused, Kochman said. The two oldest children were returned to their mother in May and the two youngest were returned in November with the provision that Dolney wasn't allowed to see them. The couple had been divorced and were living together again, he said. Kochman said the latest incident of abuse caused an uproar in the couple's neighborhood. He and four other officers had to go to the couple's house Monday evening when neighbors gathered outside the house, flattened the tires of Dolney's car and threw rocks. After talking with the crowd and assuring them an arrest was imminent, the group left the area, Kochman said. ``I totally understand their concern and the way they felt,'' he said. ``It's a heinous crime, one that totally disgusts me. My hope is they never see those kids again. ``However, I can't agree with vigilantism.'' Victor Papale, director of Children and Youth Services, declined to comment specifically about the case because of confidentiality. Dolney and Ms. Coulter each were charged with one count of conspiracy and three counts of reckless endangerment. Dolney also was charged with three counts each of endangering the welfare of children and aggravated assault. Dolney was being held on $25,000 cash bond and Ms. Coulter on $10,000 bond pending a preliminary hearing Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Herbert Wehner, former Social Democratic Leader, Dead at 83
DOC.TEXT: Herbert Wehner, the fiery orator who quit the Communist Party to become of one West Germany's leading Social Democrats, has died, a spokesman said. He was 83. Wehner died late Friday at his home in the Bonn suburb of Bad Godesberg, Social Democratic Party spokesman Eduard Heussen said. He had been seriously ill for several years, suffering from diabetes, Alzheimer's disease and sclerosis. One of the most influential post-war Social Democratic politicians who had been a member of West Germany's parliament for 33 years, Wehner was born on July 11, 1906 in Dresden, the son of a shoemaker. After studying to become a salesman, Wehner joined the German Communist Party when he was 21. He became a member of the party's Central Committee in the early 1930s. When Adolf Hitler's Nazis came to power in 1933, Wehner went underground and two years later fled to exile. He lived in Belgium, the Netherlands, Prague and Paris, where he organized German emigre groups that went to Spain to fight in the Spanish civil war on the Republican side. Imprisoned in Prague, Wehner was expelled to Moscow, where he worked for some time as an official in the Cominform Executive Committee. In 1941, he went to Stockholm and was instructed by the party to investigate which of the German Communists in Sweden collaborated with the Gestapo. Wehner was jailed for one year in 1942 for ``threatening Sweden's freedom and neutrality.'' During his imprisonment Wehner decided to leave the Communist Party, and was formally expelled from the party which accused him of betraying its cause. Wehner returned to Germany in 1946 and joined the Social Democrats. From 1958 to 1973, he was a deputy party chairman. He entered Parliament in 1960 and nine years later became the parliamentary leader of the Social Democrats, a post he held until leaving his seat in 1983. Wehner, a passionate pipe smoker, became famous for his fiery and often controversial speeches in Parliament and served as minister for intra-German affairs from 1966 to 1969 during the so-called grand coalition government. When Willy Brandt became chancellor in 1969, Wehner became one of his closest aides in forging the Ostpolitik, leading many delegations on ground-breaking visits to East European countries. Wehner was married three times, the last time in 1983 when he married his foster daughter Greta Burmester. Funeral arrangements were incomplete.

President Bush says the end of former Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega's rule should be a lesson for the ``two holdouts preventing a totally democratic hemisphere,'' Cuba's Fidel Castro and Nicaragua's Daniel Ortega. ``So let Daniel Ortega and Fidel take note, like the dinosaur, the day of the dictator is over,'' Bush declared to a standing ovation at a Republican dinner. Bush, who celebrates the first anniversary of his inauguration today in the privacy of the presidential retreat in Camp David, Md., kicked off the off-year election season by appearing Friday night at a $1,500-a-plate dinner for Republican Gov. Bob Martinez's November re-election effort. Speaking in the city where Noriega remains in custody awaiting trial, Bush praised prosecutors for assembling a team ``to make sure justice prevails.''

In a show of support for an emerging democracy, Secretary of State James A. Baker III will visit Czechoslovakia next month after he holds talks in Moscow on easing East-West tensions. U.S. officials say Baker may add other Eastern and Central European stops to his schedule, as the Bush administration steps up its campaign of trying to encourage Warsaw Pact countries to adopt Western political and economic systems. Czechoslovakia is making that transition with little indication of tension. It flirted with reform in 1968 and then experienced two decades of hard-line rule after the ``Prague Spring'' was extinguished by Soviet troops and tanks. Baker, who is going to Moscow on Feb. 4 for talks with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, also is considering stops in Romania and Bulgaria, the U.S. officials said Friday.

Mayor Marion Barry's top aide is running the city government while political advisers assess the mayor's future in the wake of his arrest on a federal cocaine possession charge. Barry, who said he is innocent of the crime, wept Friday when he told his cabinet he was turning over most of the reins of District of Columbia government to his city administrator. Barry's arrest late Thursday in an FBI ``sting'' operation at a Washington hotel for allegedly smoking crack and his appearance before a federal magistrate Friday threw the city government into turmoil and threatened to end his political career. U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens told reporters a court-ordered blood test administered to Barry after his arrest came back positive.

R.J. Reynolds Tobbaco Co.'s decision to cancel a planned test marketing of a cigarette aimed at blacks is a ``victory for health,'' the nation's top health official said. Reynolds' announcement on Friday came a day after Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan attacked the company for promoting a ``culture of cancer.'' The company said anti-smoking advocates misrepresented Reynolds' plans for a campaign that was to begin in Philadelphia in three weeks for a new menthol cigarette called Uptown. ``We regret that a small coalition of anti-smoking zealots apparently believes that black smokers are somehow different from others who choose to smoke and must not be allowed to exercise the same freedom of choice available to all other smokers,'' said Peter Hoult, Reynolds executive vice president of marketing.

DOC.HEAD: `Wonder Horse' Gallops Into the 1990s
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: Hobbyhorses date back to ancient Greece but remain a favorite toy for space-age tots. Ask Chuck Sakolsky, who was in charge of making and selling nearly $5.5 million worth last year. ``The funny thing is that even though it is a rocket-ship world, kids' interest in horses has never gone away. The hobbyhorse is as basic to the toy business as anything there is,'' said Sakolsky, general manager of the Wonder Products Inc. factory in northwest Louisiana's Bossier City, near Shreveport. The Wonder Horse _ a heavy-duty plastic horse molded in mid-gallop and held up by steel springs _ is a 20th century descendant of the hobbyhorse, a stick with a horse's head at one end. Toy historians have traced hobbyhorses to the time of Socrates and to illustrations in a French Book of Hours in the 15th century. No references to rocking horses are known before the 17th century, but whenever they were invented, they had become immensely popular by the 1800s. Wonder introduced the spring-mounted horse in 1939, Sakolsky said, and bouncing horses all but eliminated American-made molded rocking horses from toy departments by the middle 1970s. ``Mostly what's out there are flat pieces of wood put together to look like a horse,'' he said, adding that most of today's molded horses on rockers are imported and are either expensive or cheap. The Wonder company plans to reintroduce its rocking horse this year, capitalizing on growing nostalgia among parents and older people. Like the rocking horse, Wonder is coming back from almost nothing. The company was founded in Memphis, Tenn.; the move to Bossier City came after it had been sold twice. CBS Inc., the broadcasting and entertainment concern that owned a Louisiana swingset company called Gym Dandy, put the two together. ``CBS got out of the toy business a couple years back. ... They sold the company to some of its managers. They really didn't have the wherewithal to keep it going,'' Sakolsky said. Basic or not, the company went under. Rotocast Plastic Products Inc. of Miami bought it for $2.5 million last year at a sheriff's sale and brought in Sakolsky to run it. ``We've doubled our business since 1987 and we'll double it again in 1990,'' he said. Sakolsky estimated that Wonder sold about $3 million worth of toys in 1988, $5.5 million in 1989 and probably will sell nearly $10 million worth in 1990. He declined to give the number of toys sold but said the company has relationships with retailers ranging from large toy chains to small shops. ``At one time, we had close to 70 percent of the market,'' he said. ``In 1988, I think we had around 30 percent. I believe we'll have 50 percent of the market by 1990.'' The company's mainstay remains the spring-mounted horse, which retails anywhere from $40 _ for a 28-inch model suitable for a 2-or 3-year-old _ to more than $100. ``We have palominos, roans, pintos ... we're coming out with a dapple gray,'' he said. Sakolsky also has gone back through 40 years of catalogs to find products worth bringing back, and has created a couple of his own. Last year the company introduced a horse of a brighter color _ a hand-painted replica of a 1914 carousel horse, painted in vivid merry-go-round hues, priced at $150. The same horse, mounted on a brass pole and sold as furniture, retails for up to $500. ``It is the Rolls-Royce of the ride-on horses,'' said Sakolsky. ``I sort of think of these as grandmother horses, because it's the sort of thing a grandmother looks at and says, `Gee _ that's what my grandchild has to have.'''

DOC.HEAD: Tough Times for Truck Makers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: While the auto industry has struggled with a series of much-publicized problems in recent months, manufacturers of heavy trucks have been traveling a similar rocky road. That goes not only for the state of their businesses, but also for the treatment their stocks have received on Wall Street. In 1989, while the stock market as a whole was rising about 25 percent, the Dow Jones index of auto manufacturing issues dropped 8.36 percent. Transportation equipment, a group that includes several producers of trucks and truck parts, fared worse with a 9.81 percent decline. So far in 1990, both groups have slumped further as the general market has come under pressure. While the fortunes of car and truck makers might seem subject to many of the same influences, they are two different types of businesses in the eyes of the analysts who follow them. Cars, and light trucks commonly owned by the public, carry the label of cyclical consumer goods, sold in a marketplace whose mood is set by such forces as disposable income and consumer interest rates. Medium- and heavy-duty trucks, by contrast, are classed as capital equipment like factory machinery, subject to the ups and downs of the industrial economy and of the confidence of business planners. Dealers' truck sales in the United States began 1989 at a record-setting pace, and then fell sharply by late summer. ``It was a huge swing,'' said Frank Prezelski, an analyst who follows the industry for Deutsche Bank Capital Corp. in New York. After a small net decline in sales for 1989 as a whole, Prezelski projects a further decrease of 10 percent to 15 percent in 1990. At their present level, ``we believe capital goods stocks reflect a recession, or at least a meaningful downturn,'' said Karen Ubelhart, an analyst who follows the group for Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. Although investment opportunities may be developing in some other types of equipment stocks, she added, ``we would continue to avoid the truck sector. Despite substantial stock declines, we believe the chance of further earnings-per-share disappointment exists.'' Some of the stock declines have been substantial indeed. Loss-plagued Mack Trucks, which Ubelhart characterizes as ``a troubled company in a troubled industry,'' has lately traded at a little above $5 in the over-the-counter market, down from $15.37 at its early-1989 peak. The stock of Navistar, a major truck producer traded on the New York Stock Exchange, has fallen over the same period from near $7 to around $4. Prezelski at Deutsche Bank agrees that the near-term news for the industry is likely to remain negative. But further ahead, he sees a ``super cycle of the '90s'' developing that would produce a dramatic improvement. ``After a slow start in 1990, we expect an acceleration of orders and shipments for several years, culminating in a peak of demand, probably in 1993, in both North America and Europe,'' Prezelski says in a current report on the industry, ``We believe that the early 1990s will see all-time record truck demand in North America and probably in Europe due to the need to replace aging fleets in the United States and the repositioning of European truckers for the changing market of the post-1992 period as European Common Market integration becomes a reality.''

DOC.HEAD: Wall Street Sets Fed Vigil
DOC.TEXT: Whatever dance the stock and bond markets do in the days and weeks ahead, Chairman Alan Greenspan of the Federal Reserve Board is likely to be calling the tune. That's the near-unanimous expectation on Wall Street as Greenspan prepares for a series of appearances before varous committees of Congress beginning this coming week. Greenspan makes his Capitol Hill rounds at a time when hopes are dimming for any further moves by the Fed to relax its credit policy. If the outlook for the U.S. economy alone were at issue, analysts say, the central bank would have a few problems pushing interest rates lower right now, given a recent revival of worries about inflation. But that's not the biggest deterrent bothering the private analysts and economists who make their living trying to guess the Fed's next move. There also is the new variable of rising interest rates in Japan, West Germany and other industrialized countries, in some cases to their highest levels in several years. This tends to exert upward pressure on U.S. interest rates, because yields on American securities must remain competitive to attract money from international investors. If the Fed should choose to fight that pressure, many analysts believe, the result could well be a dollar decline in foreign exchange. But many observers see potential pitfalls as well in a restrictive Fed policy. Such an approach theoretically increases the chances of a recession. Beyond that, many believe it is a perilous approach in a period of shaky credit conditions in the ``junk'' bond market and at banks with problem loans on their hands. ``During a period of financial distress, many shocks can occur and overwhelm the financial markets,'' said Hugh Johnson, an analyst at First Albany Corp. in Albany, N.Y. ``The effect of these shocks can be aggravated by a Federal Reserve that is reluctant (justifiably so) to add liquidity to the markets each time a decline occurs. ``There is a risk that the Federal Reserve will be seduced, by declines in the dollar or intermittently strong inflation and economic data, into keeping interest rates too high, too long.'' With such worries dragging it down, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 11.31 to 2,677.90 in the past week. The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell .76 to 187.56; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 1.16 to 440.88, and the American Stock Exchange market value index was down 6.15 at 366.08. Volume on the Big Board averaged 172.26 million shares a day, against 161.92 million the week before. For much of last year, the Fed generally was perceived to be facing a choice between two relatively straightforward options _ tightening credit to slow inflation or easing it to stave off recession. The assignment was a juggling act, to be sure, but there were really only two balls that had to be kept in the air. Now, many observers worry, the central bank may be faced with more elaborate challenges, some of which seem to be mutually contradictory. ``It is hard to ascribe a universal cause'' to the problem of rising interest rates overseas, said James Grant, editor of the biweekly Grant's Interest Rate Observer. ``Inflation in Japan, oil prices notwithstanding, is quoted at only 1{ percent. Inflation in Switzerland is 5 percent. Yet interest rates are up, violently, in both countries. ``Money-market yields have been rising in West Germany, where economic growth is sizzling. But they have not been falling appreciably in the U.S., where growth is vanishing. ``The Federal Reserve would no doubt prefer to be easier,'' Grant said, ``but the dollar and the domestic inflation rate tie its hands.''

DOC.HEAD: Pricing The Market
DOC.TEXT: The price of stocks at any one time has a lot to do with dreams, the level of lassitude in the herd, and the madness of the crowd, but beneath all that are some fairly good yardsticks. Here are some of them at mid-January, provided by the statisticians at Wright Investors' Service, which believes in the superiority of fact over opinion, evidence over wishes, and hunches and reason over all. At mid-month the Dow Jones industrial average was down 5 percent from its Jan. 2 all-time high of 2,810.15 points, and Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was off 6.3 percent from its high. But these readings are dominated by the bigger companies. While the Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 still showed gains of nearly 20 percent over the past year, the broader-based Value Line composite index has risen only 5 percent.
DOC.HEAD: PRICE-EARNINGS
DOC.TEXT: At about 337 in mid-January, the S&P 500 was priced at 14.5 times estimated earnings for the previous 12 months, or well below the peak of 21 in the summer of 1987. Based on anticipated year-ahead earnings, the P-E was 14, compared to 14.8 in 1987. For comparison, the S&P's postwar average P-E is 13.5, and its latest 20-year average is 12.2.
DOC.HEAD: PRICE-CASH FLOW
DOC.TEXT: The S&P industrial average at mid-month was priced at 7.6 times estimated 1990 cash flow, about 20 percent higher than the 6.2 price-cash flow multiple averaged over the past 20 years.
DOC.HEAD: PRICE-EQUITY
DOC.TEXT: At its peak in August 1987, the S&P 500 was priced at 2.4 times its equity value; at mid-month, the market's price-equity ratio is 2.2. Comment from Wright: ``This multiple shows the market in its worst light, since 2 times book value has time and again acted as a warning signal of an impending market correction.''
DOC.HEAD: PRICE-SALES
DOC.TEXT: The S&P industrial average was priced at 69 percent of estimated 1990 sales, a level almost one-quarter higher than its 20-year average of 55 percent.
DOC.HEAD: PRICE-OPERATING PROFITS
DOC.TEXT: At mid-month, the S&P 500 was priced at 226 percent of its average price level of the past 20 years. In contrast, corporate operating profits are running at just 156 percent of their 1970-1989 average.
DOC.HEAD: WRIGHT'S ASSESSMENT:
DOC.TEXT: ``Most stock market price-value measures are currently on the high side, suggesting that any negative economic or corporate news is likely to produce a decline in stock prices. ``Since the outlook for operating profits remains weak, it is reasonable to expect that the recent weakness in stock prices will extend further into 1990.''
DOC.HEAD: WRIGHT'S FORECAST:
DOC.TEXT: Economic growth in 1990 is likely to fall below consensus expectations, with disappointing corporate earnings. ``Consequently, until interest rates decline and economic fundamentals improve, the stock market's negative trends are likely to persist. Wright expects bond market returns to exceed equity returns in the coming year.'' That message went out last week from the Bridgeport, Conn. headquarters of of Wright, an international adviser to institutional investors and manager of large portfolios.

DOC.HEAD: Campeau's Financial Plight Only Part of the Retailing Story
DOC.TEXT: Few talk-radio listeners in the New York area have not heard that Bonds, the men's clothing store, is going out of business. Bonds, owned by Eagle Clothes Inc., has bombarded the airwaves with ads touting its close-out sale. The store is not alone in its predicament. Mattress discounter Bed City Shops Inc., fur retailer Antonovich Inc. and the Foxmoor women's clothing chain are among several retailers sorting out their finances under the supervision of bankruptcy court. Now that Federated Stores Inc. _ the renamed holding company for Campeau Corp.'s U.S. department store operations _ has been added to the list, customers are wondering whether something is rotten in retailing. The answer, say analysts and store executives, is not really. Some companies, like Campeau, have peculiar problems, and in general, the shake-out is part of a natural winnowing process in the business. Campeau's fall from grace, although the largest bankruptcy case in retailing history, had almost nothing to do with the business of selling merchandise. Rather, the Campeau stores were victims of a love affair with leverage, a legacy of the 1980s takeover obsession. Most of the blame belongs to Robert Campeau, founder of the Canadian real estate development company, who borrowed heavily to finance his dream of presiding over a vast retail domain. His advisers helped turn the dream into a nightmare by failing to foresee that the price he would pay was too dear. The huge sums spent for Federated Department Stores Inc. in 1988 and Allied Stores Corp. in 1986 saddled the two with $7.7 billion in debt. By September it became clear their profits couldn't cover their debt payments. On Jan. 15, their fate was put into the hands of a Cincinnati bankruptcy court judge. But famous retail names in the Campeau constellation, including Bloomingdale's, Burdines, Jordan Marsh and Lazarus, are not likely to disappear, going the way of now-defunct W.T. Grant Co. Industry experts make the point that in contrast to the Campeau debacle, Grant failed in 1975 largely because of mismanagement. Campeau's stores, which were profitable before being leveraged to the hilt to finance the mergers, could emerge from their Chapter 11 restructuring _ possibly separated and under new ownership _ with minimal damage to their reputations. Avijit Ghosh, a marketing professor at the New York University's Leonard N. Stern School of Business, said recent developments in retailing reflect the overall business climate in which consolidations have sometimes required painful adjustments. ``Retailing has been going through a shake-out period,'' but the industry as we know it isn't in its death throes, Ghosh said. ``Ten years ago everybody was talking about the fact that specialty stores would wipe out department stores,'' Ghosh said. ``That has not happened. Department stores have held their own.'' Many department stores are thriving. Cash-rich May Department Stores Co. has become the envy of the debt-laden; Nordstrom Inc. is admired for its service; while J.C. Penney Co. Inc., Dayton Hudson Corp. and Dillard Department Stores Inc. have become darlings of Wall Street investment analysts. The star performers are following a principle of retailing: They adapt to changing customer tastes and spending patterns. Those who can't change fall by the wayside. ``We are a self-cleansing industry,'' said William R. Howell, chairman and chief executive officer of Penney. That means when women shun mini-skirts, stores must stock more mid-calf lengths, for instance. Or when consumers decide regular retailers charge too much, stores must prove their prices are fair, as Sears, Roebuck and Co. is trying to do with its highly publicized switch last March to ``everyday low prices.'' The success so far of Sears' pricing policy hasn't been impressive. Sears hasn't made itself distinctive enough to give people new reasons to shop there. Analysts say the giant retailer better make up its mind fast on an identity because better-focused, faster-growing competitors are snapping at its heels. Some of the serious problems that do exist in retailing are symptoms of highly saturated markets. What is going on in the New York metropolitan area is a prime example of how hard it is for too many stores to co-exist without cutting each others' throats. Stores such as Bonds and Bed City ran into trouble to some extent because they had too many competitors. High rents didn't help matters. ``I think the country is overstored. Many of us fell into the trap of opening stores everywhere but the customer ends up paying more money because somebody's got to foot the bill for the rent,'' said Jeremiah Crowley, president and chief executive officer of Bed City. In an industry where only the fittest should survive, the publicity over the Federated bankruptcy filing has drawn unfair attention, store executives contend. Harwell W. Proffitt, chairman emeritus of Proffitt's Department Stores based in Alcoa, Tenn., outside of Knoxville, said the situation makes him sad. ``The public I think perceives that our industry has a problem,'' he said while in New York attending a national merchants convention this past week. ``Retailers are getting a bum rap they don't deserve.''

DOC.HEAD: Advertisers Angle to Reach Huge Super Bowl TV Audience
DOC.TEXT: This year's Super Bowl telecast promises to have it all _ fast moves, wild sounds, emotional performances from some old veterans and the emergence of some newcomers. And that's only in the commercials. A car commercial that is to debut on the program next Sunday has generated irate complaints that the ad promotes irresponsible driving. A soft drink maker is using a new ``three-dimensional'' sound technique in an ad which also reunites some people who appeared in a similar commercial nearly 20 years ago. And being introduced is a new shaving instrument on which its creator already has invested $200 million and a decade in development. For those who get bored with the game, a beer company has come up with a football simulation for the second year pitting teams of helmeted beer bottles against each other in a contest played out over five commercials. Broadcasts of the National Football League's annual championship game, which this year matches the San Francisco 49ers against the Denver Broncos, traditionally attract one of television's biggest audiences of the year. That has enabled the network airing the game to charge record amounts for advertising time on the show. CBS is charging $700,000 for a 30-second commercial in this year's game, up from $675,000 on the 1989 broadcast. Advertisers view the broadcast as an opportunity to expose new products or advertising campaigns. Some use the sponsorship to motivate sales forces. In Super Bowl broadcasts over the past decade, Apple Computer introduced its Macintosh personal computer with an Orwellian ad that only ran once, Burger King found the goofy guy named Herb who had never eaten its burgers and Timex showed divers who unearthed a replica of its new watch beneath the Red Sea. ``It is not just a high-rated show _ it's an event,'' said Arnold Chase, director of network operations from the ad agency Bozell. ``People make a date to watch the Super Bowl. They don't plan anything else for that afternoon.'' Hal Trencher, vice president of sports marketing and sales for CBS Sports, said that despite the higher price, all 28 minutes of commercials in this year's game were sold by Thanksgiving. Twenty different advertisers bought time in the game, down from 30 last year. ``The idea seems to be if you are going to be in it, you dominate it with as much inventory as possible,'' Trencher said. But the price has gotten too high for some advertisers, including some who tried to capitalize on the popularity of the game anyway. Holiday Inns Inc., based in Memphis, Tenn., spent more than $5 million this fall on a campaign in which it selected a dozen people over a 12-week period for trips to the Super Bowl in New Orleans. The company announced a winner a week in commercials on ``Monday Night Football'' broadcasts on ABC. The winners will be at the game, but Holiday Inns won't be on the Super Bowl broadcast. ``It's pretty cost-prohibitive for us,'' said spokeswoman Faith Morris. Sterling Drug Co. ran a promotion in nine cities this fall that it called the ``Phillips' Milk of Magnesia Super Bowl Flush.'' Radio announcers asked listeners to name the activity most frequently performed during the Super Bowl. Those who called to say ``toilet flushing'' were entered in a sweepstakes with nine winners getting trips to the Super Bowl. Spokesman Terry Kelly said the company was not sure as of Friday whether it could buy commercial time for the laxative on the game broadcast. Here are a few commercial highlights to look for in the Super Bowl broadcast: FAST MOVES: Nissan Motor Corp. in USA plans to run a new ad for its Nissan 300ZX Turbo that shows a driver fantasizing about the car outrunning a motorcyle, a race car and a jet plane. The industry-backed Insurance Institute for Highway Safety asked Nissan and CBS not to run the ad. ``It sends out just one message _ look how fast this car can go,'' said institute president Brian O'Neill. Nissan plans to run the ad anyway. CBS declined comment. WILD SOUNDS: Coca-Cola Co. is employing a new sound technique on a 60-second commercial that reprises its 1971 ad featuring the song, ``I'd Like To Teach The World To Sing.'' The technique generates sound that seems to be coming from many points in a room, but it will be picked up only on stereo TV sets. OLD FACES: Coca-Cola reunites about two dozen people who appeared in the 1971 ``Hilltop'' ad and shows their children joining them in song on the same Italian hilltop where the first ad was shot. Pepsi-Cola Co. has new ads with former Pepsi product promoters Michael J. Fox and San Francisco quarterback Joe Montana. Anhueser-Busch Inc. plays its ``Bud Bowl II'' clash of beer bottles in several ads. The Budweiser team defeated Bud Lite last year. NEWCOMERS: Gillette Co. will be introducing its Sensor shaving product that it unveiled for the trade and the media last year and on which it is banking considerable resources. Toyota Motor Sales USA Inc. and General Motors Corp.'s Pontiac division also have new ads.

DOC.HEAD: Bankruptcy Filing Expected To Further Sober Buyout Business
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 29-31, beg ``Congress was out'' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with House Judiciary Committee hearing planned, picks up 32nd graf, Treasury Secretary; also SUBS 22nd graf, beg ``PaineWebber officials'' to fix typos.
DOC.TEXT: When Campeau Corp.'s department stores sought bankruptcy court sanctuary, it didn't surprise Wall Street dealmakers who months ago saw the takeover business punctured by the failure of the company's record retailing buyout. But Campeau's latest problems seem to have driven another stake into the heart of the once-raging market for corporate buyouts. Bankers and investment firms have become even warier. And, ``it's made investors more cautious,'' said Perrin Long, a securities industry analyst with Lipper Analytical Services Corp. Campeau's department store divisions, Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp., filed for protection from their creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy law. The divisions have a combined $7.7 billion in debt. Much of it was borrowed through high-interest junk bonds to finance the purchases by Campeau, a Canadian real estate developer, of Allied in 1986 and Federated in 1988. The takeover business, which boomed in the '80s on the back of junk bond financing, had to shift quickly into low gear after Campeau revealed its troubles last September. Financing for several deals, including Ramada Inc.'s restructuring and Coniston Partners' acquisition of TW Services Inc., had to be revamped because of junk bond market gyrations. Furthermore, big banks made cautious by the Campeau mess refused to back a planned employee-management buyout of United Airlines' parent UAL Corp. Suddenly, takeover financing appeared to be drying up. Wall Street reacted by throwing a tantrum _ the collapse of the UAL deal helped send the Dow Jones industrial average plunging 190 points on Oct. 13. By the time Federated and Allied headed into court last week _ as many observers had expected would happen _ investment bankers and dealmakers already were coping with a changed environment. But experts say the Campeau filing has helped to subdue the buyout market further. Companies still will be bought and sold, but finding bond investors will be difficult, said Long. ``We're in a transitional period because junk bond financing kind of has a dirty name,'' he said. Norman Weinger and Michael Metz, two Oppenheimer & Co. analysts, agreed in a report last week that mergers and acquisitions will involve bigger commitments of equity by buyers. Investors simply don't want to leave themselves open to the kinds of losses that Campeau's creditors are facing. Investment firms were listed among Campeau's biggest creditors. The firms own or hold for others billions of dollars in Federated and Allied bonds, and also put up millions of their own dollars for short-term bridge loans to help Campeau complete the Federated deal. First Boston Corp., Campeau's lead adviser in the Federated deal, could lose as much as $293 million, according to Fred Garcia, a First Boston spokesman. Of that amount, $43 million is from junk bonds owned by First Boston, Garcia said. The remaining $250 million is from a bridge loan. First Boston already has provided for any losses by charging them against its 1989 earnings, Garcia said, adding that the company still showed a profit for the year. Another of Campeau's more than 50,750 creditors is PaineWebber Inc., which put up a $95 million bridge loan in the Federated buyout. A PaineWebber spokesman, Jeffrey Taufield, said the company's losses on the loan have been offset somewhat by fees it collected on the Federated deal. Like First Boston, PaineWebber has adjusted its 1989 earnings to reflect any losses from the unpaid loan. Publicly, the companies portrayed any losses as a fact of investment banking life. ``We remain committed to the merchant banking business, understanding _ as has been demonstrated very clearly _ that it is a high risk and high reward business,'' said Garcia. PaineWebber officials will continue looking at opportunities ``in companies where they believe there is long-term potential,'' Taufield said. But investment bankers have been chastened somewhat by the Campeau filing. ``It would be foolish for us not to consider current market conditions in any transaction,'' said an employee at one Wall Street firm. ``We're not backing away _ but we've got our eyes open.'' Long predicted investment firms would move to reduce their exposure to bridge loans, which generally are refinanced with bond sales. The firms and other creditors are lining up to see how much they can recover from Campeau. Long speculated the firms might get 20 cents back for each dollar they lent. Besides their own balance sheets, dealmakers are also concerned that Campeau's troubles may revive anti-takeover sentiment in Washington. A year ago, after the record $24.53 billion leveraged buyout of RJR Nabisco Inc. but well before Campeau's problems became public, congressional committees held hearings on possible ways of curbing debt-financed buyouts. House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jack Brooks has already announced that his committee will hold hearings on the Campeau filing and and look into the consequences of leveraged buyouts. Brooks said he feared the Chapter 11 filing was ``only the beginning, and that we will see the takeover trophies of the 1980s become the bankruptcy case names of the 1990s.'' Another I-told-you-so came from Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, whose state is home base for Federated and Allied. ``Campeau represents the merger mania of the '80s, when companies were more interested in devouring one another than producing a better product,'' Metzenbaum said. Congress was out of town last week and spokesmen for the Senate Finance and House Ways and Means committees said there had been no discussion of those panels holding new hearings in the wake of the Campeau filing. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady _ who last year testified that investors could be ``left holding the bag'' if debt-laden buyout targets ran into trouble _ has not commented publicly on the Campeau filing. Brady last year did not advocate any limits on takeovers, saying market forces should be allowed to determine the future of the buyout process. Congress passed some minor restrictions on the deductibility of interest from debt-financed buyouts last year. Jim Jaffe, an aide to Ways and Means Chairman Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., said the committee was unable to garner enough support for more substantive changes because of a lack of guidance from the Bush administration. ``That is really what people are waiting for,'' Jaffe said. ``They figure it's not worth doing anything if the administration isn't going to ultimately sign on.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Big Companies, Two Big PR Problems, Two Radically Different Approaches
DOC.NOTE: EDS: UPDATES with Reynolds announcing cancellation of Philadelphia test marketing; No pickup
DOC.TEXT: When AT&T service conked out and waylaid millions of callers, the phone giant scrambled to fix its image by apologizing and offering compensation. When the top U.S. health official blasted R.J. Reynolds for peddling a new cigarette to blacks, the company chastised him for paternalism. Two of the best-known corporations in American business were responding to potentially enormous public relations crises this past week. But their strategies couldn't have differed more. ``I think it's clear that AT&T responded admirably by accepting criticism and trying to make amends for what was clearly a loss of service,'' said Gene Kimmelman, legislative director of the Consumer Federation of America, a Washington-based public interest group. ``Certainly, RJR didn't respond the way AT&T did.'' On Friday, R.J. Reynolds announced it was canceling its Philadelphia test marketing of the new cigarette, saying the company's efforts have been misrepresented by smoking opponents. American Telephone & Telegraph Co.'s long-distance service has been touted by the company as the most sophisticated and reliable in the world. When it abruptly failed for nine hours on Martin Luther King day, the company faced one of the most serious public image problems since the breakup of the Bell System monopoly last decade. The company, which has 80 million customers and dominates the long-distance market, admitted a lapse in its standards, apologized in full-page newspaper ads and offered Valentine's Day discounts to compensate. ``I would give AT&T high marks for facing up to the public and not trying to be secretive about it, not trying to stonewall,'' said James Arnold, president of Chester Burger Co., a New York consulting firm that specializes in public relations. Robert Irvine, a Louisville-based public relations consultant and the author of ``When You Are the Headline,'' a book of advice to public figures on how to respond to crises, said AT&T shrewdly executed what he called ``classical crisis management.'' ``Once they knew they had the problem, they disclosed it quickly,'' he said. ``Now the Valentine's thing is a little cute, but it's their way of saying, `We want to do something.''' Irvine and other public-relations experts said R.J. Reynolds, on the other hand, may have caused itself an unwanted problem with a decision to manufacture and test-market a new cigarette aimed at blacks, called Uptown. Blacks historically have suffered higher rates of cancer and other smoking-related illnesses, and R.J. Reynolds' strategy has been seized upon by anti-smoking groups as another example of what they call the tobacco industry's cynical and sleazy business practices. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan elevated the criticism this past week by traveling to Philadelphia, the key Uptown test market, and accusing R.J. Reynolds of promoting a ``culture of cancer.'' Though the company declined to respond publicly, it implicitly rebuked Sullivan by saying it was ``disturbed by the sense of paternalism'' surrounding the controversy, as though blacks were less able to choose to smoke. ``What R.J. Reynolds did was to base its strategy on marketing decisions,'' consultant Arnold said. ``They ran afoul of public attitudes and it has made them appear to be out of sync.''' In announcing the decision to cancel the test, Peter Hoult, RJR executive vice president of marketing, said, ``We regret that a small coalition of anti-smoking zealots apparently believes that black smokers are somehow different from others who choose to smoke and must not be allowed to exercise the same freedom of choice available to all other smokers.'' Before Friday's announcement, Ahron Leichtman, president of the Citizens Against Tobacco Smoke, a Washington-based activist group, said he saw R.J. Reynolds' behavior in the Uptown controversy as the start of a possibly broad new front in the battle against cigarette consumption. ``There are no ethics with these tobacco industry executives, no ethics. If they don't get 5,000 new smokers every day, they lose money,'' he said. ``This R.J. Reynolds Uptown campaign just may blow up in their face.'' In other business and economic news this past week: _The Campeau Corp. of Canada, owner of many famous U.S. department store chains ranging from Bloomingdale's to Burdine's, put them into Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors because of a crushing debt load. It was the biggest bankruptcy filing in retailing history and one of the biggest casualties of the merger craze of the 1980s, when Campeau bought the stores with billions of dollars in loans. The stores said they would remain open. _Bank of New England Corp., one of the biggest banks in the Northeast, said it expects to report a loss of $1.05 billion for 1989 because of bad real estate debt and was seeking to sell more than $6 billion in assets to stay solvent. Banking industry analysts interpreted the action as another grave sign of economic problems in New England and speculated that the federal government might have to take over the bank. _Corporate profits and the government's latest data combined to show the economy remains weak and inflation hasn't gone away, which left the stock and bond markets unsettled. Major computer makers reported sharply lower fourth-quarter results; Boeing, Conrail and Pillsbury were among prominent companies announcing job cuts; the November trade deficit widened to $11.5 billion, the worst showing in 11 months; and inflation statistics showed the 1989 rate totaled 4.6 percent, the worst since 1981.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Recalls Mislabeled Pain Reliever for Children in Two States
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration has recalled Carriage brand Children's Non-Aspirin Pain Relief chewable tablets in New Jersey and Pennsylvania, saying some bottles contained potentially toxic doses for children. The bottles are filled with adult sinus tablets and had been mislabeled as the children's medicine, the FDA said. The FDA said the instructions on the mislabeled bottles could result in a child taking a dose of acetaminophen four times higher than the children's dose and potentially toxic doses of two other ingredients _ the decongestant phenyl propanolamine and the antihistimine phentoloxamine. The FDA said the bottles were labeled as chewable tablets of acetaminophen 80 milligrams with lot number 082427 and the expiration date 9-90 on the bottom of the bottle. The recall covers CR Pharmacies in New Jersey and Pennsylvania. American Pharmaceutical Co. of Passaic, N.J., manufactures the lot for CR Pharmacies, owned by Laneco Supermarkets. Calls to American Pharmaceutical's office were not answered Friday evening. The manufacturer estimates that about 100 bottles of the adult sinus medicine were mislabeled as the chewable acetaminophen for children, the FDA said in a statement. The mislabeled bottles were included in a shipment of 288 bottles of acetaminophen last year to CR Pharmacies and Laneco supermarkets around Phillipsburg and in the Lehigh Valley area in eastern Pennsylvania.
